Pleiades Change Log: 2020-10-12 - 2023-04-04

New Place Resources

  • 10th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 2nd Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 3rd Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 4th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 5th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 6th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 7th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 8th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • 9th Street
    W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Abbazia di San Faustino
    An abbey located in Massa Martana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; John Muccigrosso
    Contributors:
  • Abbazia di Santa Maria di Falleri
    The Medieval Cistercian abbey church of Santa Maria di Falleri occupies a portion of what was initially the walled area of the ancient town of Falerii, established in 241 BCE. The abbey's name, along with that of the associated hamlet, preserves the ancient toponymy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Abd al Kuri (island)
    Abd al Kuri is an island located about 65 miles southwest of Socotra in the Indian Ocean and is part of the Socotra Archipelago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Abini nuragic sanctuary
    A nuragic sanctuary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Abu Bakr cemetery
    Burial area in the northwestern portion of the Giza Necropolis containing burials dated to the Fourth-Fifth Dynasties.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Abū Dhuba‘
    Minor site from which inscribed bricks have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Abū Jāmūs
    Ruin of unknown type where cuneiform tablets are said to have been discovered in modern Iraq.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Abul
    A Phoenician and Roman trade and production center with evidence for storage and production.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Abusir Pharos tomb
    A tomb that seems to imitate the famous lighthouse of Alexandria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Elizabeth Robinson
  • Abū Ṭbīrah
    Medium-sized Sumerian city close to modern Al-Nasiriyya.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Acbatana
    A now unlocated settlement that Pliny the Elder places on Mt. Carmel.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Achilleion
    Middle Neolithic settlement on the southeastern edge of the Thessalian Plain of Karditsa, 5 km southeast of Farsala.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Achutrajpur
    Ancient settlement and center of Buddhism near modern Banpur with remains from the 7th-12th centuries. Demolished in modern times.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ackling Dyke
    A segment of a Roman road running from Old Sarum (Sorviodunum) to the hill fort at Badbury Rings (Vindocladia).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Acquoria
    A basis villae near Tivoli in opus incertum on the river Aniene measuring 70 x 20 m. Two phases have been identified: second-first century B.C. and first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Acropolis of Aletrium
    The Acropolis of Aletrium, often referred to as the "Civita", is the fortified citadel of the ancient city. Surrounded by polygonal walls, it is accessed via two gates.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Acropolis of Halos
    The Hellenistic acropolis of Halos lies just beneath the summit of the hill and its later Byzantine successor, according to Reinders (1988, 58).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Robin Iversen Rönnlund
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Acropolis palace at Jebel Khalid
    Hellenistic palace at the city of Jebel Khalid on the west bank of the Euphrates.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Adad Gate
    The Adad Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Adad-mukīn-ḫegallīya ("The God Adad Is the One Who Establishes My Prosperity"), is the second of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the eastward-facing entrances to the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Adad Gate
    The Adad Gate is one of Babylon's eight city gates and it is situated on the western side of the inner city, directly west of the nu-x-ù quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Adad-Šala temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Adad and the goddess Šala. Although its location is not known, the Adad-Šala temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Adad temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the god Adad.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ad Duodecimum
    A station (statio) located in the territory of the Batavians between Grinnes and Noviomagus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ad Fines
    Modern Ingrannes in north-central France.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Adilcevaz
    Medieval castle of the town Adilcevaz on the shore of Lake Van where Urartian inscriptions have been found. Not to be confused with Kef Kalesi which is located further north and outside of Adilcevaz.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Aedes Ceres Liber Liberaque
    The Temple of Ceres on the slope of the Aventine Hill in Rome was originally dedicated by Sp. Cassius in 493 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aedes Fauni
    A temple dedicated to Faunus located on Tiber Island, the Aedes Fauni was dedicated in 196 BCE by Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus and Gaius Scribonius Libo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aedes Herculis Pompeiani
    A temple of Hercules located near the Circus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aedes Tensarum
    A temple on Rome's Capitoline Hill where the carts that carried the exuviae in festival parades were stored.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Afrin bridge
    An ancient bridge on the Afrin river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ager Albanus
    A famously fertile territory of central Italy that originally was a part of Alba Longa. This region lay between the lacus Albanus, Bovillae, and Aricia. The Roman Via Appia passed through it.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ager Faliscus (region)
    The territory of the Faliscans that lay between areas where Etruscan, Latin, and Sabellic languages were spoken. The geographic limits of this territory on the right bank of the Tiber River stretch from Grotta Porciosa in the north to Capena in the south.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ager Laurens
    A region south of Rome along the Tyrrhenian coast between Ostia and Lavinium that is noted for its numerous rural villas and its connection to otium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ager Lunensis Survey area
    An archaeological survey in the territory of Luni that tracked settlement patterns between ca. A.D. 300 and A.D. 1200.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • ager Mutycensis
    The territory of Motyca in the Roman province of Sicilia that, according to Cicero, supported 187 farmers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ager Veientanus
    The territory of the Etruscan, and later Roman, city of Veii in South Etruria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Agia Paraskevi
    A barren, uninhabited island in the Nikasiai islands (Naxos).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Agios Andreas
    A Mycenaean citadel on Sifnos with continued use in the Iron Age.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Agios Nikolaos (island)
    An island that is part of the Nikasiai islands (Naxos).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Agios Vasileios, Laconia
    At Agios Vasileios is the archaeological site of the only Mycenaean palace thus far discovered in Lakonia. It is located near the village of Xerokambi in Lakonia, Greece.
    Creators: Michael Karabogias
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Michael Karabogias
  • Agora of Dura-Europos
    A group of ashlar buildings at the city center, identified by excavators as civic buildings.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Agrab Tepe - Dalma II
    One of three tells (archaeological mounds) located near Dalma in northwestern Iran, the excavation of Agrab Tepe in 1961 yielded Neolithic remains. According to Muscarella (1973), the tell is sited southwest of Hasanlu in the Solduz Valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aiano-Torraccia di Chiusi Roman villa
    The Villa Romana di Aiano-Torraccia di Chiusi, located near San Gimignano, is notable for a tri-apsidal courtyard.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ain Dara temple
    The Ain Dara temple, an archaeological site located near the village of Ain Dara, in Afrin, Syria, was the location of an Iron Age Syro-Hittite temple. The structure was noted for the similarities it bore to Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem. The site was in use from ca. 1300 until 740 BCE. It finds comparison with the temples at Emar, Mumbaqa, and Ebla's Temple D. In January 2018 the ruins of the temple were substantially damaged by air strikes carried out by the Turkish Air Force during the Afrin offensive. The site also subsequently suffered further damage, wanton destruction, and looting.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ain Diwar
    A ruined Roman bridge near Ain Diwar, Syria, that once crossed the Tigris river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • 'Ain el-Sabil Church
    Late antique mud-brick church located at Ain el-Sabil in Egypt. The exact dating of the site is still unknown.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Akchakhan-Kala
    An archaeological site located in what is now modern Karakalpakstan, Uzbekistan, Akchakhan-Kala was an ancient fortress in Chorasmia initially built ca. the fourth century BCE and occupied until the second century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aktash Burial Ground
    Burial site on Lake Aktash on the Crimean peninsula made up of at least 12 mounds from the Scythian, Taurian, and Greek cultures.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Alahana Parivena
    A middle to late eleventh century CE monastic college located outside of Polonnaruwa in Sri Lanka that belonged to King Parakramabahu I.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alanya Castle
    Alanya Castle is a thirteenth century fortification built on the site of Korakesion.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alatzomouri Pefka
    A large-scale Minoan dyemaking and dying establishment overlooking the modern Bay of Mirobello at Pacheia Ammos in Lasithi, Crete.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alatzomouri Rock Shelter
    Α small Μinoan rock shelter of uncertain function discovered alongside a highway on the modern Alatzomouri hill just west of Pacheia Ammos in Lisotho, east Crete. A significant assemblage of broken pottery and tools, all dating to EMIII, were found in the shelter.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Alaybeyi Höyük
    Settlement in eastern Anatolia containing signs of habitation from the Chalcolithic age (ca. 4700 BCE) to the Iron Age (ca. 400 BCE), including a large number of remains associated with the Kura-Araxes Culture.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • al-Bara
    al-Bara is one the so-called "Dead Cities" of northern Syria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Al-Bilād al-Qadīm
    A mosque or madrasa where a stone block with cuneiform inscription was found (and removed) in the 19th Century. The building itself no longer exists.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Alcalar megaliths
    A Calcolithic necropolis comprised of megalithic monuments located near Portimão, Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alcazaba de Villavieja
    A Roman amphitheater at Berja.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alepotrypa cave
    A cave located in the Gulf of Diros with evidence for Neolithic habitation and burial.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ale's Stones
    A megalithic monument in Sweden in the form of a ship, likely dating from ca. AD 600, the end of the Nordic Iron Age.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Aletrinates
    The inhabitants of Alētrium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alfar Romano de Cartuja
    The Alfar Romano de Cartuja (Roman potters' workshop of Cartuja) was a pottery production center for southern Spain that was active from the 1st century till the later 2nd century CE.
    Creators: David Rothfels; Julia Doelling
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Algund
    A bridge on the Via Claudia Augusta crossing the Adige river near Maiensis Statio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • al-Jazirah (region)
    The northern portion of the region between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers is known today as Upper Mesopotamia. The area, extending from the mountains of eastern Anatolia in the north to the Tharthar Depression (northwest of Baghdad) in the south, is an alluvial plain that formed an important crossroads region in the ancient and medieval periods. Major settlements of the region in the early Islamic period include Ar-Raqqah and Edessa.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Al-Khasbah
    One of the largest Early Bronze Age sites in Oman. This site, located in central Oman, has monumental buildings and tombs from the 4th-3rd millennium BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Al-Khawd
    Find-spot of a hoard of metal objects dated to the early Iron Age, located on the campus of Sultan Qaboos University in Oman.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Allahdino
    A settlement located some 40km outside of modern Karachi, Pakistan, dating to the Mature Harappan period. The site was abandoned by the close of the third millennium BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Almendres Cromlech
    A megalithic complex located near Guadalupe, Portgual, dating to the Early Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Almoguera
    The Spanish village of Almoguera is located in the southeast of the province of Córdoba, near Baena. It belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X in the thirteenth century.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Alta Semita
    The Alta Semita was an urban street running along the spine of the Quirinal Hill. The Alta Semita also lent its name to the sixth Augustan region of the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alto Chacón, Teruel
    An Ibero-Roman oppidum located just west of modern Teruel in Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Alto do Colaride
    A Roman necropolis located in a natural cave.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aludiri
    Urartian fortress of Aznavurtepe.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Alverdiscott
    A Roman marching camp identified via cropmarks.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alyscamps
    Alyscamps is a necropolis located outside the walls of Arles, France.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Alyzeia Fortifications
    Walls and towers surrounding the ancient city of Alyzeia in Acarnania. Significant reference was made to the plan in Murray 1982 (page 107, figure 107) in mapping these components; however, only those locations that are visible in more recent Google Earth imagery (especially that dating to April 2017 and May 2020) are included here.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Amaltheum
    An estate of T. Pomponius Atticus in Epirus, now unlocated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Amathus necropolis
    The necropolis of Amathus on Cyprus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ambresbury Banks
    Ambresbury Banks is an archaeological site in the Epping Forest of Essex, England. There are the remains of a 4.5 ha Iron Age hill fort, a site that is now forested.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Amiternum (Samnium)
    An ancient city in Samnium located between Interamna Lirenas and Atina perhaps corresponding to the modern comune of Sant'Elia Fiumerapido (FR).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • ‘Ammān al-Madanī civil airport
    Bronze age building located within the civil airport of Amman.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Amphissa Tholos
    A Mycenaean tholos tomb located southeast of Amphissa, Phokida.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Amphitheater at Castrum Rauracense
    Discovered in late 2021 on the site of the Basler Ruderclub in Augst, this amphitheater lies just west of the Roman fort of Castrum Rauracense. It seems to have been built in an abandoned quarry sometime in the 4th century CE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Sebastian Heath
  • Amphitheater Birten
    A Roman amphitheater located at Castra Vetera (modern Birten Germany)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Amphitheater of Anazarbos
    A Roman amphitheater located south and outside the city walls at Anazarbos (modern Dilekkaya in Turkey).
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Amphitheater of Dura-Europos
    Intramural amphitheater located within the military sector on the north side of Dura-Europos. Built on the site of the former Bath F3, which was destroyed by fire. The amphitheater's dedication in 216 CE is attested by an inscription found fallen from above entrance C on the south side of the amphitheater.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Amphitheater of Micia
    The Amphitheater of Micia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Amphitheatre of Thapsus
    A stone-built Amphitheatre at Thapsus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Anavarza Kalesi
    Anavarza Kalesi is a large fortress of Byzantine and Armenian date on probable Roman foundations. It shares its Turkish name with the 200m high limestone outcrop on which it stands. This outcrop served as the acropolis of ancient Anazarbos, and it also has been suggested as a location for the earlier "Kundu," which is mentioned in Akkadian sources.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Anavlochos
    An archaeological site in Crete, Anavlochos (Vrachasi, Lasithi), provides evidence of a settlement straddling the end of the Bronze Age and the Early Iron Age, carrying on to the Archaic period (ca 1200-650 BCE).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Anazarbos city wall
    The Anazarbos city wall visible today was built in the 10th century of the current era.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ancient harbour (submerged) at Aegina
    Archaeological remains of Aegina's military harbor.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Ancient Theater of Argos
    The Ancient Theater of Argos was a Hellenistic theater initially constructed in 320 BCE and later renovated by the Romans.
    Creators: Merrick Gormley; Nomi Solwren
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Ancient Theater of Chaeronea
    The theater at Chaeronea
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Andelos reservoir
    A reservoir that functioned as part of the water supply of Andelos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Andernos-les-Bains
    A Gallo-Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Anemospilia
    A Minoan temple (?) located on northern end of Mount Iuktas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Anfiteatro Fausto
    The "Anfiteatro Fausto" or "Amphitheater of Faustus" refers to a Roman amphitheater that was built during the reign of Tiberius (likely 30 or 32 CE) at Terni.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Anghelu Ruju necropolis
    A pre-nuragic necropolis discovered in 1903.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ani citadel
    The Ani citadel is a flat-topped hill that was once known as Midjnaberd (the Inner Fortress). Its defensive walls date to the seventh century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ani city wall
    Defensive walls attributed to King Smbat in the tenth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Antinoeion at Hadrian's Villa
    A sacred precinct at the western end of Villa Hadriani, comprising two temples at opposite (north and south) ends of a plaza or garden, and (on the western edge of this complex) a small colonnaded hemicycle. Here, Hadrian may have planned to build a large, semi-circular temple-tomb for Antinous, in place of which his successors built the colonnaded hemicycle.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Antipolis
    According to Pliny the Elder, Antipolis was a settlement opposite the site of Rome that later became the Ianiculum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • antrum Cyclopis
    A curious toponym that comes from the Regionary Catalogues for Regio I, the antrum (or atrium) Cyclopis is thought to have been a cave or grotto, perhaps in the flank of the Viminal Hill. It seems to lend its name to the vicus Cyclopis (CIL 6, 2226) that ran south and west to join the via Appia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Anu Gate
    The Anu Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Anu-mušallim-epšēt-qātīya ("The God Anu Is the One Who Makes My Undertakings Successful"), is the fifth of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the west-facing entrances to the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Apadana Palace
    A monumental hypostyle building at Persepolis dating to the sixth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Apollo-Grannus-Tempel
    A Roman temple in Faimingen near Lauingen in Bavaria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • A Ponte da Xira
    A Roman bridge in the northwestern Iberian peninsula that crosses the río Valiñas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aqua Crabra
    An aqueduct supplying villas in the area of the city of Tusculum, mentioned by both Cicero and Frontinus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aquae Labanae
    Cold, sulfur springs located near Nomentum, according to Strabo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aquae Rusellanae
    A thermal site located near Roman Rusellae in regular use and reuse since at least Roman times. Its ancient name is not known. The first modern excavations and mapping efforts date to the 18th century of the modern era.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Aquas volaternas
    A place named on the Peutinger map, possibly to be associated with modern Monte Cerboli, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Aqueduct of the Arcioni, Rocca di Papa
    The remaining segment of a Roman aqueduct in the valley of the Arcioni stream, comune of Rocca di Papa (Italy).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aqueduct of the Gier
    A Roman aqueduct of the first century AD supplying Lugdunum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aquis Querquennis
    A first century A.D. Roman encampment along the Via Nova.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ara del Tufo necropolis
    An Etruscan necropolis at Tuscania.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ara Pacis Augustae
    The "Altar of Augustan Peace" was located in the Campus Martius of Rome. It was originally situated to the west of the Via Lata, near the eastern end of Augustus' Horologium. The reconstructed fragments of the altar are now housed in a museum located on the Tiber's banks in the Piazza Augusto Imperatore, a square created during the Fascist era in order to spotlight the ruins of the Mausoleum of Augustus.
    Creators: Echo Smith; Edward Keogh; Sara Hales
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Arapsu Bridge
    A Roman bridge near Antalya, Turkey.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Ararus (river)
    A river of Scythia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Aras
    Site for Urartian rock inscription (also known as "Delibaba inscription").
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Archaic tholos tomb at Pharsalos
    Center point of Archaic period tholos tomb of Pharsalos, used until the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Dan Diffendale; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arch at F Street and 10th Street
    Monumentalized passage arch marking the intersection of F Street and the south side of 10th Street in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Arch of Augustus at Ariminum
    The Arch of Augustus at Ariminum was dedicated in 27 B.C. and marked the end of the Via Flaminia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arch of Caracalla
    The Arch of Caracalla at Volubilis was constructed in 217 CE by the governor Marcus Aurelius Sebastenus in honor of the emperor Caracalla and his mother Domna Julia.
    Creators: Alisa MacDonald; Anna Wilson
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Arch of Caracalla
    The so-called Arch of Caracalla at Theveste is a tetrapylon arch dating to the third century. Originally dedicated to the deified Septimius Severus with Julia Domna and Caracalla, the arch was repurposed and modified to function as a gate in the Byzantine city wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Arch of Diocletian
    The Arch of Diocletian dates to the late third century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arch of Trajan at Canosa
    The Arch of Trajan at Canosa dates to the second century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arco di Sant'Ercolano
    The Arco di Sant'Ercolano of Perugia is the ancient Porta Cornea of the Hellenistic walls of the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arco Etrusco
    The so-called "Arco Etrusco" is one of the gates of ancient Perusia. The gate dates originally from the third century B.C. when it was one of seven gates in the Etruscan wall. In 40 B.C. it was refashioned under Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arcus Divi Veri
    An arch, likely on the Via Appia, that is known only from the Regionary Catalogues. It may have honored the Parthian victories of Lucius Verus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arcus Novus
    A now-lost arch on the ancient Via Lata. It was dedicated to Diocletian either in 293 CE (marking the occasion of his decennalia) or in 303-304 (joint triumph with Maximian). The present church of Santa Maria in Via Lata occupies the site of the arch.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Area A at Pseira
    Bronze Age settlement associated with the Minoan culture located on the Katsouni Peninsula, a thin peninsula on the southeastern corner of the island of Pseira.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • area Apollonis et Splenis et Calles
    A trio of toponyms included in the Regionary Catalogues for Regio I. The area Apollonis is otherwise unknown. Topographers debate the trustworthiness of the second and third toponyms.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Area Carruces
    Mentioned only in the Regionary Catalogues, the Area Carruces was perhaps a square where travelers were accustomed to leaving their carriages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Area di Monte Giulio e Capitaneria
    The low hill known as Monte Giulio is anthropic, formed by the accumulation of sediment atop an ancient quay. Archaeological investigation beginning in 1968 revealed numerous architectural remains, including a cistern and a bath complex along the via Guidoni. The ruins of the so-called Capitaneria, or Harbor office, are located near the modern stele to the Fallen of Kindu. This complex seems to have been connected to the management of port traffic and was in use from the reign of Claudius until the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • area pannaria
    A place mentioned only in the Regionary Catalogues for Regio I. It is of indeterminate nature and location. It is one of a number of open areas attested for this region of the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arene Candide
    A cave in Liguria with Palaeolithic, Neolithic and temporary Late Roman occupation
    Creators: Stefano Costa
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Argaka Slag Heap
    A copper-smelting slag heap located in the village of Argaka in western Cyprus (Paphos district), dating between the third and eighth centuries CE and likely derived from ore mined at Limni.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Argiletum
    The Argiletum was a street of ancient Rome that passed from the Forum Romanum and crossed the Suburra. Its route more or less followed that of the modern streets Via Leonina and Via della Madonna dei Monti.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Argive Plain
    Adjacent to the Argolic Gulf and roughly centered on the ancient city of Argos, this alluvial plain covers some 250 square kilometers and is considered one of two major components of the ancient Argolis/Argolid region.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Arienzo
    A villa of the second century AD that was destroyed by a flood in the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Arinçkus
    Find place for a Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Arminna East
    Archaeological site on the Nile River.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Arpaia milestone
    A Roman milestone of the Via Appia located in Arpaia, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Arras-sur-Rhône Roman Milestone
    A Roman milestone located in the modern French commune of Arras-sur-Rhône, registered as a historical monument in 1926 when it was to be found in the cemetery of the church of Saint Clair.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Arteda Civitate
    An early medieval settlement in Spain (9th to 13th centuries CE) listed in contemporary Latin documents. This settlement is now identified with a second phase of occupation of an archaeological site known as El Forau de la Tuta near modern Arieda in Zaragosa province where a previously unknown Roman settlement has also been discovered. In addition to archaeological finds in situ, spolia from both the Roman and medieval phases have been identified in the more recent Ermita de San Pedro.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Artemis Laphria Sanctuary (Kalydon)
    This sanctuary is believed to have been active since at least the Geometric period, possibly on the site of a Mycenaean settlement. Ceramic evidence indicates continuous activity at least through the Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Artulu
    A city in Tabal mentioned in royal inscriptions of the Assyrian king Shalmaneser III (r. 858-824 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Aruch
    Findspot for Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Aşağı Anzaf
    Fortress close to the Urartian capital Tushpa.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Aşağı Yarımca
    Mound close to Harran where an inscribed stele has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ascoli Satriano Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge crossing the Carapelle stream in the territory of Ascoli Satriano.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Asklepieion and Lerna
    A sanctuary complex on the northern margins of ancient Corinth near the theater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott; Zachary Rosalinsky
  • Askut
    Ancient Egyptian island fortress on the Nile in the Middle Kingdom, now submerged.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Assembly Hall from Synagogue at Dura-Europos
    Assembly Hall with Torah Shrine located on the west side of the Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Assur Archive 15 (N 1)
    In the southwest courtyard and nearby rooms of the Aššur temple, researchers found a library and an archive consisting of at least 301 clay tablets, mostly fragmentary, and possibly several hundred more. These tablets were concentrated in the northwest part of the courtyard, the northwest rooms and the Enpi gate, and some stone tablets and other inscribed objects were also found in this area. Tablets found in other parts of the Aššur temple complex also belong to Assur Archive 15. This includes at least 72 clay tablets, often fragmentary, as well as fragmentary clay prisms and cylinders. These tablets were mostly found in the southern part of the large forecourt, as well as west of the temple complex. The texts included in the library date from the Old Assyrian to the Neo Assyrian period, with a core of Middle Assyrian texts and contained cultic and hymnic texts, myths, omens, incantations, prescriptions, lexical lists, as well as hemerological, mathematical, astronomical and astrological texts. The dating of the archive is similar; it contained lists, decrees, letters and historical texts.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
  • Aššur-mušalbir-palê-šarri-ēpišīšu-nāṣir-ummānīšu
    The Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) surrounded his new capital Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") with a rectangular-shaped, 16,280-cubit-long inner and outer city wall. The name of the city wall (dūru) was Aššur-mušalbir-palê-šarri-ēpišīšu-nāṣir-ummānīšu ("The God Aššur Is the One Who Prolongs the Reign of Its Royal Builder (and) Protects His Troops") according to some Akkadian royal inscriptions, but Aššur-mulabbir-palê-šarri-ēpišīšu-nāṣir-perʾīšu ("The God Aššur Is the One Who Prolongs the Reign of Its Royal Builder (and) Protects His Offspring") according to other texts written in the name of Sargon II.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • A Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Atlit Yam
    Atlit Yam is the site of an ancient submerged Neolithic village off the coast of Atlit, Israel, occupied during the final Pre-Pottery Neolithic B period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Atrium Vestae
    The Atrium Vestae or House of the Vestals refers to an architectural complex on the northwest slope of the Palatine Hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Attacotti
    The name Attacotti refers to a people who despoiled Roman Britain between AD 364 and 368 along with other groups.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • *Atuna
    *Atuna is the capital of the kingdom *Atuna in Tabal.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • *Atuna (kingdom)
    A kingdom in Tabal mentioned in royal inscriptions of the Assyrian kings Tiglath-pileser III (r. 744-727 BC) and Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Audleystown Court Cairn
    A dual court grave near the south shore of Strangford Lough in County Down, Northern Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Auf Schiffels
    A Roman road station.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Augusta Bagiennorum amphitheater
    The Roman amphitheater of Augusta Bagiennorum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Auld Bourtreebush
    Auld Bourtreebush is a prehistoric stone circle in Aberdeenshire, Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Avezzano Roman villa
    A large Roman villa near Alba Fucens that originates in the second century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Avitta Bibba amphitheater
    A Roman amphitheater located in the modern Siliana Governorate of Tunisia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • 'Awām
    The ruins of the Sabaean temple dedicated to Almaqah and its associated burial ground are located near the town of Mārib, Yemen.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Awlad Azzaz Site
    Late 18th Dynasty tomb site near the towns of Nag ed Deir and Awlad Azzaz in Egypt.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ayanis
    Ayanis (or Ayanıs, now Ağartı Kalesi) is an Urartean fortress and settlement located 35 km north of Van on a rocky outcrop 250 m above Lake Van (1867 m above sea level). It was founded in the 7th century BCE under Rusa, son of Argišti, and was named Rusahinili Eidurukai ("The City of Rusa in front of Mount Eiduru"). Here two inscriptions of Rusa, son of Argišti (7th century BCE), have been found which report that Rusa cultivated the barren land, built the fortress and the city as well as a “tower temple” (“susi temple”) and a “Gate for the God Haldi” (A 12-01 and A 12-09).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Gabriel Mckee; Noah Kaye; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
  • Ayaz-Kala
    An archaeological site in Northern Uzbekistan, dating between the fourth century BCE and the seventh century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ayio Gala
    Site in the northwestern corner of the island of Chios consisting of a two caves, both containing pottery and other remains dated to the Neolithic period. The entrance to the upper cave is located inside the Panayia Galactonosera chapel.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Azor Cemetery Site
    Bronze and Iron Age settlement located in modern Azor and Holon in Israel. Archaeological excavations thus far have largely turned up funerary remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Baba Hatim Ziyarat
    The mausoleum of Baba Hatim dates to the eleventh and twelfth centuries. It is located near Imam Sahib, in Kunduz Province, Afghanistan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bāb-Lugalerra
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Bāb-Lugalerra was one of the four city districts of the western half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained three temples.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Bacino Termale Euganeo
    A key element of a well-known area of thermal spas and springs already in use in Roman antiquity, located in modern Italy's Veneto region.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bağin
    Village where fragments of a Urartian stele have been found (one in a church, one in a fortress).
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Bahçecik
    Urartian site containing a ruined building and some rock inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Bakr Āwā
    Large mound with citadel in the plain of Shahrizor, occupied from Early Bronze Age to modern time.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Karen Rubinson; Tom Elliott
  • Balineum Ampelidis et Dianes
    A bath complex that is included in Regio XIV and also possibly represented on the Severan Marble plan. In the Notitia, referred to as "Balineum Ampelidis, Prisci et Dianes" and as Balineum Ampelidis et Dianes in the Curiosum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • balneum Abascantis et Mamertini
    The balneum Abascanti were baths near the Porta Capena that were possibly built by T. Flavius Abascantus, the freedman of Domitian. Also near the Porta Capena were the balneum Mamertini, possibly dedicated by Sex. Petronius Mamertinus, praetorian prefect in 139-143 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • balneum Torquati
    A bath located in the vicinity of the Porta Capena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Balsignano
    A fortified Medieval site located in Puglia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bambakajat
    Find spot for inscribed Urartian rock artefacts.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Banāt al-Hassan
    A multi-period group of mounds in central Mesopotamia (modern Al-Warka District of Iraq), by which passes the modern Basra-Baghdad highway (national highway 1). The site lies about 15 kilometers to the north of the modern town of Al-Warka and about 25 kilometers north-northwest of the ancient site of Uruk. It is not to be confused with Banat al-Hassan in Anbar province, northwest of Baghdad.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Band-e Kaisar
    A third century AD Roman bridge located near Shushtar, Iran.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bani Walid
    A modern city in Libya's Misratah province on the western edge of which Roman milestones and funerary inscriptions have been found removed from their original positions as part of modern agricultural activity. The local museum holds artistic and architectural artifacts from a number of nearby locations.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Baou des Blancs
    A rocky promontory that overlooks the modern town of Vence in the Alpes Maritimes department of France. Iron Age, Late Antique, and Medieval occupation and fortifications are attested there.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Baptistery of Butrint
    The Baptistery of Butrint is a round structure, with a diameter of 14.5 meters. It was built in the sixth century A.D. and was excavated in May 1928 by Luigi Maria Ugolini.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Barbar Temples
    Archaeological site in northern Bahrain associated with the Dilmun culture. Three successive temples were built on the site during the 3rd-2nd millennia BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Barburgh Mill Roman fortlet
    A Roman fortlet lying on a small hill near the line of a Roman road (R77). Excavated in the 1970s, the site has now been largely destroyed by a gravel quarry.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Barcola
    A no-longer-visible villa maritima was identified north of Tergeste in 1887. According to AdriAtlas, a reanalysis by Fontana (1993) places the beginnings of the villa's occupational sequence in the third quarter of the first century BCE.
    Creators: Francis Tassaux
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Bar Hill Fort Bathhouse
    The Bar Hill Fort Bathhouse was built around 140 CE, at the same time as the Antonine wall, and is a long and narrow stone structure with latrines and two heated rooms.
    Creators: Daphne Daniel; Rose Gatlin
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Barnako
    A Byzantine and Ottoman fortification northeast of (and overlooking) the Azyleia/Mytika plain in Acarnania, Greece. Some commentators have supposed an earlier antecedent on the site.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Barracks of K5
    Military barracks reworked from private houses in Block K5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Barreira Megalithic Complex
    A prehistoric megalithic complex in the modern Sintra municipality in Portugal's Lisbon district. It was formally identified in 1961 and designated as a cultural heritage site in 1993. The complex consists of at least 24 standing stones.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Barsova Gora
    Archaeological site on the Ob River in Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug, Russia containing remains dated to the 6th-4th centuries BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Başbük
    This modern village in Turkey's Şanlıurfa province is the site of a subterranean complex discovered in 2017 and only partially excavated. The excavated portion of the complex can be dated to the Neo-ssyrian period, thanks to the presence of an unfinished, rock wall panel depicting a divine procession with some divine figures labeled in Aramaic.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Christopher W. Jones; Thomas Mertens
  • Başbulak
    Find spot for a stone with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Basilica Aemilia
    A basilica located at the juncture of the Sacra Via and the Argiletum flanking the Forum Romanum that was initially built in 179 B.C.E.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Basilica and convent of S. Ippolito
    An important paleochristian complex located in the area of Portus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica Benedettina di S. Michele Arcangelo
    An abbey church located in Capua on the western slopes of Monte Tifata.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica Constantini
    The Basilica Constantini, also referred to as Basilica Nova ("New Basilica"), Basilica of Maxentius or Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine, is a colossal fourth-century basilica located along the Sacra Via in Rome. It is considered the largest ancient structure in the valley of the Forum Romanum and is typically deemed the final Roman civic basilica built in the ancient city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Basilica Damous el-Karita
    A Christian basilica of the Byzantine period located in Carthage.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Basilica di Santa Sinforosa
    A minor Paleochristian basilica located in Guidonia Montecelio that was dedicated to the patron saint of Tivoli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica di Santo Stefano in via Latina
    The now-ruined basilica of Santo Stefano in Via Latina was a fifth-century CE early Christian basilica. It is now located within the confines of the archaeological park of the Via Latina tombs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica Neptuni
    A building in the Campus Martius that originally dates to ca. 25 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere
    The Basilica di Santa Maria in Trastevere is a titular minor basilica located in the Trastevere district of Rome, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica of St. Crispinus
    The fourth century Basilica of St. Crispinus is one of the largest known in Africa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi
    A papal basilica begun ca. AD 1228.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Basilica of St. Titus
    A Christian basilica of the mid-sixth to seventh centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Basilica of the Sacred Heart (Paray-le-Monial)
    12th-century church in Paray-le-Monial, France. This site was a popular pilgrimage site and is an important example of Cluniac architecture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Basilica Ulpia
    The Basilica Ulpia is located in the Forum of Trajan at Rome and derives its name from the emperor Trajan's gentilician nomenclature. The basilica was considered a marvel of ancient Roman architecture by observers, including the historian Ammianus Marcellinus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Bath C3
    Bath building constructed by Roman soldiers in Block C3.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bath E3 Phase 1
    Bath building located in the intramuros military sector of Dura-Europos, replaced by Bath E3 Phase 2.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bath E3 Phase 2
    Bath building located in the intramuros military sector of Dura-Europos, replaces Bath E3 Phase 1.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bath F3
    Bath building originally occupying all of Block F3, located in the intramuros military sector of Dura-Europos. Excavations reveal that the bath likely had two phases of renovation (one perhaps after 165 CE, and another around c. 200 CE), before it was destroyed by fire. Dura-Europos' amphitheater was built over the remains of Bath F3, and thus the amphitheater's dedicatory inscription, dated to 216 CE, serves as a terminus ante quem for the bath building.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors:
  • Bath-Gymnasium Complex at Sardis
    Bath/gymnasium complex containing a palaestra and a synagogue that was developed in the 3rd century CE.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Bath M7
    Bath building constructed by Roman soldiers in Block M7.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Baths at Conimbriga
    The Roman baths at Conimbriga.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Baths of Pozzo Pantaleo
    A public bath (thermae) of the Roman Imperial period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Baysān
    Find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Beaumont-sur-Oise amphitheater
    The Beaumont-sur-Oise Gallo-Roman amphitheater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Becilla de Valderaduey Roman bridge
    A bridge that crosses the Valderaduey river and that has traditionally been considered to be of Roman origin, although it may in fact be more recent in date. The ruins are found in the municipality of Becilla de Valderaduey in the Province of Valladolid, of the autonomous community of Castilla y León, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Be'er Resisim
    Early-Middle Bronze Age settlement with 82 buildings on a hilltop in the Negev Desert.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Beirut Souks
    Area along the western harbor of Beirut developed during phases of urban expansion from the 4th century BCE through the 1st century CE. The area was inhabited into late antiquity, with limited use into the medieval period. Rescue excavations were conducted in the area prior to its commercial redevelopment in the 1990s and early 2000s.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Beit Farhi
    Ottoman period house located in Damascus' Old City built by the Sephardic Jewish Farhi family begun in 1780.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Beit She’arim
    Beit She'arim National Park is the site of a large number of ancient rock-cut Jewish tombs, dating to the second century AD. The necropolis was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2015.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Belas dam
    A third century AD Roman dam that served the city of Olisipo or perhaps a local Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bēlet-ilī Gate
    The Bēlet-ilī Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Bēlet-ilī-murappišat-talittīšu ("The Goddess Bēlet-ilī Is the One Who Increases Its (Animals’) Offspring"), is the eighth of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the south-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location remains unknown.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Beljaus
    Founded from Chersonesus in the late fourth century B.C., Beljaus was a fortified agricultural settlement located near the mouth of Lake Donuzlav.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Benalroma
    Roman villa at modern Benalmádena Costa on the Spanish Mediterranean coast, southwest of Malaga. The site is located on the north corner of the intersection of Avenida Antonio Machado and Avenida de las Palmeras. Most of the excavated portions of this large villa, which included a garden and water feature, are conserved or reburied under modern structures; however, a walled pit makes some portion of the extant remains visible to passerby.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Benalúa
    A late antique harbour site that is linked to the abandonment of the site of Lucentum.
    Creators: Javier Martínez Jiménez
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Beregrani
    An ancient people of Picenum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bergantino nymphaeum
    A nymphaeum on the shores of the Alban Lake that is located in a natural grotto that is assigned to the Flavian period and associated with the complex of the Villa of Domitian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bethania
    A village located near Jerusalem, at the Mount of Olives.
    Creators: Annette von Stockhausen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Bibey Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge across the Bibey river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Biblis
    A spring located in the territory of Miletus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bidoni
    A monumental sanctuary (26 x 20 m) dedicated to Iuppiter.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi fortress
    Thirteenth- and fourteenth-century fortress located in Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi in the Odessa region of southwestern Ukraine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Billingsgate Roman House and Baths
    A Roman balneum attached either to a Roman townhouse or mansio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bingerbrück
    A large Roman necropolis was discovered near Bingen. It included many military gravestones that dated from the first to fourth centuries A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bingöl Dağ (epigraphic findspot)
    Find spot for a Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bir Ftouha basilica
    An Early Christian pilgrimage complex and baptistry at Carthage.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bir Hima Rock Petroglyphs and Inscriptions
    Located in Saudi Arabia's Najran province, the Bir Hima Rock Petroglyphs and Inscriptions is part of the Ḥimā Cultural Area, a rock art site dating ca. 2500–1000 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Birket Habu
    An artificial lake created to bring water from the Nile to the Palace of Amenhotep III at Malkata in Egypt.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bīt-Purutaš (kingdom)
    A kingdom located in northern Tabal, in the vicinity of modern Kayseri. This area was briefly under Assyrian control during the reign of the eighth-century-BC king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Bizye Roman amphitheater
    A Roman amphitheater in eastern Thrace.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:

  • Bocca di Magra Roman villa
    A villa maritima of the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bokerley Dyke
    A Romano-British defensive dyke ca. 3.25 miles (5.2 km) long located in northeast Dorset.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bolʹshoĭ Petropavlovskiĭ burial ground
    Burial complex along a stretch of over 3 km of the northern bank of the Siniukha River, a stream in the Laba River valley (Krasnodar region). The necropolis contains over 200 individual burials dated to the Middle Bronze-Early Iron Ages (3rd millennium BCE-3rd century CE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Bordușani-Popină
    Tell in Eastern Romania with evidence of habitation in the Gumelnitean and La Tene periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bostankaya
    Village where a block with Urartian inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bothwellhaugh
    The remains of a Roman legionary fort located in North Lanarkshire near Glasgow, Scotland, that was built in connection with the Antonine Wall (ca. A.D. 142-165).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Boucheporn
    A significant center in eastern Gaul producing sigillate pottery.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bou Khenndak Copper Mines
    These mines, evidently actively worked in the 19th century and early 20th century but not in more recent times, are mentioned in AAA in passing (without any clear assertion of ancient evidence of exploitation) alongside discussion of some meager Roman remains at Merachiche, 3.5km to the northwest. They are conflated with the former in a single mine/quarry symbol in BAtlas.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Bouleuterion at Aspendos
    The Bouleuterion at Aspendos dates to the early second century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bouleuterion at Patara/Arsinoe
    The Bouleuterion at Patara/Arsinoe sits on the agora opposite the theater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bowes Moor
    A small, square Roman temporary camp along the main Roman road between York and Carlisle.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Böyük Kəsik
    Chalcolithic settlement in modern Azerbaijan. The settlement was oval shaped and was 1.2 hectares in area, but the top layers were destroyed and the lower layers are not visible due to ongoing agriculture on the site.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Bozca
    A modern village in the Avanos district of Turkey's Nevşehir province. Bozca is one of the proposed locations of ancient *Atuna.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Bozkurt
    Settlement inhabited from the middle-late Chalcolithic to the Urartian Kingdom in the middle Iron Age. The site is located on the southwest slope linking Mount Ağrı with the Doğubayazıt Plain in Eastern Turkey. Bozkurt comprises a complex of sites, including one mound, two cemeteries, two fortresses, and an outpost-road station.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Brampton Old Church
    The Brampton Old Church stands on the site of a Roman fort located 13 km northeast of Carlisle and 0.8 km south of the Stanegate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Brandon Camp
    An Iron Age hillfort that was re-used by the Roman army as a depot.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bratton Castle
    Bratton Castle is a bivallate Iron Age hillfort on Bratton Down on the western edge of the Salisbury Plain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bridge at Brugnato
    A Medieval bridge of Roman origins on the Vara river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Bridge at Eleonas
    Excavations of the metro train line exposed piers of an ancient bridge across the Kephissos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Brihadishwara Temple
    11th century Hndu temple Tanjuvar dedicated to Shiva with smaller shrines around it.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Brompton Roman fort
    A Roman auxiliary fort likely to have been built to support pre-Flavian campaigns in modern Wales.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Bronze Age Settlement at Knossos
    A bronze-age settlement associated with the so-called Palace of Minos south of modern Heraklion on the island of Crete.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • B Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • B Street Gate in Camp Wall
    Intramuros gate spanning B street at Dura-Europos and offering access into the military sector.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Buddhas of Bamyan
    Monumental statues of Gautam Buddha were carved into the cliff-face at Bamyan, located in the Bamyan valley in the Hazarajat region of central Afghanistan, The statues were, respectively, 35 and 53 m tall. They were intentionally destroyed by the Taliban in 2001.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Building (house?) at Dura-Europos preceding Synagogue phase 1
    Traces of preceding building of uncertain type (house?) detected below the synagogue levels in Block L7.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Building (house?) preceding Synagogue phase 1
    Traces of preceding building of uncertain type (house?) detected below the synagogue levels in Block L7.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Building (Temple?) West of The Principia Court (Rooms E7-20, E7-21, E7-22, E7-37, E7-38, E7-39, E7-40)
    Building located west of the principia in block E7 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Bukhara
    Bukhara began as part of the Persian empire in the sixth century B.C. The site is especially important as an example of an Islamic city of central Asia. The city center was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1993.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Büklükale
    Hittite city.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Bulutpınar
    Find place for a Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Buonconvento, Siena
    Numerous instances of ancient ceramic production have been documented in Buonconvento, Siena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Burgast
    Area in the Altai region of extreme western Mongolia containing a number of burials and other structures from the Bronze Age (Bulan-Kobin Culture), Turkic, and Medieval periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Burgus Solva 28
    A late Roman burgus (10,40 × 10,20 m) at Visegrád-Szentgyörgypuszta
    Creators: Holger R.E. Jürgenliemk
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Burgus Szentendre-Dera
    Burgus Szentendre-Dera is a late antique Roman military encampment located along the Hungarian Danube at Szentendre (St. Andrae). The fort secured the Pannonian Limes.
    Creators: Holger R.E. Jürgenliemk
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Burmageçit
    Find place for a bronze artifact with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Burmarina
    Minor settlement in Upper Syrian Euphrates.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Burmarina Archive 1
    The small town of Burmarina belonged to the area of the city Til-Barsip which was under Neo-Assyrian rule. An archive, consisting of about 130 clay tablets and fragments, including some bullae, was discovered in two rooms, presumably part of a private house, in Area F. Although most texts were written in Assyrian, some were in Aramaic, and some had short Aramaic notes written in ink. While most of the Assyrian texts were loan or purchase documents, the archive also includes short notes and a list. The Aramaic texts concern loans or are short notes written on bullae.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Burnswark Hill
    Burnswark Hill (287 m above sea level) is located near Ecclefechan in E. Dumfriesshire, Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Burnswark Hill Iron Age Hillfort
    An Iron Age Hillfort in Scotland
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Burnswark Hill Roman Camp
    One of two Roman siege camps at Burnswark Hill that flank the Iron Age hillfort. The camps are linked to the campaigns of the Roman commander Quintus Lollius Urbicus ca. 140 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Burnt Palace at Kalhu
    The Burnt Palace, which was destroyed by fire when Kalhu fell to anti-Assyrian Babylonian and Median forces in 612 BC, has the longest building sequence yet identified at Nimrud (biblical Calah). This royal residence, which was constructed in the southeast quarter of the citadel, had at least nine phases of occupation between the Middle Assyrian and Hellenistic Periods. The so-called Burnt Palace was rebuilt/renovated three times during the ninth to seventh centuries BC and it might have temporarily served as a royal residence during the reign of Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC), while that Assyrian king was building his new capital Dūr-Šarrukīn. An immense collection of burnt ivories (the ‘Loftus ivories’) was discovered in and near the throne room in 1954–55; these are now in the British Museum (London).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Bussock Camp
    At Bussock Camp in Berkshire, England, are the remains of a bivallate Iron Age hillfort covering ca. 4.4 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Buston VI Necropolis
    Necropolis in Southern Uzbekistan with late Bronze Age remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Buttercrambe Moor Roman camp
    A Roman temporary camp first identified by means of cropmarks in July 1995. The camp was located on the high ground to the north of the River Derwent.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Bwrdd Arthur
    Bwrdd Arthur is the site of an Iron Age hill fort atop a limestone hill in Anglesey, Wales.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Byzantine fort at Halos
    The later Byzantine fort at Halos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Robin Iversen Rönnlund
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Byzantine fortress at Thignica
    A Byzantine fortress located at the site of Thignica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Byzantine fortress at Timgad
    A sixth century A.D. Byzantine fortress built at Timgad by the governor Solomon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Byzantine house
    A Byzantine house located at Scylletium/Scolacium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Byzantine necropolis
    A necropolis of Scolacium dating to the fifth through seventh centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cadbury Camp Hill Fort
    A 2.8 ha hill fort near Tickenham, Somerset, England, in use from the Bronze Age to the Anglo Saxon period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cadbury Hill hill fort
    Cadbury Hill, near Congresbury, North Somerset, is the site of an Iron Age hill fort. On account of other hill forts with the "Cadbury" appellation, this particular fort is sometimes referred to as Cadbury-Congresbury.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caecandrus (island)
    A desert island in the Persian Gulf, as described by Pliny the Elder. Its location can no longer be determined.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caereni
    A people of northern Britain described by Ptolemy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caesar's Camp, Bracknell Forest
    An Iron Age hill fort located in Berkshire, along the line of the Roman road connecting Londinium and Calleva Atrebatum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cahercommaun
    A triple stone ringfort built ca. AD 800.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cajarc
    A Gallo-Roman pottery workshop producing terra sigillata in the Flavian period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caldone (promontory)
    A promontory placed by Pliny on the Arabian side of the Persian Gulf, near its northern limits. Its precise location cannot be determined today.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Caldoval
    A Roman settlement with public baths that was occupied from the later republican period until the fifth or sixth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caledonii
    A people located in what is now eastern Scotland (Caledonia) prior to and during the Roman period.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; A.S. Esmonde Cleary; R. Talbert; R. Warner
  • Callow Hill Roman villa
    A Roman villa measuring approximately 138 by 216 m dating to the last quarter of the first century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Calstock Roman fort
    A Roman fort located in Cornwall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Camenae, Camenarum Fons
    A toponym that appears in the Regionary Catalogues of the fourth century CE. The same toponym describes a vicus in the inscription of the vicomagistri base (CIL VI, 975 = ILS 6073). Based on Juvenal (3.10-20) it is hypothesized that this place was located just outside the Porta Capena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Camp du Château
    A large oppidum active in the Late Bronze and early Iron Ages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Campochiaro
    An Italic sanctuary sacred to Hercules located in località Civitella in the comune of Campochiaro. The site is to be connected with the Pentrian Samnites.
    Creators: N. Purcell
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
  • Campus Agrippae
    "Campus Agrippae" describes an area within regio VII of ancient Rome that is connected to the building activities of Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa in the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Campus Caledianus
    A region near Beneventum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Campus Lanatarius
    An area of Rome that is mentioned only in the Regionary Catalogue for Regio XII. This area likely was located between the Baths of Caracalla and the present location of the church of S. Saba.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Campus Viminalis
    An open area on the Esquiline Hill that is mentioned in the Regionary Catalogues for Regio V. It was likely a narrow area that lay outside the so-called Servian Wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Camp Wall
    Partial Southern boundary wall designating the Roman military camp area in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Can Blai
    A Late Roman fortlet on the island of Formentera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cancellone necropolis
    Rock-cut tombs located along the remains of a road dating as early as the sixth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Can Cortada Roman villa
    A Roman villa located in the vicinity of the Can Cortada farmhouse in the Horta-Guinardó district of Barcelona that was discovered in July 1987. It was dated to the second century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Canicella necropolis
    An Etruscan necropolis located to the south of the city of Orvieto with tombs ranging in date from the eighth to the third centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cannatello
    An archaeological site located in the territory of the eponymous frazione of the Italian municipality of Agrigento, Sicily. A middle and late Bronze Age fortified settlement dating to the fourteenth to thirteenth / twelfth centuries BCE has been discovered. Archaeologists deem it to be an important center of maritime trade. The site is located some seven kilometers southeast of the historic center of Agrigento and it sits on a flat hill located near the Naro River, about 1.5 kilometers from the coast.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Canon Frome
    A Roman auxiliary fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Canopus at Hadrian's Villa
    The Canopus garden is set at the principal entrance to Hadrian's Villa. An imposing waterway occupies all its length.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Capalbio
    Capalbio is a municipality in the Province of Grosseto. It is first attested in A.D. 805 when Charlemagne donated the locality to the Abbey of the Tre Fontane.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Capitolium of Sala
    Tetrastyle Corinthian temple located in the Roman forum at Sala (modern Chellah) dating from the early Hadrianic period (c.120 CE).
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Capitolium of Terracina
    A Tuscanic podium temple that is often referred to as being of the Capitolium type was built at Terracina in the middle of the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Capitolium of Verona
    Excavations have determined the location of the capitolium of Roman Verona, part of an extensive, terraced complex that underpins medieval and later structures of the city. The capitolium itself stretches from the northern end of the modern Piazza Erbe to the via Emilei, lying beneath the Palazzo Maffei, church of San Benedetto, Palazzo Malaspina and surrounding structures.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Capitolium Vetus
    The Capitolium Vetus was located on the Quirinal Hill and was an earlier shrine to the triad of Iuppiter, Juno, and Minerva than the famous Capitoline Temple. It was likely perched on the northern edge of the Quirinal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Capo di Bove
    An archaeological site located at the fourth milestone of the Via Appia Antica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cappadocia Gate at Kerkenes
    Gate on the southeastern side of the large fortified Iron Age site at Kerkenes (ancient Pteria).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cappella di Sant'Antonino (Finale Ligure)
    A twelfth-century chapel located near the Castrum Perticae. The site is located in the municipal territory of modern Finale Ligure in Italy's Ligurian Alps.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Caput Africae
    A place in Rome's second Augustan region that was perhaps a paedagogium for the training of imperial pages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Carpis (river)
    A river that flowed from the territory of the Ombricans to the Dravus. It's modern location is uncertain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Carrara
    The quarries at Carrara in northern Tuscany produced a range of white marbles that saw limited local use until being widely exploited and exported by the Romans from the first century B.C. onward.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Carrowkeel Megalithic Cemetery
    A Neolithic cemetery dated to 3400 to 3100 BC. Fourteen passage tombs have been identified.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Carrowmore Megalithic Cemetery
    A grouping of fourth-millennium BC Neolithic monuments located on the Cúil Irra peninsula near Sligo, Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa Bellezza
    The so-called "Casa Bellezza" is a Roman domus located on the flank of the Aventine Hill in Rome. Its remains are found at Largo Arrigo VII, no. 2-4.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa de la Fortuna
    A Roman domus at Cartagena, Spain, dating to the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa del Fabbro
    Casa del Fabbro or House of the Cabinet Maker is a domus located in Pompeii's Regio I. It derives its modern appellation from an extensive set of carpentry tools found in situ during excavation. The site was excavated in 1914, 1927, and 1933.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa della Biblioteca
    The House of the Library (VI, 17, 41)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa dell’ Amore punito
    A domus excavated in 1844 and 1867.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa della Regina Carolina
    A domus at Pompeii partially excavated in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa del Marinaio
    A domus at Pompeii, the so-called Casa del Marinaio or Casa di Niobe or Casa del Gallo is linked to VII .15.1 and VII .15.16 and was excavated ca.1859 and 1871.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa del Obispo
    The archaeological site of Casa del Obispo has evidence for multiple urban phases, ranging from the eighth century B.C. to the eighteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casa del Rilievo di Telefo
    The House of the Relief of Telephus or Casa del Rilievo di Telefo is one of the largest houses attested in the excavated area of Herculaneum (ca. 1,800 sq. m.). The house was excavated between 1934 and 1936.
    Creators: Tom Elliott; Yifan Li
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Wilhelmina Jashemski
  • Casale Bevilacqua
    A villa platform (basis villae) at Tusculum measuring ca. 180 by 90 meters. The terrace walls are dated to the early second century B.C.
