    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casale dell’Infernaccio
    A Roman villa located at Magliana Vecchia that dates to the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casale di Giovio
    The Casale di Giovio was originally a Roman funereal monument that was re-worked in seventeenth century to assume its current form.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casale Sinibalda
    The Casale Sinibalda is located on the western side of the Fosso Saina. Located to the north of the casale are the remains of a basis villae of the so-called fourth style, meaning it verges on opus quadratum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casetta Etruscan necropolis
    The Necropolis della Casetta at Blera contains numerous dado-type tombs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caspingium
    A Roman settlement, now unlocated, of Germania Inferior. The Tabula Peutingeriana places it along the military road connecting Noviomagus and Lugdunum Batavorum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Casteddu di Ceccia
    A stone-built monument of the Torrean civilization located south of Porto-Vecchio, Corsica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castel del Monte
    A 13th-century castle near Andria in the Apulia region of southeastern Italy built during the 1240s by the Emperor Frederick II. The castle was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1996.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castel Fiorentino
    The castle was the site of the Holy Emperor Frederick II's death in 1250.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castelfusano Paleochristian basilica
    Situated along the via Severiana are the remains of an anonymous Paleochristian basilica that was in use between the second and the seventh centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Castellazzo di Taneto
    A Medieval fort dating from the mid-ninth to the eleventh century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castell Bryn Gwyn
    Castell Bryn Gwyn is a circular Neolithic enclosure some 54 m in diameter that shows signs of re-use during the Iron Age and in the Roman period. The site is located on the Isle of Anglesey.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castelliere di Monte Acuto
    A multi-period site on Monte Acuto with evidence for habitation (Late Bronze Age) and cult activities (mid-first millennium BCE).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castellina del Marangone
    A small fortified coastal settlement in Etruria occupied from the tenth century B.C. to the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castello di Attimis
    A twelfth-century castle
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castello di Monte Sant'Angelo
    The castle of Monte Sant'Angelo was built in 837 by the Doge of Venice Orso I. It is located in the comune of Monte Sant'Angelo in Apulia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castello di Poira
    A now-ruined castle with Medieval origins occupying the same range of hilltops as ancient Poira.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castello Piccolomini
    A castle of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries located in Celano, the Province of L'Aquila (Abruzzo), Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castello Savelli Torlonia
    A castle at Palombara Sabina that originates in the eleventh century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castell Ruf
    A Pre-Roman oppidum located near Santa Maria de Martorelles, which lies to the northeast of modern Barcelona.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castellu di Cucuruzzu
    Castellu di Cucuruzzu is a Torrean archaeological site in Corsica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Castel Malnome (Ponte Galeria)
    An imperial necropolis with at least 326 tombs was identified at modern Castel Malnome (Ponte Galeria) in Italy. Archaeological evidence marks these as burials belonging to working-class people of the Roman imperial period, with most graves having either no grave goods or very few. The osteoarchaeological analysis led excavators to speculate that the individuals buried here many have worked in the salt flats.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castelvecchio di San Gimignano
    The site of Castelvecchio di San Gimignano likely had sacred significance in the first millennium BCE. The area was occupied in the late sixth to early seventh centuries CE as it provided a location to control movement between southern Tuscany and Piedmont. The site was fortified in the twelfth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castiella
    A Spanish region located in the north of Spain that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as Castilla.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors:
  • Castillo de Montalbán
    The Castle of Montalban is a ruined castle located in San Martín de Montalbán, province of Toledo, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castillo de Ucero
    A Medieval castle (thirteenth to seventeenth centuries) located near Ucero in Spain's Soria province.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castle an Dinas
    Castle an Dinas is an Iron Age hillfort near St. Columb Major in Cornwall, United Kingdom, built during the third and second centuries BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castle Greg
    A well preserved Roman fortlet located midway between Castledykes and Cramond.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castle Hill
    Castle Hill is located about 350 m south-east of Round Hill and was the site of an Iron Age hill fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castle of Gradara
    A castle in the Marche built first in the eleventh century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castra Misenatium
    A barracks at Rome that accommodated sailors from the imperial fleet at Misenum who were seconded to Rome in order to operate the rigging of the velarium of the Flavian Amphitheater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castra Peregrina
    Located on the Caelian Hill, the Castra Peregrina housed Roman soldiers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro de Alvarelhos
    A multi-period fortified site with occupation stretching from the Bronze Age to the Middle Ages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro de Coaña
    A Pre-Roman oppidum located in the modern Spanish province of Asturias.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castro de Pragança
    Castro de Pragança, a multi-period, fortified Iberian settlement located in modern Portugal's Cadaval municipality, Lisbon administrative district.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castro de San Cibrao de Las
    An oppidum occupied from the second century BC until the second century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Castro de Santo Ovidio
    A pre-Roman castrum of Lusitania located in the Vizela river valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro de Troña
    An elliptical, terraced Iron Age settlement of the Castro culture located in Pias, near Mondariz, Spain. The sites is located at an altitude of 280 meters above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro de Zoñán
    A settlement dating to the second through fourth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro do Monte Padrão
    The remains of a multi-period fortified settlement located in modern Portugal's Porto district, that dates initially from the ninth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castromaior
    An Iron Age oppidum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro of Zambujal
    A Chalcolithic settlement located in Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castro Romariz
    A fortified Iberian settlement in modern Portugal's Santa Maria da Feira municipality.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Castrum Caetani
    A Medieval fortification that incorporates and repurposes the Roman mausoleum of Caecilia Metella.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Castrum Perticae
    A fortified site of the later Byzantine period located at Finale Ligure.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catacomb of San Zotico
    A Christian catacomb located at the tenth mile of the ancient Via Labicana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catacomb of SS. Paul and Agatha
    An important paleochristian complex of Malta, dating from the fourth to the ninth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catacombs of Commodilla
    A catacomb along the Via Ostiensis that contains, among other wall paintings, the earliest depiction of a bearded Jesus Christ.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catacombs of Domitilla
    A Christian catacomb located on the via Ardeatina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Catacombs of Praetextatus
    A vast Roman catacomb along the Via Appia that began to be used at the close of the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catacombs of San Senatore
    A Christian catacomb located at the fifteenth mile of the Via Appia in use from the late third century A.D. until the Middle Ages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cataracta Sexta
    The Sixth Cataract is where the Nile cuts through the Sabaluka pluton.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Cati fons
    The Cati fons was a spring located on the western flank of Rome's Quirinal Hill. It was the source of the water carried by the brook known as Petronia amnis. The location of the spring remains debated and uncertain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Catribana Roman bridge
    A restored (2019) bridge located near Sintra, Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cattabania (region)
    A region of pre-Islamic, south-western Arabia centered in the Baihan valley. Strabo notes that this region produces frankincense.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cattedrale di Santa Maria di Amiternum
    The ruins of the cathedral of the fifth century are located in an area of the archaeological site of Amiternum that was occupied in the second and third centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caudini
    A Samnite tribe that was subjugated in 275 BC by L. Cornelius Lentulus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cave di Fosso del Drago
    A tuff quarry along the line of the via Tiberina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Caveirac milestone
    A Roman milestone - (CIL 17-02, no. 256).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Cave of Anigrid Nymphs
    A healing sanctuary connected with the river nymphs of the river Anigros. The cave is in proximity to the thermal springs of Lake Kaiafas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Cave of Eileithyia (Inatos)
    Sacred cave dedicated to the goddess of childbirth, Eileithyia, at Inatos, Crete. The site was in use from the Geometric period to the Roman period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Cave of Saint Peter
    A cave in the outskirts of Antioch that was converted into a church.
    Creators: Reid Richardson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Çelebibağı
    Find spot for a Urartian stela, a mosque in the village Çelebibağı.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Cellarulo
    An area in the Contrada Cellarulo of Benevento that is designated as an archaeological area with evidence for the later phases of ancient Benevento's history.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Central Building at Kalhu
    Near the middle of the citadel of Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud), the ninth-century-BC Assyrian king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) constructed a building with a grand, south-facing entrance. This building, constructed east of the southeast corner of the Northwest Palace, might have been one of the temples built by Ashurnasirpal II when he made Kalhu the administrative capital of the Assyrian Empire. Alternatively, the Central Building might have served as a palace.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Central Palace at Kalhu
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III (r. 744–727 BC) built himself a grand, ornately-decorated royal residence at Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud). This (large) palatial complex, which included a pillared-portico (a bīt-ḫilāni), was constructed south of the Northwest Palace (built by Ashurnasirpal II [r. 883–859 BC]). The “Cedar Palace” (as it is referred to in at least one contemporary Akkadian inscription) was largely dismantled by the seventh-century-BC ruler Esarhaddon (r. 680–669 BC), who had its (sculpted and inscribed) limestone slabs reused in his own royal residence (the Southwest Palace). The building is now generally referred to as the “Central Palace,” a modern designation given to it by its excavators since the palace was constructed in the central part of the Kalhu citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cercina (Etruria)
    A now-unlocated place near to Florentia in Etruria (Regio VII) known from epigraphic sources. Caius Caesar, the father of Iulius Caesar, helmed a veterans' colony there.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cerreto Sannita
    A Samnite temple dedicated to Flora.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chalandriani
    A major Early Bronze Age necropolis on Syros, Chalandriani contains tombs related to the Keros-Syros culture of the Early Cycladic II period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Chale Ghar 1
    Bronze Age copper mine reused as a sanctuary or ritual site from the 8th century BCE-8th century CE, located near the modern village of Veshnaveh, Iran.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Chamahzi Mumah
    Iron Age burial site located ni the Pusht-i Kuh region of Luristan.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Chancy
    The fortification located at Chancy dates initially to the reign of Valentinian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chapelle Sainte-Agathe
    The chapelle Sainte-Agathe was originally a Roman-period thermal complex that was converted to a Christian church by the seventh century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chapel of Hakor
    Chapel for the Sacred Barque of Amun-Ra in Karnak, established by the Egyptian pharaoh Hakor of the Twenty-ninth dynasty who reigned from 392/1 to 379/8 BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Chatramotitis
    A region of Arabia Felix that Strabo notes as producing myrrh.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chew Green
    Chew Green is the site of a Roman encampment located in Northumberland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Chhim
    Village in the Sidon Hinterland in modern Lebanon inhabited from the Classical period through Late Antiquity, likely built on a sanctuary site in use during the Bronze and Iron Ages. Remains at the site include a Roman temple, a Christian basilica, and five olive oil presses.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Chiarone (river)
    The Chiarone is a river of the Maremma. It creates one of three major valley systems in the Ager Cosanus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chicha
    Protourban settlement in Western Siberia occupied in the late Bronze Age to Iron Age
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Chiesa Ipogea di San Nicola
    A poorly understood paleochristian site located on the grounds of the Inviolata part in the comune of Guidonia-Montecelio in the greater metropolitan area of Rome. The cave site may originally have functioned as a mithraeum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chil Zena
    A mountainous outcropping located to the west of Kandahar. A flight of forty stone steps leads to the top of the outcropping. The bilingual inscription of the third century BCE known as the Kandahar Bilingual Rock Inscription is found here.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chintolgoi-Balgas
    A major city of the Khitan People of Mongolia. The city was built in 1004, but has layers from before this period and up to the 16th-17th centuries. It was built on the site of an earlier settlement, Kedun.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Chogha Bonut
    Chogha Bonut is an archaeological site located in the Khuzistan Province of Iran. It lies approximately 5km to the west of Chogha Mish. The tell was the site of a settlement of the Elamite civilization and was settled by ca. 7200 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Christian House Church
    Church adapted from a private house building in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Chrysopolitissa complex
    The Chrysopolitissa complex in Paphos is an archaeological area that includes various ruins. Among these are those of an early Christian basilica (fourth to seventh centuries), a medieval Franciscan church (thirteenth century), and the so-called Pillar of St. Paul.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Chughā Gāwānah
    Large mound in the middle of Shahabad-e Gharb (Islamabad) in Western Iran, possibly ancient Palum.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Chughā Pahn East
    A mound where a cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Chughā Pahn West
    A mound where a cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Chughā Sabz
    A mound where a cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Church at Shams el-Din
    The church, well visible in Google Earth, is in the SW sector of the archaeological area
    Creators: Bruno Bazzani; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Church of Mren
    7th-century Armenian church in the Kars region of Turkey. This church is now ruined, but still is the second-largest domed basilica from the 7th-century Caucasus still extant.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Church of Saint Catherine, Thessaloniki
    A late Byzantine church in Thessalonica
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Church of Saint Gregory of Tigran
    Armenian church in Ani, in modern Western Turkey, completed in 1215.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Church of St. Gião
    A Paleochristian sanctuary in Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Church of St. Peter
    A twelfth century AD Christian church built atop the remains of a Roman temple of Apollo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Church of the Holy Apostles (Patmos)
    17th century church behind the Monastery of Saint John the Theologian in Patmos.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Cildá
    A Roman encampment of the Cantabrian wars, dating ca. 29-19 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cinco Puentes
    A Roman bridge
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cirauqui
    Remains of a Roman bridge and paved road.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Circus at Antinoopolis
    A circus was identified at the site in the nineteenth century. John Humphrey dubbed this site "the most impressive circus in Egypt outside Alexandria".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Circus at Lepcis Magna
    The Circus at Lepcis Magna is located to the southeast of their city and measures ca. 100 x 450 m.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Circus at Segobriga
    The area of the Roman Circus at Segobriga had been occupied in the earlier Roman period (at least since the Augustan period) by a cremation necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Circus Maximus Mithraeum
    A mithraeum adjacent to the Circus Maximus and facing the carceres of the same was located at the margin of the Forum Boarium and now situated beneath a building in the via dell'Ara Massima. The site was excavated in 1931.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Circus Varianus
    A circus that was part of the Sessorium palace next to the Amphitheatrum Castrense. The obelisk currently situated on the Pincian Hill was discovered on the site in the sixteenth century. It had been moved to the spina of the circus during the reign of Elagabalus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cisterna delle 36 colonne
    A large Roman cistern associated with the so-called Villa di Marmura at modern Gianola in Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Citadel Fortification of Dura-Europos
    Walls and towers surrounding the citadel hill inside Dura-Europos on the city's eastern side.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Citadel of Dura-Europos
    Fortified hill inside of Dura-Europos, located on the eastern side of the city.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Citania de Santa Luzia
    A fortified protourban site located near the modern city of Viana do Castelo in northern Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Citizen House (Westgate Building)
    The remains of a possible Roman rampart were identified on the St John’s Hospital site in 1954.
    Creators: Syvanne Aloni
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • City wall of Cosa
    Cosa's polygonal masonry fortification wall, reinforced with interval towers, has a length of ca. 1500 meters. Traditionally the wall has been dated between ca. 273 and 264 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • City Wall of Dura-Europos
    The fortified wall encircling the city of Dura-Europos built primarily of locally-quarried ashlar limestone blocks. Built ca. 150 BCE, the walls were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • City wall of Pompeii
    The city walls of Pompeii surround the ancient urban center and have several architectural phases.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cividade de Terroso
    A settlement of the Castro culture founded ca. 900 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Civita Giuliana
    The Civita Giuliana is located in the northern suburbium of Pompeii, about 700 meters from the city walls. Thus far the site has produced archaeological evidence of suburban villas in Pompeii's hinterland. Early twentieth-century excavations were carried out here, only to be published in 1994. Clandestine looting at the site brought about a cooperative effort to resume excavations in the interests of heritage protection in 2017.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Clausura Bir Oum Ali
    The so-called Clausura Bir Oum Ali is part of a defensive barrier that formed part of the Limes Numidiae of the ancient Roman empire. This system of military outposts and fortifications closed off the Roman province of Africa Proconsularis to the south.
    Creators: Stanisław Ludwiński
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Cleddans
    A Roman fortlet on the Antonine Wall in Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Clepsydra of the Oropos Amphiareion
    The Oropos Amphiareion clepsydra is a hydraulic inflow clock serving the Sanctuary of Amphiaraus. Situated on the southeast bank of the sacred spring of Amphiaraus, this inflow hydraulic clock dates to the 4th century BCE.
    Creators: Clara Leach; Ethan Lambright
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Clivus Suburanus
    The Clivus Suburanus was a street of the ancient city of Rome. It rose from the Oppian and Cispian Hills and continued to the Porta Esquilina. Some current urban streets - via in Selci, via di San Martino and via di S. Vito - approximate at least part of its course.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cloghanmore
    A megalithic chamber tomb located in County Donegal, Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Clots de Raynaud
    Site of a Roman pottery workshop near the modern town of Sallèles-d'Aude, in use from the 1st century BCE-3rd century CE. The site is now a museum, the Musée des Potiers Gallo-Romains.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Çobantepe
    An Early to Middle Bronze Age site located on the southern shore of the Dardanelles.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Coddu Vecchiu
    A Bronze Age megalithic gallery grave on Sardinia that belongs to the "giants' tomb" classification.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Coemeterium Maius
    A major Roman necropolis and catacomb along the Via Nomentana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Col di Marzo, Perugia
    Survey and excavation at Montelabate overlooking the upper Tiber valley in the territory of Perugia have revealed evidence for an Etruscan settlement on the hill of Col di Marzo (Perugia). This place is located some 10 km from Arna and rises to 645 meters above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cold Knap Roman Building
    A courtyard building of a non-military nature dating to the later Roman period (second to third century CE) that was located on the seafront at modern Barry (Wales, United Kingdom).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Colle della Coedra
    A small hill in the Alban Hills that was the site of a protourban settlement of Latium covering some 265 square meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Collegium at Italica
    A building that has been identified as the seat of a Collegium because of its internal structure and size, was previously known as the"House of the Exedra".
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Colle Lecinone
    Remains of a villa built on several terraces.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Colleville
    An unusual Gallo-Roman dwelling was excavated during the 1960s. Its main periods of occupation corresponded to the reign of Augustus and then the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Colonia Artefigia
    A place in Italy mentioned in the alimentary inscription from Veleia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Colonnes de Riez
    The remains of a Roman temple of the first century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Colossus Neronis
    The "Colossus Neronis" or "Colossal Statue of Nero" was a monumental bronze statue of the first-century CE emperor reportedly created by Zenodorus. The statue was originally an element of the sprawling Domus Aurea of Nero but the monument endured long after Nero's reign. The statue's original position likely marked the summit of the Velian Hill. The Flavians refashioned the statue to resemble Sol and Hadrian relocated the statue nearer the Flavian amphitheater as part of the work to create the Temple of Venus and Roma.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Columbarium in via Luigi Tosti
    Excavations in 2022 revealed the remains of a Roman tomb of small dimensions, likely of the columbarium type. The tomb included fragments of a sarcophagus in white marble and an inscribed funerary altar of the second century CE. The altar commemorates the life of one Valeria Laeta, daughter of Publius, who lived 13 years and 7 months. The absence of traditional pre-Christian epigraphic formulae led ministry archaeologists to speculate that the tomb is of a Christian nature.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Columbarium of Constantine
    The so-called Columbarium of Constantine is a second century tomb that was later repurposed as a mill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Columbarium of Tiberius Claudius Vitalis
    A columbarium tomb located on the grounds of the Villa Wolkonsky in Rome, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Column of Trajan
    The Column of Trajan (or Trajan's Column) is a victory column that was erected in the Forum of Trajan at Rome ca. 113 in order to commemorate Trajan's victories in the Dacian Wars. The column is particularly noted for its helical historiated bas relief frieze decoration.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Commercial Stoa of Mytilene
    This stoa was built against a fourth century BCE seawall sometime in the Hellenistic era. The seawall shows evidence of later Roman repairs.
    Creators: Anna Farrar; Shannon Wells-Moran
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Complesso di Sant'Imbenia
    A bronze age settlement on the northwest shore of the Bay of Porto Conte in western Sardinia. Excavations revealed a nuraghe and associated village, as well as indigenous, Phoenician, Levantine, and Greek ceramics. Activity at the site seems to have started as early as 1500 BCE and continued until the 7th century BCE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Concarneau
    Site of a Gallo-Roman villa discovered in 1964 in the village of Le Questel near Concarneau. The villa dates from the middle of the first century BCE to the fourth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Constantina
    A Spanish village located in the north of the province of Sevilla that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Contrada Diana
    A prehistoric settlement and Greco-Roman era necropolis underlying the modern city of Lipari, with burials dating from the bronze age through the Roman period.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Convento delle Monache at Grottaferrata
    Construction at the site of Convento delle Monache at Grottaferrata revealed a basis villae measuring 120 by 90 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • conventus Caesaraugustanus
    The conventus Caesaraugustanus was a Roman administrative subdivision of Hispania Tarraconensis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Conventus Carthaginiensis
    The Conventus Carthaginiensis, an area of Iberia that included parts of the modern Spanish regions of Castile/La Mancha and Madrid.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Conventus Lucensis
    A Roman administrative unit located in Gallaecia in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Coombe Hill
    Coombe Hill in East Sussex is the site of a Neolithic causeway enclosure built ca. 3200 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Coriaria Septimiana
    A place included the Regionary Catalogues for Rome's Regio XIV, Coriaria Septimiana refers to tanneries in the Transtiberim. On the basis of epigraphic evidence, the place listed in the Notitia is associated with a small tanning facility on the site of the paleochristian church of Saint Cecilia in Trastevere.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Corre
    A Gallo-Roman site located near the junction of the Saône and Coney rivers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cortaillod-Est
    Settlement on the northern shore of Lake Neuchâtel in Switzerland containing the inundated remains of a Bronze Age village, inhabited ca. 1010-955 BC.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Cortegana
    A Spanish village located in the north of the province of Huelva that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Corviano
    Corviano (Bomarzo) is a protected landscape with evidence of Etruscan, Roman, and Medieval activity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cossourado
    A proto-urban Iron Age site of the Castro culture occupying a hilltop that sits 375 m above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Costa Murata archaeological area
    A site with votive activity from the Archaic period and a later Roman house in addition to the basalt-paved Roman road.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Costești-Blidaru
    A Dacian fotress located near modern Costești village, Hunedoara County, Romania, built in the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Costone della Folonia necropolis
    The Costone della Folonia necropolis of Sovana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Coue d'Auzenat
    A Gallo-Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Couto de Ouro
    A fortified, proto-urban Iron Age village. The site is located in the modern Portuguese municipality of Paredes de Coura.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Creiro
    A Roman garum manufactory.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Crocodile Necropolis
    Cave approximately 17km Northwest of El Maabdeh, Egypt where thousands of mummified crocodiles were found in addition to several other types of animals and human mummies as part of the Egyptian crocodile cult. All discoveries at this site were from the Ptolemaic or Roman periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Crofton Roman villa
    A villa occupied between ca. AD 140 and 400 now located in Orpington, in the London Borough of Bromley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Cronk ny Merriu
    A promontory fort on the Isle of Man.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Charlotte Tupman; Elizabeth Robinson; Tom Elliott
  • Crowdundle Beck
    The Crowdundle Beck is a small river that is a tributary of the River Eden.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Crowdundle quarries
    A no-longer-extant Latin inscription was observed at the Crowdundle quarries along the Crowdundle Beck in 1600 and in 1690. The text mentioned Legio XX Valeria Victrix. The limestone quarried here was used in the construction of Hadrian's Wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Crown Prince's Palace at Assur
    The Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib built a residence for his son Aššur-ilī-muballissu in the city of Assur. That house was constructed near the city wall in the southeastern part of city (city plan quadrants l8/l9), near the bank of the Tigris River. This building, which is known from numerous inscribed stone blocks, is often referred to as the “(Crown) Prince's Palace” or “Prinzenpalast.”
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Crypta Neapolitana
    A rock-cut tunnel of the Via Domitiana built during the first century BC under the direction of Lucius Cocceius Auctus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Csopak
    Roman ruins were discovered on the shores of Lake Balaton.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • C Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Cuarto Roble
    A fortified Roman villa within the territory of Norba Caesarina. Re-occupation occurred during the Islamic period in Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Cuneiform findspot close to the citadel of ‘Ammān
    Location on a slope south-east of the citadel of ‘Ammān (modern Jordan) where cuneiform texts were discovered.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Cutilia
    A Sabine town located between Reate and Interocrium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dabanegoris regio
    A region of Arabia mentioned by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dacia Malvensis (province)
    During the second century CE, Dacia was subdivided into three provinces (Dacia Porolissensis, Dacia Apulensis, and Dacia Malvensis).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dafni Pan cave (Attica)
    A small cave sanctuary near the later Daphi monastery with activity in the fifth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Dağönü
    Once known as İririn or Érérin and now known as Dağönü, this modern Turkish village located in the Van Province of eastern Turkey at the eastern coast of Lake Van lies ca. 10 km north of Ayanis. Here a stela with an inscription of the Urartian king Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) has been found (CTU I A 5-18).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
  • Dah-i Nū
    Mound of Elamite city.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Dalma Tepe
    Dalma Tepe is an archeological site located in western Azerbaijan, some 5 km southwest of Ḥasanlū Tepe.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dalma Tepe III
    The third tell near Dalma, Iran, that remains unexcavated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Danebury Hill Fort
    Danebury hill fort is an Iron Age hill fort near Hampshire, England. The fort covers ca. 5 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dangstetten
    Dangstetten was the site of a Roman military camp.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Daphni Monastery
    The current Daphni Monastery in Attica dates to the eleventh century, yet its earlier Christian phases belong to the sixth century AD when a Christian site grew atop the abandoned and destroyed sanctuary of Apollo Daphnaios.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Darb Qirmiz
    Darb Qirmiz is a residential neighborhood in the tenth-century Fatimid quarter of Cairo, Egypt, with the oldest remaining monuments dating from the fourteenth century.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Dargues
    The remains of the earthworks of a Roman temporary camp.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Darsa (island)
    Darsa is an island in the Socotra Archipelago of Yemen.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dasht-e Nawar
    Dasht-e Nawar is a settlement site beginning in prehistoric times on the shores of the lake of the same name. Based on epigraphic evidence, the Archaeological Gazetteer of Afghanistan (1982) classifies it as Kushan, second-third century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Daunian Mountains
    A mountain range of southern Italy that constitutes the eastern appendix of the Campanian Apennines.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Davti-blur
    Davti-blur is the Armenian name of an Urartian settlement situated on a natural hill near the modern village Nor-Armavir. Just like the settlement on the immediately adjacent hill Armavir which in Urartian was called Argištihinili ("city of Argišti") it was founded by Argišti I, son of Minua (8th century BCE). In Davti-Blur, a column base with an inscription of Argišti I was found which reports the construction of a building. Furthermore, several inscriptions on clay pithoi by Argišti have been found there which attest to the administrative activity at this place. A stone block of the Urartian king Sarduri II, son of Argišti I (8th century BCE) reveals that the place was further developed and extended by Sarduri II.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
  • Decumanus maximus at Vulci
    Belonging to Vulci's Roman phase, the Decumanus Maximus is the well-preserved east-west road of the city paved in basalt.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Değirmenköy
    A findspot of an Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Deir el-Bahari
    Deir el-Bahari is a complex of mortuary temples and tombs that constitute a part of the Theban necropolis located on the west bank of the Nile river, opposite Luxor.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Delian League
    A modern name for an alliance formed by Greek cities, led by Athens, in 478 BCE. Formed in the aftermath of the Persian Wars, the purpose of the league was ostensibly to avenge damage to Greece inflicted by the Persian Empire by attacking Persian territory. Athens increasingly dominated the league until it effectively became the Athenian Empire.
    Creators: Ryan Horne
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Delibaba Fortress
    Delibaba (or Dellal / Velibaba) Fortress is an Urartian fortress which lies to the east of the Dellal pass 17 km southeast of the city Horasan in the Horasan county of the Erzurum province between Hasankale (Pasinler) and Aleşkirt. Its name Delibaba (Velibaba) comes from the modern Turkish village Delibaba (Velibaba) which is situated in the vicinity of the fortress. A stone inscription of the Urartian king Minua, son of Išpuini (9th / 8th century BCE) which was found there reports that the fortress was built by Minua "through the protection of the god Haldi". The Urartian name of the fortress is unknown.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Delikkemer aqueduct
    An inverted siphon aqueduct at Patara.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dema Tower
    A round defensive tower located to the east of the Dema Wall in Attica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Demircihöyük
    An ancient Settlement located in Eskişehir Province, Turkey.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Dendra
    Bronze Age cemetery near the Mycenean settlement of Midea.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Dereüstü
    Find spot for fragmentary stele with Urartian inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Dermech basilica
    A Christian basilica of Byzantine Carthage.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Derveni tombs
    Macedonian tombs and Hellenistic chamber tombs where the Derveni krater and Derveni papyri were discovered.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Dharmaraja Cave
    Modern name of a seventh-century Pallava cave temple in Mahābalipuram.
    Creators: Emmanuel Francis
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dharmaraja Ratha
    Modern name of a seventh-century Pallava rock-cut temple in Mahābalipuram.
    Creators: Emmanuel Francis
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Dholavira
    Dholavira was a settlement connected with the Indus Valley Civilization. Covering some 47 ha (120 acres), the city was occupied from ca. 2650 BCE until ca. 1800 BCE. It is possible that occupation began as early as 3500 BCE, however.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dibba
    Iron age tomb where cuneiform inscription was found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Dicle Bridge
    An historic bridge built across the Tigris river by Sancaroğlu Ubeydoğlu Yusuf in AD 1065.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dikili Tash
    Dikili Tash is a prehistoric tell in eastern Macedonia, approximately 1.5 km east of ancient Philippi. The site has been excavated by the École française d’Athènes in stages since 1920. Neolithic and Bronze Age deposits have been investigated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Dilmun Temple at Saar
    20th century BCE Dilmun temple on the highest part of the ancient settlement mound at Saar in modern Bahrain.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Dinkha Tepe
    The site of Dinkha Tepe is located in the Ushnu valley of Iranian Azerbaijan. Sir Aurel Stein initially identified second-millennium BCE funereal deposits there. The University of Pennsylvania Museum, under Robert H. Dyson, jr. and Oscar White Muscarella, carried out further excavations in the late 1960s.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dis Pater, Aedes
    A temple listed in the Notitia for Regio XI but not the Curiosum may be a misidentification of the temple of Summanus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Divorum
    A porticus constructed by Domitian in A.D. 80 on the eastern Campus Martius on the site of the Villa Publica, whose northern entry—a triumphal arch—was flanked by two small temples in honor of Titus and Vespasian.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Djub-i Gauhar
    9th-7th centuries BCE Iron Age cemetery site near modern Eyvanki in Iran. The excavated site comprises 56 stone-lined tombs, 9 pit graves, and 1 pithos grave.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Documaci tumulus
    Elite tomb structure constructed in the late 4th-early 3rd century BCE near the Hellenistic settlement of Callatis.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Dolciano
    Dolciano is located in the environs of Chiusi and abundant evidence of Etruscan necropoleis has been documented there.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dolmen de la Pierre Blanche
    The ruinous remains of a dolmen-type tomb, its tumulus no longer extant, are located on the same axis as the Tusson tumuli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dólmenes de Antequera
    A Chalcolithic necropolis located in Antequera, province of Málaga, Andalusia, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dolmen of Guadalperal
    A megalithic stone circle dating to the third millennium BCE located in Peraleda de la Mata in eastern Extremadura, Spain. The monument is usually submerged beneath the waters of the Embalse de Valdecañas, a reservoir of the Tagus river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Domus Aurea
    A sprawling palace complex begun by Nero after A.D. 64 that aimed to connect the Esquiline, Caelian, and Palatine hills.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Domus de Janas on Monte Crobu
    A prehistoric chamber tomb of the third millennium B.C. The 'Domus de Janas' tombs are typical of the Ozieri and Beaker cultures and are found chiefly on Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Domus di Vigna Guidi
    A well-appointed domus of the mid-second century CE that was consumed by the construction works to create the Thermae Antoninianae, resulting in its being buried to a depth of some 10 m in construction fill. Heritage officials describe the house as a sort of 'condominium', comparing it to the contemporary insulae of Ostia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Domus Faustae
    The Domus Faustae refers to a part of the Latern Palace. In about 312, Constantine razed the barracks of the imperial horse-guards barracks that adjoined the palace. At that time, the palace was known as Domus Faustae. Since the equites singulares Augusti had supported Maxentius, Constantine destroys the barracks and orders the beginnings of the construction of the Basilica di San Giovanni in Laterano on the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • domus Philippi
    The domus Philippi of the Regionary Catalogues may refer to the house of Julius Philippus (244-249 A.D.)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Domus rustica
    The ruins of a Republican-period 'domus rustica' located on the via Alexandre Gustave Eiffel in Rome, Italy, near Ponte Galeria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Donatım
    A hill where a basalt stone inscription was found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Donuktaş
    An archaeological site in Tarsus, Turkey, that has been interpreted in various ways and assigned to various periods. The current consensus suggests that the ruined concrete structure is of a sacred nature and dates to the second century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Doric nymphaeum
    The so-called "Doric nymphaeum" is located on the shores of the Alban lake and was a component of the Villa of Domitian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dornburg
    A Celtic oppidum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dorset Cursus
    A Neolithic cursus monument spanning some 10 km of Cranborne Chase in east Dorset, United Kingdom.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dorsigi
    An ancient people of India whose territory is now unlocated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Doss Penede (Nago-Torbole, TN)
    A pre-Roman and Roman complex at the foot of Castel Penede.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Doss Trento
    Doss Trento is a small hill that lies along the course of the Adige River. A Paleochristian basilica was located on the hillside.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Dover Castle
    The medieval castle (twelfth century) sits atop earlier Roman fortifications.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss
  • Dragonera
    Two coastal villas (villae maritimae) discovered in 2003 and 2004, respectively.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Drepanon Cemetery
    An ancient cemetery at modern Drepano in Greece, uncovered in rescue excavations since the 1970s.
    Creators: Enrico Regazzoni
    Contributors: Enrico Regazzoni; Tom Elliott
  • Drombeg stone circle
    A megalithic stone circle monument, also known as the Druid's Altar, consisting of seventeen closely spaced stones with a diameter of 9.3 m. Thirteen stones survive today.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Drumlanrig
    A Roman auxiliary fort located at Drumlanrig in Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • D Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Dugali Alti
    Dugali Alti or Dugali Alti di Ostiano is an archaeological site located near Ostiano in Cremona, Italy, that has provided evidence of agricultural practices in the Neolithic period of northern Italy.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dugirdkhan
    Mound where cuneiform inscription has been found, periodically inundated.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Duino Mithraeum
    A Mithraeum near Duino, in the province of Trieste, north-eastern Italy, that is located within a natural cave.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Dülük Baba Tepesi
    A mountain in Türkiye rising to 176 meters (577 feet) above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dun Carloway
    Dun Carloway Broch is a well preserved broch in Scotland that was in use from ca. the first century BC until ca. AD 1300.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Dur-Abiesuh
    City founded by Babylonian king Abiesuh in the 18th-17th centuries. The location of this city is unknown, as cuneiform tablets from the site were taken in the 1990s without recording the location, but it is likely less than 50 km from Nippur.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Dur-Šarrukin Archive 1
    Three tiers of niches were found in Room H 5 (on the northwestern side of Forecourt I) of the Nabû temple at Dur-Šarrukin, the short-lived capital of the Assyrian king Sargon II (721–705 BC). Fragments of clay tablets and inscribed prisms in these niches suggest that a temple library was located here. The empty niches might be a result of the move of the capital to Nineveh under Sennacherib (704–681 BC) or of the use of perishable writing materials.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Dur-Šarrukin Archive 2
    Two tiers of niches (similar to Dur-Šarrukin 1) were found in Room H 15 (on the northwestern side of Courtyard II) of the Nabû temple at Dur-Šarrukin, the short-lived capital of the Assyrian king Sargon II (721–705 BC). Although no inscribed objects were found inside the niches, the existence of a temple library is suggested by a similar construction in Room H 5 (on the northwestern side of Forecourt I). The empty niches might be the result of the move of the capital to Nineveh under Sennacherib (704–681 BC) or of the use of perishable writing materials.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Duurlig Nars
    Xiongnu tomb site near the modern village of Bayan-Adarga, Khentii, Mongolia. The site contains burials dated from the 4th century BCE to the 2nd century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Dymaean Wall
    The Dymaean Wall is a Cyclopean fortification wall dating ca. 1300 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • E5 Barracks
    Partially excavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block E5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • E6 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block E6 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ea-Damkina temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Ea and the goddess Damkina. Although its location is not known, the Ea-Damkina temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ea Gate
    The Ea Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Ea-muštēšir-nagbīšu ("The God Ea Is the One Who Keeps Its Spring(s) in Good Order"), is the seventh of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the south-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location remains unknown.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Eandasaya
    The temple of the goddess Ištar of the Star, Eandasaya (“House Which Rivals Heaven”), was located in the New City district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of two temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Early fortified site at Ghuzza
    An unexcavated, eroded fortified site at the gold-processing complex at al-Ghuzza in Egypt's eastern desert. It may date to the New Kingdom period.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Eastern Desert
    Desert region between the Nile River and the Red Sea.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Eastern Outer Wall of Babylon
    The Neo-Babylonian ruler Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) started planning and constructing an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. This massive mudbrick brick wall, together with its protective quay wall and a wide moat, remained unfinished at the time of Nabopolassar’s death. His son and successor Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) finished the work started by his father. Traces of Babylon’s once-impressive eastern outer wall are still visible today.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ea temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the god Ea.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ebursasa
    The temple of the god Šara, Ebursasa (“House of Beautiful Jars”), was located in the Bāb-Lugalerra district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ecclesiasterion (Odeion) at Messene
    The Ecclesiasterion (Odeion) at Messene was originally constructed in the third century BCE and may be a converted ecclesiasterio/bouleuterion.
    Creators: Alisa MacDonald; Amir Wekseler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter; Amir Weksler
  • Edikukalama
    The temple of the god Šamaš, Edikukalama (“House of the Judge of the Land”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon. Edikukalama is attested in the Old Babylonian Period and it was rebuilt in the Neo-Babylonian Period by Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Edurkuga
    The dais of the Igīgū gods, Edurkuga (“House, Pure Abode”), was located in the TE.E (read as either Tê or Kisīri) district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of two daises in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Eʾesirkalama
    The temple of the god Pisangunuk, Eʾesirkalama (“House of the Street of the Land”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Eʾešmah
    The temple of the god Ea, Eʾešmah (“Exalted House”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Egalgabarinutukua
    The palace of the eighth-century-BC Assyrian Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) at Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), Egalgabarinutukua ("Palace That Has No Equal"), was constructed between 717 BC and 706 BC. This royal residence was constructed on a high, mud-brick terrace located within the city’s citadel, which was located against the northwestern stretch of the city wall. This large, ornately-decorated palace complex consisted of over two hundred rooms (including chapels to the deities Ea, Sîn, Ningal, Adad, Šamaš, and Ninurta) and courtyards, as well as a ziggurat.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Eggardon hill fort
    Eggardon Hill is the site of an Iron Age hill fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Egišhurankia
    The temple of the goddess Bēlet-Ninūa, Egišhurankia (“House of the Ordinances of Heaven and Underworld”), was located in the Bāb-Lugalerra district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon. Egišhurankia seems to have been located near Imgur-Enlil, along the northern wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ehilikalamma
    The temple of the goddess Ašratu, Ehilikalamma (“House of the Luxuriance of the Land”), was located in the Ka-dingirra district (modern Sahn) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of four temples in that part of the city, which was located in the northern part of the eastern half of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ehursagtilla
    The temple of the god Ninurta, Ehursagtilla (“House Which Exterminates the Mountains”), was located in the Šuanna district (modern Ishin Aswad) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of two temples in that part of the city, which was located in the southern part of the eastern half of Babylon. The building was rebuilt by the Neo-Babylonian king Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Eightercua
    A megalithic tomb dated ca. 1700 BC located near Waterville, County Kerry, Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Eilean Dòmhnuill
    Eilean Dòmhnuill is the site of perhaps the earliest crannog settlement in Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ein Karem
    Settlement in existence since the Early Bronze Age with evidence of habitation through the present day, albeit with a great reduction in size in the 14th-early 17th centuries. This site is now a suburb of Jerusalem.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Ekadima
    The temple of the god Belili, Ekadima (“House Which Creates ...”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ekagula
    The dais of the Anunnakū gods, Ekagula (“House, Big Gate”), was located in the TE.E (read as either Tê or Kisīri) district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of two daises in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ekišnugal
    The temple of the god Sîn, Ekišnugal (“House of the Great Light”), was located in the Kullab district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of four temples in that part of Babylon. The temple is mentioned in Old Babylonian Period texts and was (re)built by the Old Babylonian king Abī-ēšuh (r. ca. 1711–1684 BC) and the Neo-Babylonian ruler Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC). The temple survived into the Hellenistic Period.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ekitušgarza
    The temple of the goddess Bēlet-Eanna, Ekitušgarza (“House, Abode of the Regulations”), was located in the Tuba district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon. Ekitušgarza was rebuilt by the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–652 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ekitušgirzal
    The temple of the goddess Bēlet-Eanna, Ekitušgirzal (“House, Abode of Joy”), was located in the New City district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of two temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ekklesiasterion at Akragas
    Located in the Upper Agroa, the Ekklesiasterion at Akragas dates to the fourth and third centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ekklesiasterion/Theater at Metapontum
    A building complex located in the city's agora, the Ekklesiasterion/Theater is dated ca. 625-300 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • el-Amrah
    Predynastic and Early Dynastic burial site containing over 1,000 burials. It is the type-site of the Amratian culture.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Elar
    Site for rock inscription (now fragmented and removed) by the road from Yerevan to Lake Sevan.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • El Castellar de Berrueco
    A celtiberian settlement located just south of modern Berrueco in Spain's Zaragoza province.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Elephant tomb at Carmona
    Structure in the the necropolis of Carmona (near Seville) named for a small sculpture of an elephant found inside it. Rather than a tomb, it may have been a sanctuary or temple.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Elephas herbarius
    Elephas herbarius (Elefantum herbarium), a place included in the Notitia, is mentioned only once and must lie at the southern limit of Regio VIII. Coarelli concludes that this place must have been located on the lower slopes of the Capitoline Hill facing the Forum Holitorium. Its coincidence with Late Antique and Medieval toponyms suggests that it refers to an ancient statue of an elephant, perhaps one shown eating plants, in the area of the Forum Holitorium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • el Kharafish
    Nomadic desert campsite located near the Dakleh Oasis associated with the Sheikh Muftah culture. The site was seasonally occupied from about 3000-2200 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Elkharas
    Khwarazmian site on the bank of the Amu Darya River. The site was excavated in 1973-1975 prior to flooding due to dam construction. The primary occupation at the site is dated from the 6th century BCE-3rd century CE, with evidence of later occupation as late as the 11th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • el-Mahasna
    Predynastic cemetery site approximately 8 miles north of Abydos. A small settlement was built on the site in the Early Dynastic period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • El Molón
    A fortified, pre-Roman oppidum located to the north of modern Camporrobles in Spain's Valencia region.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • El Qattah
    At this site located northwest of modern Cairo in Egypt's Giza governate, early twentieth-century excavations identified, among other finds, a Middle Kingdom necropolis with evidence of at least 14 tombs, including the tomb of one Neha, a Middle Kingdom prince.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Emah
    The temple of the goddess Ninmah/Bēlet-ilī, Emah (“Exalated House”), was located in the Ka-dingirra district (modern Kasr) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of four temples in that part of the city, which was located in the northern part of the eastern half of Babylon. Emah was rebuilt by the Assyrian king Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC) and the Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Emekiliburur
    The temple of the goddess Šarrat-Larsa, Emekiliburur (“House which Gathers All the Me’s”), was located in the Kullab district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of four temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Emesikila
    The temple of the god Amurru, Emesikila (“House of Pure Me’s”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon. Emesikila is mentioned in Old Babylonian sources.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Emeurur
    The temple of the goddess Nanāya, Emeurur (“House which Gathers the Me’s”), was located in the TE.E (read as either Tê or Kisīri) district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was the only temple in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Empulum
    A now unlocated settlement of Latium Vetus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Enamhe
    The temple of the god Adad, Enamhe (“House of Plenty”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon. Enamhe was (re)built by the the Old Babylonian kings Sūmû-lā-El (r. ca. 1881–1845 BC) and Hammu-rāpi (r. ca. 1792–1750 BC) and the Neo-Babylonian ruler Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Enamtila
    The temple of the god Bēl-mātāti (Enlil), Enamtila (“House of Life”), was located in the Kumar district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of seven temples in that part of Babylon. Enamtila is mentioned in Old Babylonian and Kassite Period texts.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • 'En Besor
    Settlement on a hill in modern Israel with Early Bronze Age and Hellenistic remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Enlil Gate
    The Enlil Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Enlil-mukīn-išdī-alīya ("The God Enlil Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of My City"), is the third of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the north-facing entrances to the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Enlil Gate
    The Enlil Gate is one of Babylon's eight city gates and it is situated on the northwestern side of the inner city, directly north of the Bāb-Lugalerra quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Enlil temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Enlil. Although its location is not known, the Enlil temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Enunmah
    The temple of the god Nusku, Enunmah (“House of the Exalted Prince”), was located in the Bāb-Lugalerra district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • *Epocuria
    An unlocated fort in the canton of the Iceni, attested in a single document from Roman London. The transcription of the name is uncertain due to the condition of the document.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Equus Tiridatis Regis Armeniorum
    A now-lost equestrian statue at Rome honoring Tiridates I of Armenia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Eremo di San Michele (Coli)
    The cavern of San Michele was a hermit's dwelling place that is located near a cavern known as the "cave of San Colombano". This hermitage lies in a relatively solitary area of the valley of the Curiasca di San Michele stream, a tributary of the Trebbia river (Italian municipality of Coli, province of Piacenza).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Eridanos
    A stream that flowed from the Lykabettos, through the Agora to the Kerameikos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Eridu
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Eridu was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained thirteen temples (including Esagila) and the ziggurat Etemenanki. Eridu is also a name of Babylon itself.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Erzen
    Find place for cuneiform inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Esabad
    The temple of the goddess Gula, Esabad (“House of the Open Ear”), was located in the Tuba district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon. Esabad was rebuilt by the Assyrian king Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–652 BC). The temple survived into Arsacid times (247 BC–AD 224).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Esag
    The temple of the god Lugalbanda, Esag (“Foremost House”), was located in the Kullab district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of four temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Ešasurra
    The temple of the god Išhara, Ešasurra (“House of the Womb”), was located in the Šuanna district (modern Ishin Aswad) of Babylon. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, this was one of two temples in that part of the city, which was located in the southern part of the eastern half of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Esgair Perfedd marching camp
    A Roman marching camp that orginally covered ca. 6.2 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ešiddukišara
    The temple of the god Nabû, Ešiddukišara (“House of the Director of the Universe”), was located in the Tuba district of Babylon, in the western half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of three temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Eskiharran
    The findspot of a stele from the reign of Nabonidus, the last king of the Neo-Babylonian Empire.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Eskiyapar
    Hittite city with fortification.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Espelt Roman villa
    A Roman villa that was inhabited from the late first century AD until the fifth century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Esquilinus Mons
    The Esquiline Hill is one of the seven hills of Rome. The eastern section of the hill lay outside the Servian Wall, and served as a pauper's cemetery during the archaic and Republican periods.
    Creators: Echo Smith; Edward Keogh; Sara Hales
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • E Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Etruscan necropolis of Malignano
    An Etruscan necropolis south of Sovicille in the province of Siena. The tombs date from the fifth century B.C. onward.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Etruscan necropolis of Pianacce
    An Etruscan necropolis located near the center of Sarteano with tombs dating from the sixth to the second centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Etruscan necropolis of Terrone
    A rock-cut Etruscan necropolis located at Blera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Eurguba
    The temple of the god Pisangunuk, Eurguba (“House, Established Foundation”), was located in the Kullab district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was one of four temples in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Eurunanam
    The temple of the god Nabû, Eurunanam (“House, the Very City”), was located in the New City district of Babylon, in the eastern half of the inner city. According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon Tablet IV, it was the only dais in that part of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Exeter Roman Bathhouse
    A stone-built bathhouse at Exeter connected with the Neronian fortress.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ezida (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the god Nabû. Unlike most of the religious buildings constructed at Kalhu, the Ezida ("True House") was built in the southeast corner of the Citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • F5 Barracks
    Military barracks located north of the camp wall in the northern part of Block K5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • F7 Barracks
    Military barracks located north of the camp wall in the northern part of Block K5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Fábrica Romana de Salga
    This Roman fish-salting workshop located in Setúbal dates to the first century CE. It was discovered in 1979.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fagutal
    Fagutal is the name of the western spur of the Esquiline hill in Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fanum Pithiviers-le-Vieil
    The Fanum of Pithiviers-le-Vieil.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Farah Bala Hisar
    According to Ball (1982), Farah Bala Hisar is the site of a large fortified enclosure of mud with multi-period remains, the latest of which are those of a castle dating from the Timurid period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Faras Cathedral
    Cathedral in Faras founded in 620, rebuilt in the 8th and 10th centuries that was the seat of the Diocese of Faras. The site had well-preserved wall paintings from the 8th-9th centuries. This cathedral was flooded by the creation of Lake Nasser in the 1960s.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Farfa Abbey
    A Benedictine abbey located ca. 60 km from Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Fatimid Cemetery in Aswan
    The Fatimid Cemetery in Aswan includes tombs dating from the seventh to the twelfth centuries CE. The site is included in the UNESCO World Heritage Site "Nubian Monuments from Abu Simbel to Philae".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fazouro
    A first-third century AD castrum site on the Galician coast.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ferentinae Lucus
    A sacred grove and fountain, likely on the slopes of the Alban Mount, that was the site of the assembly of the Latin League.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Feride Gül Tarla (FGT) excavation sector
    The Feride Gül Tarla (FGT) excavation sector at Klazomenai.
    Creators: Peter Cobb; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ferrone Necropolis
    An Etruscan necropolis located on a tufaceous plateau overlooking the valley of the Fosso della Lenta. The tombs in the necropolis date between the seventh and fifth centuries BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Festoi
