    A place that, according to Strabo, was located between the "fifth and sixth milestone" and may have, at one point, marked the limit of the Ager Romanus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fidenates
    The Fidenates number among the lost peoples of Latium enumerated by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fifth century baths at Lebadeia
    Foundations of a bath facility with mosaic pavement and other structures were discovered during rescue excavations in 2006 at the corner of Daidalou and Kadmou streets in modern Levadeia, Greece.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Filippovka Burial Ground
    An archaeological site with nine burial mounds, including an intact royal mound (kurgan), located in the Southern Ural Region of Russia dating from the 6th-4th centuries BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Finca del Secretario
    An archaeological site that comprises remains of an urban area of the Roman period ranging in date from the first to the fifth centuries. Among the complexes in evidence are a salting factory, a pottery works, and thermal baths.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Findspot of so-called Kabul Hoard
    The approximate location of the fourth century BCE archaeological deposit that is referred to as either the Kabul or Chaman-i Ḥaz̤ūrī Coin Hoard.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Fines exercitus Syriaticae
    An area of the Syrian desert marked on the Peutinger Table that may indicate the boundary between the Roman province of Syria and a client state, possibly Palmyra.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fingrinhoe Roman Site
    A multi-acre site, now located within the bounds of the Fingringhoe Wick Nature Discovery Park in Colchester. The site may have been or included a Roman military supply base that was in use until ca. A.D. 120. The site included several structures, a ditched enclosure, and a possible villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Firronanus Saltus
    The pontifex Lucius Coelius Baro is recorded as the curator of the Firronanus Saltus located in regio XI.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • First Mithraeum
    First phase of a sacred space dedicated to the worship of the god Mithras at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Five Rathas
    The Five Rathas is the modern name of a group of five seventh-century Pallava rock-cut temples at Mahābalipuram.
    Creators: Emmanuel Francis
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Flacciana
    A place in Africa Proconsularis, according to the Peutinger map.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Flag Fen
    Flag Fen is a Bronze Age ritual site near Peterborough, England, comprised of 60,000 timbers arranged in five rows that connect Whittlesey Island with Peterborough. Dendrochronological evidence has dates the site to ca. 1365–967 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fleury
    A small Gallo-Roman settlement south of Béziers, located on the coast at La Fount de Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fondi Plini-Gigliotti, Prato La Corte
    A Late Roman villa on the Via Capenate about 1 km from Capena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fontager necropolis
    A necropolis in Gallia Narbonensis discovered within the thirteenth century Chateau de Fontager in 1963-1964.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fonte Coberta
    A Roman dam
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forau de la Tuta
    A previously unknown settlement with Roman-period remains was identified near the village of Artieda, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Formina Roman aqueduct
    The Formina Roman aqueduct provided water to the ancient city of Narnia. It originally dates to the first century CE. After antiquity, the first notice of it is recorded in 1371.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fórnea Roman villa
    An imperial villa, occupied between the second and fourth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Foro Romano
    The Roman forum of Aquileia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forre di Corchiano
    The Forre di Corchiano is a preserved landscape significant not only for its landforms but also for cultural heritage remains pertaining to many periods.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fortetsa Tombs
    A Late Minoan burial site just West of the Knossos Acropolis.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Fortino di Mazzallakkar
    A ruined ninth-century Arabic fort on the shores of Sicily's Lago Arancio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum Aemilianum
    The Roman forum of Terracina, entered by a quadrifons arch, sits along the line of the Via Appia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum of Col. Augusta Raurica
    The Forum of Augusta Raurica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum of Iuvanum
    The Roman forum of Iuvanum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum of Jublains
    The remains of the ancient forum at modern Jublains.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Forum of Lucus Feroniae
    The forum of the Roman colony, Colonia Iulia felix Lucoferensis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum Suarium
    A forum venalium of ancient Rome linked to the sale of pork, the Forum Suarium is mentioned in two inscriptions dating ca. 200 CE. The forum lay near the barracks of the urban cohorts (cohortes urbanae) in the northern portion of the Campus Martius, perhaps near the location of the present Via di Propaganda in metropolitan Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum Subertanum
    A site in South Etruria mentioned by Livy in connection with the year 211 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Forum Traiani
    Imperial forum constructed at Rome under Trajan between 105-112 CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Fossa Cluilia
    The Fossa Cluilia was a defensive ditch built by Caius Cluilius, king of Alba Longa, during Alba Longa's war with Rome in the seventh century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fosso della Fiora
    One of the sources of the Aqua Traiana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fosso di Pratolungo
    The Fosso di Pratolungo is a small tributary of the Anio. Its lower course is also known as Fosso di Marco Simone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Fosso Marangone
    A small stream that flows into the Tyrrhenian Sea. It now lies in the territory of the municipalities of Allumiere, Civitavecchia, and Santa Marinella and forms the geographical boundary between the latter two. The watercourse originates at Poggio Ombricolo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fosso Saina
    A minor tributary of the Anio river in the vicinity of Guidonia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fountain of Anna Perenna
    Sacred to the goddess Anna Perenna and the nymphs, this rectangular fountain surrounded by rupestral inscriptions was excavated on the modern Via Guidubaldo del Monte in Rome's Pinciano neighborhood during the late 20th century. Rich votive deposits complement the picture of the goddess' worship painted by Ovid in the Fasti entry for the Ides of March.
    Creators: Tom Elliott; Abigail Graham
    Contributors:
  • Fournou Korifi
    An Early Minoan site in south Crete; findspot of the libation vessel known as the 'Goddess of Myrtos'.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Franchthi Cave
    The Franchthi Cave is located on the Argolic Gulf in southeastern Argolis. The cave was occupied from the Paleolithic (ca. 20,000 BC) through to the Mesolithic and Neolithic periods, ultimately being abandoned ca. 3000 BC. The cave shows continuous human occupation for more than 20,000 years.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Frattura Vecchia
    Frattura Vecchia is a hamlet located in the town of Scanno now in the Abruzzo National Park. This small village is located about 1260 meters above sea level and has ancient origins, perhaps as early as 1106.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Freimühle
    A Roman outpost of the Rhaetian Limes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Friars Wash Roman Temple
    The Friars Wash Roman Temple was noted first in 1965. Aerial photography and subsequent archaeological investigation identified a system of ditches and two rectangular structures that were considered to be Romano-British temples.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Frielas
    A Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Frontone
    An Umbro-Roman temple of Iuppiter on the slopes of Monte Catria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Frontovoe 3 Cemetery
    Roman-era cemetery in the Crimea with 332 burial structures containing 500 bodies and 20,000 artifacts. The site was destroyed with the creation of the Taurida Expressway.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • F Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Fufidianum
    The name of an estate near Arpinum that once belonged to Q. Tullius Cicero.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fundus Albianus
    An estate located in the Pagus Ambitrebius mentioned on the Tabula alimentaria Traianea.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fundus Amarantianus
    An estate located near Ligures Baebiani.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fundus Appianus
    The estate of Aurelius Appianus, located near Beneventum and Ligures Baebiani (Circello). It's precise location is not known.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Fundus Babuleianus
    An estate located near Interamna Lirenas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fundus Betutianus
    An estate in Aemilia mentioned on the Veleia tablet.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Fundus Campus Naranus
    Fundus Campus Naranus, a region located near Volcei in Bruttium et Lucania (Regio III).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Funerary Chamber of Manlia Felicitas
    A subterranean funerary chamber with three frescoes walls depicting animal and vegetal life, located around the third mile of the Via Appia.
    Creators: Yuyao Liu
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Funerary Grove of Epikrates and Tomb Garden of Tertia and Secundus at Nakrason
    A funerary grove and tomb garden built by one Epikrates, attested by inscriptions on a stele, in the unlocated Anatolian settlement of Nakrason.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Funerary Grove of Q. Cervonius Chryseros
    A now-lost inscribed altar of a probable Julio-Claudian date was found by T. Mommsen among the stones of Aquileia. The inscription described the dedication of a grove.
    Creators: Zhenrui Mei
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Funtana Coberta
    A sacred well of the Nuragic civilization dated between 1200 and 850 BC. The well is located between the modern Sardinian settlements of Escalaplano and Ballao near the junction of highways S6, S13, and S23.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gaĭ-Kodzor
    Village in Krasnodar Krai, Russia, located 9 km. southeast of Anapa. Between 1972 and 1986, several separate coin hoards dated to the late Bosporan Kingdom (4th century CE) were found on a farm at the edge of the village.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Galatas
    A Minoan palatial center on Crete dated ca. 1700-1600 BC that was discovered in the 1990s.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gali͡ugaĭ
    A Bronze Age settlement with burial mounds outside it, located in the modern the Terek River in Russia's Stavropol Krai. Scholars interpret this site as one of several defining the "Maykop culture", which flourished during the fourth millennium BCE in the western Caucasus.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gallaberry Camp
    A Roman temporary marching camp that was identified via cropmarks in June 1939. The camp covered 1.33 acres and measured 64 x 110 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallardet Dolmen
    A large dolmen located near Le Pouget in Languedoc, France.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallarus Oratory
    An early Christian church in Ireland, originally built between the sixth and the ninth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gallic oppidum of Castel-Coz
    The archaeological remains of a pre-Roman oppidum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallo-Roman amphitheater at Grannum
    The Gallo-Roman amphitheater at Grannum dates to the late first century B.C.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallo-Roman Amphitheater of Agen
    A Gallo-Roman amphitheater dating to the early third century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gallo-Roman bath complex at Mackwiller
    A Gallo-Roman bath complex located at the modern town of Mackwiller in the French commune of Waldhambach.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gallo-Roman remains at La Tour, Sablé-sur-Sarthe
    The remains of a Gallo-Roman sanctuary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallo-Roman settlement, locality of Courac
    Near the locality of Courac, just north of modern Tresques, are the remains of a diffuse Gallo-Roman settlement occupied from the first to fourth centuries A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallo-Roman temple at Vannes
    Remains of a Gallo-Roman at Vannes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Gallo-Roman theater at Alba Helviorum
    A third and fourth century theater at Alba Helviorum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gallo-Roman theater at Dalheim
    The Gallo-Roman theater at Dalheim.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Gallo-Roman villa at La Grande Terre, Chandon
    A Gallo-Roman villa located in the Sornin valley, Loire, France.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ganesh Ratha
    Modern name of a seventh-century Pallava rock-cut temple at Mahābalipuram.
    Creators: Emmanuel Francis
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gangani
    The Gangani were an ancient people of Ireland, as described by Ptolemy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Garden and Pool Complex at Petra
    Garden terrace and monumental pool with island pavilion dates to the Nabataean/Early Roman periods, 9 BCE-c. 200 CE. Formerly called the "Lower Market."
    Creators: Jane Ellen Millar
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Garden Houses
    A large residential complex, built in ca. 128 CE as part of the Hadrianic remodeling of Ostia. Its central area was occupied by two blocks, each comprising four houses, surrounded by a garden furnished with six fountains.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Garden of Cybele
    An archaeological area in Vienne that includes remains of municipal and domestic architecture.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Gardens of Maecenas
    The Gardens of Maecenas or "Horti Maecenatis" were extensive, planned gardens laid out on Rome's Esquiline Hill by Caius Cilinius Maecenas in the mid-30s B.C. These formal gardens occupied what had previously been the agger of the Servian walls and the adjacent necropolis that had an unsavory reputation. Following the death of Maecenas, the gardens became imperial property.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Garn Fadryn
    A 5 ha Iron Age hill fort located in Wales.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Garšana
    A Babylonian town possibly located near Umma, Zabalam, and Karkar where over 1500 cuneiform tablets were found. The location of the site is unknown due to the tablets having been looted.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gaulopes
    A tribe located near the Sinus Capeus, on the west of the Persian gulf.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gavurkale
    Gavurkale is a hill in central Anatolia with remains of both Hittite rock-cut reliefs and architecture dating from various periods.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gebel al Silsila
    Gebel al Silsila is a mountain that was the site of quarrying activity in ancient Egypt.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gebel es-Silsilah
    A mountain on the west bank of the Nile 40 miles north of Aswan with over 30 18th dynasty shrines. This site was first settled in the late Predynastic period, wan important sandstone quarry in the 18th dynasty with some inhabitants, and was still in use in the Roman period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Gelati Monastery
    The Monastery of Gelati was founded in 1106 in western Georgia. It was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1984.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gerasa Nymphaeum
    A monumental fountain dating to the second century CE at Gerasa (modern Jerash in Jordan).
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Ghubayrā
    Town in southern Iran built on a burial site used in the 3rd-4th millennia BCE and the Sasanian period. The town on the site was inhabited from from the 10th-14th century.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ghuzza Ptolemaic Settlement
    A settlement in Egypt's eastern desert, associated with gold-mining and gold-washing during the Ptolemaic and Roman periods.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Ghuzza Roman Fort
    A roman-era fort at Al-Ghuzza in Egypt's eastern desert.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Gialia Monastery
    The Gialia Monastery is a ruined medieval Georgian Orthodox monastery located in the village of Gialia, Paphos District, northwestern Cyprus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Giants' grave of Sa Dom'è s'Orcu (Quartucciu)
    A "Giant's tomb" of the fourteenth and thirteenth centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gioiosa Guardia
    An ancient city in Sicily that was founded during the reign of Frederick III of Aragon and is located on Mount Meliuso in Sicily.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Giricano
    Modern Giricano, site of the ancient Dunnu-ša-Uzībiis, is located in the Upper Tigris region of south-eastern Turkey, in the province of Diyarbakir, about 11 km southeast of modern Bismil, ca. 5 km northwest of Ziyaret Tepe, on the north bank of the Tigris River.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Girsu Bridge
    The archaeological site of the Girsu Bridge, located in modern Iraq's Dhi Qar governorate, was identified in 1920 and has been dated to the third millennium BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Giššu Gate
    The Neo-Babylonian kings Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. That mudbrick wall is reported to have had 120 towers and 5 entrances, including the Giššu Gate. This access point to the city was probably located on the southeastern stretch of the wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Giulianello
    The site of a minor ancient center of southern Latium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gladiatorial School
    The gladiatorial school of Carnuntum was located to the west of the amphitheater.
    Creators: Sarah Bond; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gladiators' barracks
    A training ground for gladiators in Pompeii noted for the more than 100 inscriptions connected to gladiating. (V, 5, 3)
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Gol Mod-2
    Cemetery site in Arkhangai Province, Mongolia containing 98 terrace tombs associated with the Xiongnu culture.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Göltepe
    Archaeological site in the Central Taurus Mountains dated to the early Bronze Age. The Göltepe hill contains traces of a village associated with the nearby mine site of Kestel.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Göreme National Park and the Rock Sites of Cappadocia
    A natural erosional landscape within which a number of rupestral sanctuaries are located, dating as early as the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gough's Cave
    Gough's Cave is located in Cheddar Gorge. A hominin fossil commonly referred to as "Cheddar Man" was discovered in the cave in 1903.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gourimadi Prehistoric Settlement
    Survey and site excavation have provided evidence for a likely prehistoric settlement (possibly fortified) on the Gourimadi hill in the Katsaronio plain in the Karystia, southern Euboea, Greece.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Gournes Cemetery
    Early Minoan cemetery located in Gournes, Crete, containing 37 tombs. The site was largely destroyed by the installation of irrigation pipes and the building of the Hellenic Centre for Marine Research and its associated parking lot.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gövelek
    Gövelek is a village situated 27 km to the east of Van in the southeast of Turkey. Here the upper part of a stela with an inscription of Rusa, son of Erimena (presumably last quarter of 8th century BCE) was found. It reports his military success and describes deportations from the city Ṭušpa, the building of the city Rusaḫinili, and the creation of an artificial lake called "Lake of Rusa". The lake was supposed to ensure the water supply for the capital Ṭušpa (modern Van Kalesi), a function it still performs today. The lower part of the stela has been found at the shore of the lake.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Governor's Palace at Kalhu
    This beautifully-decorated Assyrian palace is located just north of the Nabû temple Ezida, in the southeast quarter of the citadel of Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud). The building likely served as the office and/or residence of several important individuals in the administration of the Assyrian Empire, probably including the governor of Kalhu. Numerous cuneiform tablets were discovered in three rooms north of the central courtyard. Because many of those Akkadian texts relate to the activities of several governors, British excavators in the 1950s dubbed the building the "Governor's Palace."
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Graeco-Roman theater at Marina di Gioiosa Ionica
    A second-century B.C. theater that represents a point of architectural transition from the Greek-style theater building to the Roman typology.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Graecostadium
    Located in Regio VIII of the ancient city of Rome, Graecostadium refers to a place that is either an area that is enclosed by walls or a set of buildings. This seems to have been a large area in any case. The Graecostadium is damaged by fire and subsequently restored under Antoninus Pius. Ths place burned again during the reign of Carinus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gran Carro (Bolsena)
    A Proto-Villanovan settlement at Lake Bolsena. Discovered in 1959, this protohistoric settlement was situated on an island that is now submerged in the waters of the lake.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grandford
    The remains of a Romano-British settlement at Grandford, Cambridgeshire, were identified by aerial photography. The site lies northwest of the modern town of March and likely lay along the Roman road conventionally known as the Fen Causeway that began at the Roman fort of Longthorpe. The site's extent may have been on the order of 40 acres.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grand Lagneux Roman Bath
    At Grand Lagneux, a small village in the French commune of Yenne, a rescue excavation in 2020 revealed part of a Roman-era bathing establishment. The excavated site is now buried under a modern home. This find constitutes another possible locality in the commune for attested ancient name "Etanna".
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Grand mausolée des Flavii
    A mausoleum near Cillium dates to the second century CE. Tiberius Flavius Secundus built the family tomb, dedicating it to his father, and inscribing two poetic texts totaling some 110 lines on its facade. Located in what is now Kasserine, Tunisia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Gran Sasso d'Italia
    The Gran Sasso d'Italia is a mountain located in the Abruzzo region of central Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Great Dam of Ma'rib
    The Great Dam of Ma'rib, which spanned the gorge of the Wâdî Dhana and fed a massive irrigation system dependent on the seasonal flooding (sayl) of the wadi, dates originally to the eighth century BCE and was connected with the Sabaean and Himyarite kingdoms around the ancient city of Ma'rib in modern Yemen. It is reported to have failed catastrophically in the 8th century CE, leading to the collapse of irrigation-dependent agriculture and a mass depopulation of the area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Jérémie Schiettecatte; Tom Elliott
  • Great Dolmen of Comenda da Igreja
    A megalithic dolmen of the fourth to third millennia BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Great Tey
    A Romano-British villa complex identified by ploughing in the 1950s.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Great Ziggurat of Aššur at Assur
    From the first half of the second millennium BC until 614 BC, there was a ziggurat, a temple-tower, at Assur dedicated to the god Aššur (and his manifestation as the god Enlil). This sacred building, which went by the Sumerian name Earattakišarra (”House, Mountain/Noblest of the Universe”) in the first millennium BC and referred to as the “great ziggurat” in Middle Assyrian royal inscriptions, was likely founded by the Old Assyrian ruler Šamšī-Adad I (ca. 1808–1776 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Great Zimbabwe
    Great Zimbabwe was the capital of the Queen of Sheba, according to legend. The city, covering ca. 80 hectares, belongs to the Bantu civilization of the Shona culture and dates between the eleventh and fifteenth centuries. It was an important trading center.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Greek theater at Alabanda
    The Greek theater at Alabanda dates to the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Greek theater of Tyndaris
    The Greek theater of Tyndaris dates originally to the fourth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Greppe S . Angelo necropolis
    A rock-cut necropolis of Caere noted as the findspot of the Sarpedon krater of the artists Euphronios.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grimde
    Grimde is the site of three Gallo-Roman tumuli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grimsbury Castle
    Grimsbury Castle is the site of an Iron Age hill fort in Berkshire, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Grociana piccola
    A Roman fortification on the modern Mt. Grociana piccola, east of Trieste. The structure seems to date to the late second and early first centuries BCE, and may have been part of a military fortification network in the area that developed over time.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Grotta Corbeddu
    A cave near Oliena, Sardinia, where evidence for the earliest human occupation of the island of Sardinia has been recovered.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotta dell'Uzzo
    The Grotta dell'Uzzo is an important archaeological site in Sicily with traces of human settlement beginning 10,000 years BP.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Grotta di Cocceio
    A 1-km long ancient tunnel connecting Lake Avernus with Cumae. It dates ca. 38-36 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotta di Seiano
    "Grotta di Seiano" or "Cave of Sejanus" refers to a subterranean tunnel dating to the early Roman Imperial period that was excavated into the volcanic tuff. It connected the area of what is now modern Bagnoli and the Campi Flegrei with the Gaiola Valley. Its construction is often attributed to Lucius Cocceius. It is now part of the Pausilypon Archaeological Park.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotta Mora Cavorso
    Cave site in the Aniene Valley in central Italy with signs of human activity from the Early Neolithic period to the early Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Grotta Paglicci
    The Paglicci cave or Grotta Paglicci is located near Rignano Garganico, Apulia, in southern Italy. Discovered in the 1950s, the cave is an important archaeological site documenting life in the Paleolithic period. In addition to artifact finds and zooarchaeological information, the cave provides evidence of the harvesting of wild oats ca. 36,000 BCE. The cave also includes Paleolithic mural art.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotta Porciosa, Borghetto
    Grotta Porciosa, near Borghetto, was the site of a small but prosperous settlement in the Ager Faliscus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotta Scaloria
    A cavern discovered in 1931 near Manfredonia with evidence for ritual activity dating to the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotte di Pertosa
    The Pertosa Caves, a system of karst caves located in the comune of Pertosa, province of Salerno, Campania, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grotte di Seiano a Pietramelara
    A ruined, terraced megalithic complex covering an area of some 900 square meters. The complex likely dates to the second century B.C. and was destroyed in the time of Sulla. The complex is interpreted as a Samnite sanctuary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Grove of Asklepios at Kos
    Mentioned in ancient sources, this sacred grove in the ancient sanctuary of Asklepios located on the Aegean island of Kos cannot be precisely located today.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • G Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Guglia di Marcello
    The so-called "Guglia di Marcello" or "Aguglia d'Agosta" is a Roman funerary monument located along the ancient via Pompei that once connected Syracuse and Messina. It dates to the period from the first century B.C. to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Güglingen Mithraeum
    A sanctuary dedicated to Mithras located near modern Heilbronn, Germany, in use during the second-third centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Gula temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the goddess Gula. Although its location is not known, the Gula temple at Kalhu is thought to have been part of the Ninurta temple complex (in the northwest corner of the citadel), east of the Šarrat-niphi temple and north of the Kidmuri temple.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gul Khanan Murdah
    Iron Age cemetery site located west of modern Eyvanki in Iran.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Gurban Tepe/Karacamirli
    Archaelolgical site in Azerbaijan containing the remains of an Achaemenid palatial structure. The primary occupation of the site is dated from ca. 600 BCE-330 CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Guzana Archive 1
    Approximately 85 clay tablets were discovered in the eastern room of a house adjoining the tarrace of the northeastern palace of Guzana. The texts were found in a secondary context, probably as fill, and belonged to Mannu-ki-Aššur, Assyrian governor in Guzana during the first quarter of the 8th century BC. The archive consists of letters to and from the governor, as well as administrative lists concerning persons, animals, and objects.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Guzana Archive 2
    Inside a clay pot, found in a private house east of the citadel gate of Guzana, excavators discovered the private archive of a man with an Aramaic name, Il-manani, dating to the last years of the Assyrian Empire. The archive consists of five Aramaic dockets concerning loans of barley, previously attached to perishable material, and five clay tablets written in Assyrian cuneiform, specifically three loan documents, one purchase document concerning a slave, and one legal settlement.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Güzelhisar
    Mosque in the village of Güzelhisar/Avnik where a Urartian inscription was found in 1965.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Gymnasium at Corinth
    The Gymnasium of the Roman period at Corinth was excavated by the University of Texas and the American School of Classical Studies beginning in 1965. It is possible that Hellenistic and Classical phases preceded the Roman phase, although evidence is scanty.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • HaBesor Stream
    The largest stream of the southern Negev, the HaBesor Stream (Hebrew: נחל הבשור‎, Nahal HaBesor) is a wadi that flows from Mount Boker into the Mediterranean Sea near Al-Zahra in the Gaza Strip, where it is known as the Wadi Ghazzeh.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hajar Bin Ḥumeid
    Tell in modern Yemen shaped roughly like an oval. The settlement on the mound was settled around the 11th century BCE and survived for 1400-1500 years.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Hambledon Hill
    Hambledon Hill is a prehistoric hill fort in Dorset, England, with occupation beginning in the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Handere bridge
    A bridge on the road from to Egin and Harput.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Harilaq
    A Late Roman fortified settlement located in the modern Republic of Kosovo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Haselburg
    A second century AD Roman villa estate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hassocks
    Located in West Sussex, Hassocks is thought to be the site of a Roman settlement, on the basis of funerary evidence discovered in the area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Hayling Island Saxon Settlement
    Between ca. 570-900 CE (radio-carbon dates), a Saxon-era settlement and possible ritual site flourished on and around the location of an earlier Iron-Age/Roman sanctuary in the northern part of modern Hayling Island (borough of Havant, Hampshire, England).
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Hazine Piri Kapısı
    Hazine Piri Kapısı is the Turkish name for a rock niche bearing an inscription of the Urartian king Išpuini, son of Sarduri I (9th century BCE). It is situated on an isolated rock near modern Elmalı (Zivistan) and Edremit.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors:
  • Healam Bridge Roman Fort
    The site of a Roman fort and an associated vicus along Dere Street, now buried and bisected by the modern A1.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Hedemünden
    An early Imperial fort located on the river Werra.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Hedemünden
    An early Roman fort located on the river Werra.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hellenistic Balaneion, Amathous
    A circular public bath building dating to the Hellenistic period in the agora of Amathous.
    Creators: David Rothfels; Wenqian Liu
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Hellenistic-Roman theater at Sarno
    An ancient theater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Helorine Hodos
    An ancient road of Sicily linking Syracuse and Helorus.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Henchir Hnich
    Discovered in 2013, this site in the modern Oued Ellouz sector of Tunisia lies 3.5km west of ancient Musti (modern Henchir Mest). Excavators interpret the site as a rural settlement of an imperial estate. The only known copy of an inscribed "lex de agris rudibus" of the emperor Hadrian was discovered here (unpublished as of January 2022).
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Hengistbury Head
    Hengistbury Head, formerly Christchurch Head, is a headland that projects into the English Channel between Bournemouth and Mudeford in the county of Dorset. It is a protected heritage landscape with human activity reaching back to the Upper Paleolithic.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Herculaneum Gate
    A city gate of Pompeii that dates to the time of Sulla.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hercules Sullanus
    Either a statue or shrine of Hercules located in Regio V somewhere east of the Piazza Vittorio Emanuele, perhaps close to the nymphaeum known as the Temple of Minerva Medica. Whether the site was, in fact, connected to Lucius Cornelius Sulla is debated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hermeskeil Roman Camp
    A late-Republican Roman army camp, located on the eastern outskirts of modern Hermeskeil in the German county of Trier-Saarburg (Rheinland-Pfalz). The site is not visible today.
    Creators: C. Haselgrove; J. Kunow
    Contributors: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
  • Hermiones
    One of the three main cultural divisions of ancient Germanic peoples, according to Tacitus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hexagonal mausoleum
    A hexagonal tomb, perhaps that of a Roman centurion, dating to the late second or early third century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hexamilion wall
    The Hexamilion wall is an ancient defensive wall built across the Isthmus of Corinth that protected the only land route into the Peloponnese from mainland Greece.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss
  • Hilakku (region)
    Hilakku is a mountainous region near Tabālu and Que in the Cilician plain. Its exact location is still debated among scholars. Nevertheless, Hilakku has been tentatively identified as being in the area of Bolkar Dağları or in that of Göksu-Tal, in the western part of Cilicia, that is, in the classical Cilicia Tracheia/Cilicia Aspera.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hippagreta
    An ancient city of north Africa described by Appian; while its precise location is now unknown, Appian locates it between Carthage and Utica and attributes its foundation to Agathocles.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Hod Hill
    Hod Hill is the site of a large, rectangular Iron Age hill-fort. After the Roman conquest, Romans occupied the hill-fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Holme Roman temporary camp
    A Roman marching camp covering 9.3 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Honos et Virtus, Aedes
    The Temple of Honour and Virtue (aedes Honoris et Virtutis) was a double temple founded by Q. Fabius Maximus Verrucosus in 234 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hoogeloon Roman villa
    Remains of a Roman villa were identified to the east of the Dutch village of Hoogeloon in the commune of Bladel, in North Brabant.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ḥorbat 'Uẓa
    Settlement east of Acre with remains from the Neolithic through the 12th century. The site was destroyed to make a highway in 1991.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Horologium Augusti
    The Horologium Augusti or Solarium Augusti was an ancient monument of the Campus Martius built during the reign of Augustus. In theory, it functioned as a giant solar marker. An obelisk relocated to Rome from Heliopolis served as the gnomon. The obelisk today stands in the Piazza di Monte Citorio.
    Creators: Echo Smith; Edward Keogh; Sara Hales
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Horrea Galbana
    Horrea (warehouses) located between the southern part of the Aventine Hill and Monte Testaccio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Horti Lamiani
    Gardens on the Esquiline Hill that passed into the control of the Iulio-Claudian family from the consul Lucius Aelius Lamia. As imperial property, the gardens were adorned with opulent display architecture and sculpture.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Horti Largiani
    Gardens that were located in regio VII, but whose precise location is uncertain. They could have been in the Campus Martius or on the slopes of the Pincian Hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Horti Liciniani
    A complex of elite gardens on the Esquiline Hill connected to the gens Licinia. The gardens were located between the via Labicana and via Praenestina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Horti Maiani
    An urban garden of imperial Rome located on the summit of the Esquiline Hill. Based on an inscription dating to the reign of Claudius, it is believed that these gardens were administered by the same magistrate in charge of the Horti Lamiani, an official with the title "procurator hortorum Maianorum et Lamianorum".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Horti Sallustiani
    The gardens of Sallust in Regio VI of the ancient city of Rome
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Horti Spei Veteris
    Public gardens of the Esquiline Hill (Regio V).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ḥorvat Radum
    Small Iron Age fortress in the Northern Negev with a surrounding wall and three buildings making up the fortress.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Horvat Shema'
    Ancient synagogue site and burial place of Rabbi Shamai just south of Meron, Israel. The site was occupied in the early 1st century BCE, again from the late 2nd to the late 3rd, from the early 4th century to the mid-7th century, from this point until the mid-9th century, and finally from the mid-12th century until the late-13th century.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Ḥorvat ʻUza
    Iron Age fortress in the Northern Negev Desert with a solid wall and ten towers. Inside the fortress are building complexes with streets between them.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hot Baths
    Remains of a large building and baths uncovered between Bilbury Lane and Lower Borough Walls, beneath what is now known as the Gainsborough Spa in Aquae Sulis, modern-day Bath.
    Creators: Syvanne Aloni
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Hottomont tumulus
    A Gallo-Roman tumulus near Ramillies in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House H2-D
    Private house located in Block H2 of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House J1-A
    Remains of a large house with peristyle located within the intramuros military sector of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House K5-A
    Private house converted later into the barracks of K5.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House L7-H
    Private house at Dura-Europos later adapted for use as synagogue phase 1.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • House L7-H
    Private house later adapted for use as synagogue phase 1.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House M8-A
    Private house preceeding the Christian church.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House of Amor and Psyche
    A domus in Ostia Antica on the Via del Tempio d’Ercole, between the Via della Foce to the south and the Tiber to the north. Installed in late antiquity, and incorporating large parts of a preexisting tenement, this house had a wide central corridor, which opened through an arcade onto a small garden (viridarium) backed by a nymphaeum.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Augustus
    An elite domus located at the southwest corner of the Palatine Hill that is identified as the house lived in by the Roman emperor Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • House of Aulus Umbricius Scaurus
    The House of Aulus Umbricius Scaurus (Regio VII, Insula 16, entrances 12-15) is considered to be the residence and trading center of the gens Umbricia, a Pompeian family involved in producing and selling garum. The house itself is described as a "Samnite-type" house and in the first century B.C. it was most likely owned by the Samnite military commander Maras Spurnius who resisted the invasion of Sulla.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of Dionysos at Paphos
    Roman villa at Nea Paphos on Cyprus containing extensive mosaic floors.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • House of Flavius Germanus
    Roman Peristyle House with interior garden and pool.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Hylas at Italica
    Residence named for a mosaic floor with an emblem showing Hylas carried off by the nymphs. The mosaic has been removed to the Archaeological Museum in Sevilla.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of Iphigeneia
    The House of Pinarius Cerialis and Cassia or Casa dell’orefice or Casa di Ifigenia (III, 4, b).
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Lucius Cornelius Diadumenus
    The House of Lucius Cornelius Diadumenus (VII, 12, 26) is a small domus noted for its wall paintings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of Marcus Lucretius
    The House of Marcus Lucretius was excavated in 1846 and 1851.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House of Messius Ampliatus
    A Pompeian domus excavated in 1916, 1918, and 1921. (II.2.4).
    Creators: Yuyao Liu
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of Minucius
    The so-called House of Minucius is located in Regio I of the city of Pompeii at the intersection of Vicolo del Menandro and Vicolo del Citarista. It is noted for two plastered benches flanking the fauces as well as painted electoral graffiti.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of M. Spurius Saturninus and D. Volcius Modestus
    A domus in Pompeii that was built using Sarno limestone. The house was excavated in 1760, 1841, and 1910 and re-examined in 2007 and 2010. The site was bombed World War Two (13 September 1943).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of N. Popidius Priscus
    A Pompeian domus that, upon excavation, was found to have a large supply of colored marble.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House of Serenos at Trimithis
    Building B1 of Area 2.1 at Trimithis (Amheida) is a domus with an annexed stable dated to the 4th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Actors
    A Roman domus in in Pompeii overlooking the via Stabiana, with shops on both sides of the entrance. The site was excavated in 1872 and bombed in 1943. Located at I,2,6.
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri; Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Birds at Italica
    Peristyle house at Italica, named for the bird-themed mosaic at the center.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of the Botanical Garden
    The site of a domus (VIII.5.38) in Regio VIII where modern botanical gardens of the ancient Vesuvian flora present in Pompeii are maintained.
    Creators: Athanasia Varveri
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Columns
    Roman Peristyle House with interior garden and fountain.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Deep Trench at Italica
    House inside the city wall, located on a street that leads directly onto the east end of the Traianeum, the great temple erected in honor of the emperor Trajan.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of the Ephebe
    Roman Peristyle House with interior garden and pool.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Faun
    A large private residence constructed ca. 180 BCE in Pompeii (VI.12.2). Its modern name derives from bronze statue of a faun placed in its impluvium. The house also contained the Alexander Mosaic, a large-scale depiction of the Battle of Issus.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Fishes
    A domus in Ostia Antica, whose two building phases have been dated, respectively, to the middle and last quarter of the third century CE.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Four Styles
    The House of the Four Styles or Casa dei Quattro Stili (I.8.17) is noted for having examples of all four style of Pompeian wall paintings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of the Labors of Hercules
    Roman Peristyle House with interior garden and fountain.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the masks, Hadrumetum
    An elite house in Hadrumetum known especially for its program of polychromatic mosaics dating to the third century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of the Ocean Gods
    Large house in Saint-Romain-En-Gaul, France, probably belonging to a wealthy merchant, built around 50 CE and abandoned in the middle of the 3rd century CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Red Walls
    A domus excavated in 1832 and 1882. It is noted for its late-stage wall decoations that may call upon public monuments for inspiration.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • House of the Rhodian Peristyle at Italica
    Roman house at Italica, also known as the House of the Rhodian Patio. Constructed on a slope, the house has a multileveled patio, with sections of different heights connected by stairs.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of the Scattered Branches and Flowers
    According to Leveau (1982), this is a vast domus identified in 1963-1964, located on the Berbache property to the south-east of the coastal plain. The structure measured at least 30 by 60 meters but excavations were not carried to completion.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Skeleton
    The so-called "House of the Skeleton" was constructed in the early first century BCE in the Roman colony of Cosa. It stands an example of the domestic architecture of the Late Roman Republic.
    Creators: Celia Garb; George Crooks
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • House of the Sundial at Baelo
    House at Baelo Claudia located across the colonnaded street from the House of the West.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the Thunderbolt
    A Vespasianic domus in Ostia Antica, built c. 70-75 CE, situated outside Porta Marina, and north of the continuation of the Decumanus Maximus. It had a slightly concave façade, comprising six shops and an entrance corridor leading to an interior peristyle garden.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors:
  • House of the Triclinium at Italica
    House of the Triclinium is located in the area southeast of the House of Hylas.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of the Two Pools
    According to Leveau (1982), the so-called "House of the Two Pools" is located to the south of the Rivet barracks. This was a large peristyle-type domus that included two nymphaea. The latter were published by Cumont and Stern.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House of the West at Baelo
    Roman domus at Baelo Claudia, also known as House no. 1.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • House of Venus
    The so-called House of Venus numbered among the most opulent houses of Volubilis. It possesses a private bath and a richly decorated interior.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • House X7-A
    Private house later converted for military use as X7 Barracks.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • House X7-B
    Private house later converted for military use as X7 Barracks.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • H Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Humayma Roman Fort
    A Trajanic fort located at Hawara (modern Humayma in southern Jordan).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Huzirina Archive 1
    In Huzirina, about 400 clay tablets were discovered in a secondary position outside a private house with a central courtyard in area F. Likely, this library was previously located in the private house since a similar type of clay tablet was also found in the central courtyard. The library dates from 718 BC to the end of the Assyrian Empire and belonged to a family of šangû-priests: Qurdi-Nergal, his son Mušallim-Baba and others. The library consists of incantations, incantation rituals, medical texts, prayers, hymns and lexical lists, including god-lists.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • Hyctanis (river)
    A river in Carmania mentioned by both Pliny and Strabo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Hypogeum of the Aurelii
    A third century AD hypogeum tomb on the Esquiline hill in Rome with both pagan and Paleochristian iconography.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Hypogeum of Trebius Giustus
    A tomb of the fourth century A.D. located on the Via Latina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ianus Augustus
    The remains of a Roman arch may mark the boundary between the Roman provinces of Hispania Baetica and Hispania Tarraconensis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ibis Nome
    15th Lower Egyptian Nome in the Pharaonic period, dedicated to the god Thoth and with its capital at Hermopolis. The site was called Djeḥuti/Tehut in Ancient Egyptian. This nome was incorporated into the Mendesios Nome during the Ptolemaic reforms of the 4th century BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Ikh Khatuu
    Area in the Altai region of extreme western Mongolia containing a number of burials and other structures dated from the Bronze Age and the Turkic Period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ilgynly-Depe
    Chalcolithic settlement near Chaacha, Turkmenistan. This site was initially settled in the 5th millennium, flourished in the mid-4th, and was subsequently abandoned.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Ilıca (Ayas: cemetery)
    Cemetery site northwest of Ankara containing burials dated to the Hittite period (16th century BCE). The modern neighborhood of Ilıca is in the Ayas district of Turkey's Ankara province.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ilıpınar Tumulus
    Tumulus near İznik Lake in Anatolia with Neolithic, Late Chalcolithic, Early Bronze Age, and Early Byzantine remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Illeta dels Banyets
    A coastal site occupied from the late third millennium B.C. onwards.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss; Tom Elliott
  • Il Tondo
    A first century AD Roman amphitheater located in Latium near Zagorolo, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Imgur-Enlil Archive 1
    The Mamu temple of Imgur-Enlil was located on the northeastern side of the citadel. In Room 8, behind the secondary cella, an archive of 40 clay tablets, belonging to Šumma-ilu and Mamu-iqbi, was discovered. While most texts date to the first half of the 7th century, three texts are older – dating from 734 to 710 BC. The archive consists of debt-notes, leases, one purchase agreement and other legal documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Poppy Tushingham
  • I Morroni
    Morroni dei Marsi, the remains of two mausolea dating to the Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ince fortlet
    A double-ditched enclosure site located to the north of the modern village of Ince (Cheshire, England) has been identified as a Roman fortlet. The enclosure covers some 0.48 ha and was first identified via crop marks seen in aerial photographs in 1994.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Insula Batavorum
    Both Iulius Caesar and Tacitus refer to the "Island of the Batavi", once located at a split in the Rhine and framed by the Waal river on the one hand and the Lower Rhine on the other. This area seems to correspond roughly to the modern Betuwe in the Netherlands.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brian Turner; Tom Elliott
  • Insula dei Dipinti
    A Hadrianic insula in Ostia Antica between the north wall of the castrum and the Tiber, comprising the houses of Jove and Ganymede, of the Infant Bacchus, and of the Paintings, arranged according to an L-shaped plan. Its façade faced onto two streets, forming a corner, while its inner sides looked out onto a large garden, without porticoes.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Insula Volusiana
    The Insula Volusiana in the Forum Boarium is an archaeological site with evidence for multiphase occupation, including craftworking evidence from the fifth and sixth centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Iovis Tifatinus
    A sanctuary sacred to Jupiter located on the western slopes of Tifata Mons (Monte Tifata).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ipogeo dei Cristallini
    A hypogeum tomb of the Hellenistic period in Neapolis (now Naples, Italy).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • `Iraq al Amir
    A multi-period settlement mound located 18 km west of Amman, Jordan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Is Calas menhir
    A menhir located near the Is Calas nuragic complex near Monte Nai, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Isera
    A Roman villa located in the Alto-Adige region of Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ishān Dulaiyhim
    Mound, sometimes associated with the ancient city Tummal, which is located in the modern Afak subdistrict of Iraq's Al-Qādisiyyah governorate.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ishkaft Salmān
    Location for Elamite rock-cut reliefs.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Ishtar Temple at Mari
    Temple dedicated to the goddess Ishtar located in the western section of the city of Mari.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Iskandar Tepa
    A settlement site in modern Uzbekistan's Pamir-Alay mountain range dating probably between the second century BCE and the first century CE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Isola Conversina
    The ruined tower of Isola Conversina, also known as Torre della Stroppa, is located on a tuff ridge with steep margins that has likely been inhabited since the Bronze Age. This hill is located along the line of the Via Amerina. The present ruined castle dates to the Medieval period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Isole della Marmorata
    The Isole della Marmorata off the coast of Sardinia provided the grey granite (also known as granito della Sardegna) that was exported to Rome during the Imperial period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Issyk kurgan field
    Saka burial ground in modern Issyk, Kazakhstan, containing over 40 kurgans dated from the 4th-3rd centuries BCE. The primary kurgan contained the burial of a richly-dressed individual now known as the "Golden Man."
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ištar Gate
    The Ištar Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Ištar-mušammeḫat-nišīšu ("The Goddess Ištar Is the One Who Makes Its People Flourish"), is the sixth of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the west-facing entrances to the city, but its precise location is uncertain.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • I Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Italia, Regio II
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Apulia and Calabria. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Italia, Regio IV
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Samnium. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Italia, Regio IX
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Liguria. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Italia, Regio VII
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Etruria. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Italia, Regio VIII
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Aemilia. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Italia, Regio X
    One of the administrative regions from Augustus's division of Italy, comprising Venetia and Histria. Described by Pliny the Elder in Book III of his Natural History.
    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Iunonis Curritis Lucus
    The sacred 'Grove of Iuno Curritis' located in Falerii Veteres.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Iuppiter Arborator
    A place included in Regio XI of the Regionary Catalogues, this may have been a shrine on the spina of the Circus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Īzah
    Central mound of the modern town of Īzah where artifacts of Elamite date were found in excavations 1976.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Izola
    The remains of a Roman villa maritima.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • J1 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks south of House J1-A in Block J1 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J2 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block J2 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J3 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block J3 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J4 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block J4 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J6 Barracks
    Military barracks in the southern part of Block J6 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J7 Barracks
    Military barracks reworked from private houses in Block J7 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • J8 Barracks
    Unexcavated military barracks reworked from private houses in Block J8 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Jaén
    A Spanish city located in Andalusia that once belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as Jaén.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Jamjamāl
    Mound on which surface cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Jandial Temple
    Jandial is the site of a semi-Classical temple of Ionic Greek design constructed in the first or second centuries BCE. It is the farthest east of any known Hellenic temple.
    Creators: Elin Hansen; Maia Shideler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Jarmo
    A Neolithic agricultural community located in Iraq, the remains of Jarmo date ca. 7090 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Javangaleh
    Javangaleh is a modern settlement situated near Ajabšir (Maragheh) in the East Azerbaijan Province in the northwest of Iran. Here a rock inscription of Argišti I (eighth century BCE) was found which reports his victory over the land Mana (CTU I A 8-13).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Jazirat Sabuniya (island)
    An island of the Socotra archipelago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Jebel Khalid
    Hellenistic settlement constructed in the early 3rd century BCE and abandoned in the 70s BCE. Part of the site seems to have been used later as a Roman camp or fort.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Jebel Qa'aqir
    Settlement south of the village of Khirbet el-Qom in the West Bank with Early Bronze Age remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Jemelle
    A large Gallo-Roman villa located in what is now Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • J Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Jura (island)
    One of the Inner Hebrides islands of Scotland with evidence of human habitation stretching back to the Mesolithic period. It is one possible identification for an ancient "Riginia" island mentioned in ancient sources.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • K3 Barracks
    Military barracks located north of the camp wall in the northern part of Block K3 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • K5 Barracks
    Military barracks located north of the camp wall in the northern part of Block K5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • K7 Barracks
    Military barracks located north of the camp wall in the northern part of Block K7 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ka-dingirra
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Ka-dingirra was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained four temples. Ka-dingirra is also a name of Babylon itself.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Kadmat Island
    Kadmat Island, also known as Cardamom Island, belongs to the Amindivi Subgroup of islands of the Lakshadweep archipelago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 1
    Two eighth-century-B.C. archives were excavated in Fort Shalmaneser, a building complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu. One archive was located in Rooms NE 47–50 at the northern side of the northeast courtyard. It consists of about eighty unsealed administrative texts, including twenty-two horse lists and forty-eight wine lists. A few clay tablets were also found in other rooms nearby.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 10
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). Inside the well of Room AB, British excavators found the leaves of approximately thirty ivory and wooden writing boards, thus constituting the largest and best-preserved discovery of writing boards in Mesopotamia. According to the Akkadian text preserved on one of the objects, some of the writing boards contain copies of the astrological series Enūma Anu Enlil belonging to “the palace of Sargon (II).”
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 11
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). The archive found in Rooms ZT 13–17 was written between 687 BC and 614 BC, thus postdating this move. This repository contained about sixty clay tablets, specifically loan documents, the sale of slaves and land, juridical texts, marriage contracts, and administrative lists.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 12
    An archive repository was discovered in Rooms K, M, and S of the Governor's Palace at Kalhu. This group of 217 clay tablets belong to five successive governors of the city and date from 835 BC to 710 BC. Apart from one literary text and a perfume recipe, the tablets discovered in Rooms K and M are generally legal documents, whereas the tablets in Room S are administrative texts. and letters (usually addressed to the governors).
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
  • Kalhu Archive 13
    In Room 8 (the throne room) of the Burnt Palace, as well as in adjoining rooms, British excavators found letters addressed to and from the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (721–705 BC).
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Kalhu Archive 14
    The remains of a library containing about 280 clay tablets were found in and around Room NT12 the Nabû Temple (Ezida). These text date from 800 BC to 614 BC. The majority of the texts assigned to this archive repository were discovered in Room NT12 and the adjoining courtyard. Some texts, including fragments of seven wooden and ivory writing boards, were found in Rooms NT13 and NT14. This Neo-Assyrian ‘library’ house omen texts (79 tablets), incantation and medical texts (75 tablets), lexical lists (37 tablets), as well as some administrative texts, epics, hemerological texts, hymns, prayers, rituals, and royal inscriptions.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
  • Kalhu Archive 15
    British excavators found fragments of at least eight or nine large clay tablets in the Throne Room of the Nabû Temple (Ezida). These now-fragmentarily-preserved tablets, all of which date to 672 BC, contain copies of treaties that seventh-century-BC Assyrian king Esarhaddon (r. 680–669 BC) made with several Median client rulers. These ‘covenant’ documents — which are often referred to as “Esarhaddon’s Succession Treaty” or “Esarhaddon’s Vassal Treaty” — were written up to ensure loyalty to Ashurbanipal, Esarhaddon’s fourth eldest son, when he ascended the Assyrian throne upon the death of his father.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
  • Kalhu Archive 16
    In Room NT16, on the southern side of the inner courtyard of the Nabû Temple (Ezida) at Kalhu, British excavators found twenty-one cuneiform clay dockets; these date from 699 to 652 BC. The texts in this archival repository are principal corn loan documents. Some might have been attached to Aramaic texts that were written on perishable materials, such as papyrus.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 17
    Among private houses in the north-east of the citadel, in Room 19 of House III, British excavators found forty-seven clay tablets, including two dockets, which might have been once attached to Aramaic texts written on perishable material (e.g., papyrus). This private archive belonged to the eunuch Šamaš-šarru-uṣur and a few other influential men. While most of the texts are loans of silver, corn, or birds, eleven of the texts are sale documents. There is also a list of silver and birds connected to different citizens of Kalhu.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 2
    Two eighth-century-B.C. archives were excavated in Fort Shalmaneser, a building complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu. Eleven tablets were found in Room SW 6, a wine store. The archive contains wine lists, as well as notes about the delivery of wine to the palace.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 3
    Three seventh-century-B.C. archives were excavated in Fort Shalmaneser, a building complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu. In the northern corner of the south courtyard, mostly in Rooms SE 1 and SE 10, British excavators discovered the archive of the rab ēkalli (“palace manager”). The archive consists of twenty-seven tablets, most of which are sealed. These documents are concerned with the rab ēkalli’s work as manager. The sealed clay bulla were attached to wooden objects such as boxes or writing boards and secured with a string.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 4
    Three seventh-century-B.C. archives were excavated in Fort Shalmaneser, a building complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu. The archive from Rooms SE 14–15 consists of nineteen clay tablets, mostly purchase documents but also some loan documents, a release documents, a legal settlement, and a letter. One of the loan documents is written in Neo-Babylonian dialect, instead of the usual Neo-Assyrian dialect.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 5
    Three seventh-century-B.C. archives were excavated in Fort Shalmaneser, a building complex in the southeastern corner of the city Kalhu. In Room S 10, in the inner southern part of the palace, British excavators found the archive of the queen's household and of her šakintu (“woman manager”). The archive consists of eighteen clay tablets; most of the documents are sealed. The principal text categories found here are purchase documents, loans, and lawsuits.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 6
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). Four hundred clay tablets dating to the reign of Sargon II and some of his predecessors were found in Room ZT 4, on the northern side of the northernmost courtyard of the palace. That archive consists of letters to and from the Assyrian king, administrative texts, lists, short notes, records of payments, and one literary text. There were also two rows of open brick boxes in that room of the Northwest Palace; these might have been intended for the storage of clay tablets.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 7
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). A few tablets were found in Rooms ZT 30 and ZT 31, on the eastern side of the northernmost courtyard of the palace. The administrative texts found in this archive repository include lists of quantities of oil (delivered to the palace), which were presumably stored in the large jars that were also found inside both rooms.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 8
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). Fourteen clay tablets and sealings, dating from 719 to 715 BC, were found in Room HH, in the southeastern part of the palace.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu Archive 9
    Most documents found in the Northwest Palace, built by the Assyrian king Ashurnarsipal II (883–859 BC), predate the move of the new Assyrian capital to Dur-Šarrukin under Sargon II (721–705 BC). An archive repository of 180 clay tablets were found in Room 57. These texts, which date from 800 to 736 BC, are mostly sale documents; there is also a list of oxen. The older documents in the archive generally deal with the purchase of slaves and houses, whereas the younger documents record the purchase of fields, some by servants of the queen.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Kalhu ziggurat
    The temple-tower of the god Ninurta, which was started by the ninth-century-BC Assyrian ruler Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) and completed by his son and successor Shalmaneser III (r. 858–824 BC), is still the most prominent feature of Kalhu (modern Nimrud). This multi-staged ziggurat, whose remains are now a pyramid of eroding mud-brick, was constructed in the northwest corner of the citadel, next to Kalhu's principal sanctuary, the Ninurta temple.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kalmākarrah Cave
    Find place for a collection of gold and silver objects from the 1st Millenium BCE.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Kamares
    Kamares is the site of a sacred Minoan cave sanctuary of the Middle Minoan period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Kamouh el Hermel
    An ancient pyramidal monument located 6 km south of Hermel in the Baalbek-Hermel Governorate, Lebanon. The monument likely dates to the second century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kampir-Tepe
    An archaeological site located in the Surxondaryo Region of Uzbekistan, in proximity to the city of Termez. Its ancient identification is uncertain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kangurttut
    Bactrian site in southwestern Tajikistan containing a settlement and burial ground dated to the Bronze and early Iron Ages.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Kapilikaya Rock Tomb
    A rock-cut tomb dated to the second century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Karacamirli Tepe 5
