    Necropolis in western Azerbaijan containing 46 burials dated to the Late Bronze Age/early Iron Age, the Late Antique period, and the 14th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Karban-I
    Burial site in the Northern Altai region containing remains associated with the Bulan-Koby culture (2nd-5th centuries CE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kastanas
    An unnamed ancient settlement located near Kastanas in Greece's Chalkidona Municipality. This site is thought to have been first inhabited in the Early Bronze Age. Occupation continued until ca. 200 BCE, although there is an abandonment phase coinciding with the Middle Bronze Age.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kastellbad Schirenhof
    Extensive Roman bathhouse associated with the Roman fort at modern Schirenhof in the German municipality of Schwäbisch Gmünd, Baden-Württemberg.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Kastellion
    Hill in Khania, Crete that was the center of the Minoan city of Cydonia and was later a Roman acropolis.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Kástron Khóstion
    A complex of structures dating to the Greek and Roman period, with ceramic evidence of prior occupation of the vicinity, on a spur of Palióvouno, overlooking a valley leading to the bay of Saránda on the Korinthian Gulf. The excavators associate this site with the attested classical city of Khorsiai on the basis of epigraphic evidence recovered at the site.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Michael Karabogias
  • Kef Kalesi
    Kef Kalesi is an Urartian fortress near Adilcevaz in the area of Lake Van in the southeast of Turkey. According to an Urartian inscription of Rusa, son of Argišti II (7th century BCE), it was built by this very king. The inscription further mentions the foundation of a new city at this site which Rusa named "City of the God Haldi in the Land Ziuquni".
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Kelsborrow Castle
    Kelsborrow Castle is an Iron Age hill fort located in the county of Cheshire in northern England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Keressos
    A fortified outpost in Boeotia located near, and belonging to, Thespiae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Keston Roman Mausoleum
    A circular Roman mausoleum was located at the Keston Roman villa. It dates to the third century CE and is located in a cemetery to the north of the villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ketef Hinnom
    Cave tomb complex located southwest of Jerusalem containing burials dated to the 6th century BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Khalandritsa
    A fortified Mycenaean settlement occupies a hilltop near modern Khalandritsa, Greece.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kharab Sayyar
    Early Islamic town in northern Syria, inhabited during the 8th-9th centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Khar gov'
    Burial site in western Mongolia containing a stone cairn and several deer stone monuments, dated to the 8th-7th centuries BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Khentiamentiu, Temple of
    An unexcavated Old-Kingdom temple, attested by epigraphic finds at Abydos in Egypt. Its remains are presumed to underlie later Osiris sanctuary structures and part of the modern town.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Khirbet el-Mastarah
    An archaeological site located in the middle Jordan Valley in the West Bank that includes the largest known of the complex oval compound type habitation sites connected with the Israelite Settlement period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Khirbet Kūfīn
    Necropolis in the West Bank near the modern village of Beit Ummar dated to the Middle Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Khorsabad Citadel Gate A
    This decorated gate is located on the western wall of the citadel of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Citadel Gate B
    This decorated gate was the principal entrance to the citadel of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 1
    This decorated gate is the northernmost city gate of the northeast wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 2
    This undecorated gate is the southernmost city gate of the northeast wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 3
    This decorated gate is the northernmost city gate of the southeast wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 4
    This undecorated gate is the southernmost city gate of the southeast wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 5
    This undecorated gate is the southernmost city gate of the southwest wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 6
    This decorated gate is the northernmost city gate of the southwest wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Gate 7
    This undecorated gate is the southernmost city gate of the northwest wall of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon"), the capital of the Assyrian Empire constructed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Palace F
    The armory (ekal māšarti) of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad) was located in the lower city, adjacent to the southern stretch of the southwest wall. No inscriptions of the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) record the construction of "Palace F," although several objects of that ruler were discovered there.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Residence J
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) had several royal residences constructed in the citadel of his new capital, Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad). Residence J, which has constructed on the western side of the citadel, is presumed to have been for one of the highest officials of the Assyrian Empire. Since no inscriptions were discovered in the ruins of the building, the owner/principal occupant of the this Assyrian palace is not known.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Khorsabad Residence K
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) had several royal residences constructed in the citadel of his new capital, Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad). Residence K, which has constructed on the western side of the citadel, is presumed to have been for one of the highest officials of the Assyrian Empire, possibly even Sargon’s heir designate Sennacherib.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Residence L
    The residence of Sîn-aḫu-uṣur, brother of the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) and grand vizier of the Assyrian Empire, was constructed in the citadel of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), near the royal palace Egalgabarinutukua ("Palace That Has No Equal"). "Residence L" was largest of the four royal residences (J, K, L, and M) built in Dūr-Šarrukīn's citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad Residence M
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) had several royal residences constructed in the citadel of his new capital, Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad). Residence M, which has constructed on the western side of the citadel, is presumed to have been for one of the highest officials of the Assyrian Empire. Since no inscriptions were discovered in the ruins of the building, the owner/principal occupant of the this Assyrian palace is not known.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khorsabad ziggurat
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) had a temple-tower built on the palace terrace of his new capital, Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad). The ziggurat was located at the northern end of the temple sector, which was accessible from Sargon’s palace, through the Courtyard XV.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Khumara Hillfort
    Fortified site in the North Caucasus constructed in the Early Medieval Period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Khurha
    A partially-excavated complex near modern Qum in Iran. The site was possibly a sanctuary and likely dates to the Seleucid age. There is some evidence that the site continued in use into the Parthian period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Kidmuri temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the divine Kidmuri (probably a collective name for a group of gods).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • King's Gate
    The King's Gate is one of Babylon's eight city gates and it is situated on the western side of the inner city, directly west of the nu-x-ù quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Kings Weston Roman Villa
    A Roman villa near Lawrence Weston northwest of Bristol, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kinneret
    Early Iron Age settlement on the Sea of Galilee covering about 25 acres of a hilltop.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Kirikongo
    Archaeological site in Burkina Faso occupied from the early first millennium CE through c. 1700. The site consists of a mound spread over approximately 37 hectares. Evidence for ironworking is present along with household structures.
    Creators: Sebastian Heath
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kirkhill Roman signal station
    A Roman signal station dating to the Flavian period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kirmington
    A Roman fort of early Claudian date.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Kisurra
    Kisurra (modern Tell Abu Hatab) was established in the Early Dynastic II period (ca. 2700 BCE). The importance of this settlement, which was located only a few kilometers north of Šuruppak (modern Fārā) and which was situated on the western bank of the Euphrates River, declined significantly during the Old Babylonian Period. Numerous cuneiform tablets have been unearthed at Tell Abu Hatab since 1902.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Kition: Military Port and Shipsheds
    Covered sheds (neoria) in the ancient harbor of Kition used in the construction and repair of warships by the Phoenician rulers of the city during the fifth century BCE.
    Creators: Duncan Feiges; Sophia Bruno
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Klady
    Eneolithic and early Bronze Age burial ground in the Northwest Caucasus with about 40 mounds located 3km northwest of Tsarskaya.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Klavdhia-Tremithos
    Settlement in Cyprus from the Middle and Late Bronze Age. Some tombs have been excavated, but the settlement itself is still buried.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Klimonas
    An early farming village in Cyprus dating to the ninth millennium BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Knocknakilla megaliths
    A megalithic complex located between Macroom and Millstreet, in County Cork, Ireland, and thought to have been constructed ca. 3,500 years ago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Knowlton Church and Earth Works
    A cluster of Neolithic and Bronze Age earthworks with a twelfth century Norman church built in the center.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Kobyakova Gorodishche
    Settlement on the right bank of the Don River inhabited from the Roman period and associated with the Maeotians.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Koi Krylgan Kala
    Koi Krylgan Kala is an archaeological site in Uzbekistan. At the site are the remains of a temple complex connected with the Chorasmian Dynasty that was destroyed ca. 200 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kolona
    An archaeological site on the island of Aegina that shows multiple settlement phases from the Bronze Age to the Classical period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Kom el-Nana
    Area south of the main city of Amarna that was the site of a temple during the Amarna period. The structure was overbuilt by a Christian monastery in late antiquity.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Komninon (Macedonian tomb), Stavroupolis
    Stavroupolis is the site of the largest Macedonian tomb known in Thrace.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kopia
    Settlement and glassmaking site in northern India, inhabited and in use during the first millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Korakou
    Korakou is a hill located on the Corinthian Gulf near New Corinth. It rises to 35 m above sea level. Carl Blegen conducted excavations at the site in 1915 and 1916. Archaeological remains show continuous use from the Early Helladic (EH) to Late Helladic periods (LH). It is suggested that the site served as a Mycenaean emporion. By the Archaic period the abandoned site gives way to burials.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Gabriel Mckee
  • Korčula Neolithic Site
    A submerged neolithic site on a former islet connected to the east coast of Korcula island, just southeast of the modern town and port of the same name. Preliminary underwater excavations conducted by a team from the University of Zadar were reported in the media in 2021. Stone walls, ceramics, and tools were among the finds.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Kordin III
    Megalithic temple in Malta constructed during the Mġarr phase (ca. 3700 BCE) and abandoned ca. 2500 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kordin Temples
    A group of megalithic temples on Malta constructed during the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Körzüt (Arapzengi) Kalesi
    Körzüt is the modern Turkish name of an Urartean fortress situated on a rock spur at the southern end of the Muradiye/Berkri plain, about 3 km north of the modern village of Uluşar (Korsot/Gortsut), in the Muradiye district of Van province in Turkey. According to an inscription of the Urartean King Minua (9th / 8th century BCE), the fortress was built by Minua.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Köşk Höyük
    Köşk Höyük is a limestone outcropping that was a site of human settlement that was terraced for that purpose in the neolithic period. The most recent layers date to the early Chalcolithic period (ca. 5000-4750 BCE), while earlier layers are Neolithic and date ca. 6300-5600 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kouloures at Phaistos
    Circular, stone, pit-like structures built into the ground at the edge of the West Court of the Minoan palace at Phaistos.
    Creators: Ciara L Wisecup
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Jeffrey Becker
  • Kouphovouno
    Neolithic and early Helladic site in Greece, located approximately 2.5km southwest of modern Sparta.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Koustilya
    A late-antique rural church now lacking decoration located about 6km north of the modern village of Tozeur in Tunisia.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Koyuk Shahri
    An ancient fortified site known as either Koyuk Shahri or Kuiyukexiehai'er that is located in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of north-western China preserves evidence of urban occupation in the Tarim Basin during the first millennium BCE. The site consists of a walled area of some 60,000 m² with an artificial mound at the center of the walled space.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kral Kaya Mezarları
    Elite Hellenistic rock-cut tombs of the Pontic kingdom.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Krasnyĭ mai͡ak
    Late Scythian burial site on the Lower Dnieper River containing burials dated to the 3rd century BCE-2nd century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ksar Douiret
    Fortified Berber granary (ksar). The surviving structure dates to the 14th century CE, but the site may have been in use as early as the Roman era.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • K Street
    N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Kudachurt
    Burial site in the Northern Caucusus containing 130 burials dated to the Middle-Late Bronze Age (2200-1650 BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Kullab
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Kullab was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained four temples.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Kululu Kalesi
    Kululu Kalesi is a proposed location of ancient Artulu.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Kumar
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Kumar was one of the four city districts of the western half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained seven temples.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Künzing Roman amphitheater
    A Roman timber amphitheater dating from the first to fifth centuries, the Künzing Roman amphitheater measured 46 by 40 meters. The site was discovered during excavations carried out in 2003 and 2004. The archaeological site is no longer visible but a reconstructed evocation of the ancient structure marks the location.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Kurban Höyük
    Site in eastern Anatolia inhabited from the Neolithic-Middle Bronze Age. The site was excavated in the early 1980s prior to being inundated by the construction of the Atatürk Dam in 1990.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Kuruçay Höyük
    Kuruçay Höyük is a fortified settlement site of the Late Chalcolithic period (ca. 4200–3100 BCE)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Kush (kingdom)
    Kingdom in Nubia centered around Napata, established as an independent kingdom following the end of the New Kingdom period. Kushite control extended northward during the Third Intermediate Period, and from 744-656 BCE ruled over a unified Egypt as the 25th Dynasty. Following the Assyrian conquest, the kingdom was ruled from Meroe. The kingdom disintegrated in the 3rd century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Kyz Kala
    Dating to the seventh to twelfth centuries, Kyz Kala is the site of two köshk or semi-fortified homes that are located to the southwest of the Sultan Sanjar Mausoleum at Merv in Turkmenistan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Almoloya
    La Almoloya, located in south-eastern Spain, is an archaeological site connected with the El Argar society of the Early Bronze Age. The site includes especially wealthy burials and a sprawling architectural complex that some scholars have equated with a sort of meeting hall or parliament.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Bastide-l'Eveque
    Natural sources of silver were exploited in the area of La Bastide-l'Eveque in antiquity. Numerous sculptural and epigraphic finds have been made in the area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • La Befa, Carcerelle
    The Roman villa rustica of La Befa is positioned at the point where the Torrente di Crevoli joins the river Ombrone. Excavation of the site identified a northern sector and a southern sector, both with multiple architectural phases, likely beginning the later first century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Chapelle-Vaupelteigne
    Gallo-Roman villas located in the valley of the Serein, a tributary of the Yonne river, dating from the first to the fourth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Lacus Orphei
    A fountain on the Esquiline (Regio V) that was perhaps located just outside the porta Esquilina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lacus pastorum
    A place in Regio III, likely located to the south of the Baths of Trajan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • lacus Promethei
    Either a spring or a fountain that is found in Regio I, perhaps just outside the Porta Capena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Esquerda
    An oppidum occupied from the Bronze Age to the early Medieval period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lagaba
    Unlocated city in Mesopotamia. Though its location is unknown, approximately 400 illicitly excavated cuneiform tablets are believed to have originated there. It is believed to have been located approximately 15 km north of Babylon on the western bank of the Euphrates.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Lago di Giulianello
    The Lago di Giulianello is a lake located in the territory of Giulianello in Lazio, central Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lago di Monterosi
    A volcanic crater lake located near Viterbo, Italy. The study of lacustrine sediments has revealed palynological evidence that has helped to reconstruct the ancient environment and vegetation of peninsular Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lago di San Floriano
    The lake of San Floriano is located in the Maremma plain near Capalbio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Hougue Bie
    A Neolithic ritual site that includes a passage grave dating ca. 4000-3500 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Hoya, Alava
    A prehistoric Iberian settlement of the Iron Age.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lake Bafa
    Lake Bafa (Bafa Gölü) in Ionia formed as a result of the silting of the Latmian Gulf.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Lake Eğirdir
    Lake in the southwestern Konya Plain; ancient name unknown.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Noah Kaye
  • Lake Mezzano
    Lake Mezzano is a small crater lake of central Italy that formed 400,000 years ago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lake Tana
    Lake Tana is the source of the Blue Nile and the largest lake in Ethiopia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Lagaste, Pomas-et-Rouffiac
    A pre-Roman emporion of the Aude valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • L'Alcora
    A Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Lône arcade, Nimes aqueduct
    A segment of the Nimes aqueduct.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lamā Cemetery
    Cemetery site near Lama village, Iran with almost 60 graves dating to the late 2nd-early 1st millennium CE. Most of the graves were destroyed by bulldozing in the area for a road in December 1999.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Lambaesis amphitheater
    The Roman amphitheater at Lambaesis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lamiospito Tholos Tomb, Dimini
    Late Helladic III B tholos tomb on the west foot of the Neolithic hill settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne
    Contributors:
  • La Montjoie
    A monumental Gallo-Roman column.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Muculufa (Butera)
    An Early Bronze Age village in Sicily.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lancaster Castle
    A Medieval castle that was established in the eleventh century on the site of a Roman fort that overlooked a crossing of the River Lune.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • La Pared de los Moros
    A Roman gravity dam dating to the third century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lapford
    Two distinct Roman forts; the smaller covering ca. 1.9 ha and the larger up to 8 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Pièce du Fient
    An elite Gallo-Roman villa with evidence for elaborate gardens dating from the first century CE, now located near the modern French town of Richebourg (Ile-de-France).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Large Temple at Sikait
    A large rock-cut temple at Sikait in Egypt's Eastern desert.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • La Salata necropolis
    An early Christian necropolis with tombs dating to the fourth through sixth centuries CE in the Italian comune of Vieste.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lascaux Cave
    Cave network near Montignac, France with over 600 Upper Paleolithic wall paintings.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • La Spezia
    The modern city of La Spezia, Italy, is located what was in antiquity the territory of the city of Luni. The area of La Spezia has been surveyed by archaeologists.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Late Antique domus
    The structure that now stands at Via in Selci no. 82 in the city of Rome rests on the structural remains of a late Roman building that likely date to the fourth or fifth century. These structural remains are likely those of the basilical hall that often was part of a Late Antique domus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Late Mithraeum
    Final phase of a sacred space dedicated to the worship of the god Mithras at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • La Temple de la Madeleine, Geneva
    The oldest Christian church in the city of Geneva, the Temple de la Madeleine site has been in continuous use as a church since the 5th century. The current structure on the site dates to the 15th century.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Lateran Obelisk
    The Lateran Obelisk is a monumental Egyptian obelisk, completed during the reign of Thutmose IV (c. 1400 BCE) and looted from Karnak in the early fourth century CE.
    Creators: Elliot Rosenthal; Michael Quinn
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Latin League
    The Latin League is the name given by scholars to a confederation of about 30 tribes and villages located in ancient Latium that was created for mutual defense purposes and existed from the seventh century BCE until 338 BCE. Its ancient name is unknown.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • La Torrecilla Roman Villa
    Remains of a Roman villa dating to the second century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • La Torricella
    A Medieval watch tower (thirteenth to fourteenth centuries) that is part of a system that appears to follow the line of the ancient Via Amerina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lazarides
    A Mycenaean settlement was excavated near Lazarides on Aegina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Le Castellard-Saint-Lambert
    An Iron Age oppidum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lefkandi Heroon(?)
    Rescue excavations in 1980 documented the remains of an unusual funerary structure dated ca. 1000 to 950 BCE that contained a double human burial alongside a horse burial. The structure's scale (50 by 13.8 m) and nature have led some scholars to identify it as a heroon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Lemba Lakkous
    A Late Neolithic settlement located near Chloraka, Cyprus. This site is the first example of the Erimi group of settlements that flourished in Cyprus ca. 3750-2300 BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Le Murella
    A middle Republican fortified site located near Norba.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Le Peu (Charente)
    The archaeological site at Le Peu (Charente) dates originally to the mid-fifth millennium BCE and preserves evidence of a fortified Middle Neolithic settlement with timber structures. The ditch and palisade fortifications and the timber structures represent the earliest evidence of such architecture in Atlantic Europe. The fortified site is located close to the monumental Tusson tumuli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Les Convents
    The remains of a Gallo-Roman villa at the site known as Les Convents, located on a plateau overlooking the Durance.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Le Spugne di Nocera Umbra
    A preserved stretch of masonry substruction for the Roman Via Flaminia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; John Muccigrosso
    Contributors:
  • Leucogaei fontes
    Leucogaei fontes, aluminous springs at the foot of the Colles Leucogaei, were located between Puteoli and Neapolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Leukata(s) Pr./Leukas Petra
    A promontory at the southwest shoreline of Leucas
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lewan
    Settlement site in the Bannu Basin, located in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province of Pakistan, occupied from the 4th through mid-3rd millennia.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Libersart
    A pair of Gallo-Roman burial mounds are located at Libersart in Belgium. The tombs may relate to a second and third century AD vicus in the area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Libraries' Courtyard at Hadrian's Villa
    The Libraries' Courtyard belongs to the republican period and is one of the most ancient gardens at Hadrian's Villa. It is enclosed in a large peristyle 48 m wide, 72 m long, and is located at the northern end of Villa Adriana.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Liman Kalesi
    An Ottoman-era fortification located on a headland in Taşucu bay (modern Mersin province, Turkey)
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Li Muri necropolis
    A necropolis with four dolmens surrounded by small kerbstone circles.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lion gate of Butrint
    The so-called "Lion gate" of Butrint is a fifth century A.D. gateway that reuses an Archaic Greek sculpted relief.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Lisinae
    Lisinae was an ancient town of Histiaeotis in Thessaly.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Little Palace at Knossos
    The so-called "Little Palace at Knossos" lies some 200 m northwest of the main Minoan "palace" center and to the east of the Unexplored Mansion to which it was once linked.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Andrew Shapland; Jeffrey Becker
  • Llandrindod Common
    A group of 18 Roman military camps and earthworks.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lobaos
    The site of two monopteral nuraghi.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lobos 1
    An archaeological site in La Playa de la Calera on the south coast of the Isla de Lobos in the northeast Canary Islands that has produced Roman imperial pottery and evidence of Muricidae mollusk processing for purple dye extraction.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Lochmaben Stone
    A standing megalith located near the mouth on the Solway Firth and dating ca. 3000 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Locmariaquer megaliths
    At Locmariaquer, Brittany, are the remains of a complex of Neolithic structures.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Longthorpe II
    A Pre-Roman Iron Age farmstead with a relatively short occupational history gave way to a Roman installation that was situated outside the confines of the first-century fort at Longthorpe near Peterborough. This installation was termed a "works-depot" by its excavators and shows evidence of both ceramic production and metalworking. The installation was likely established soon after the fort's own foundation in the late 40s. It is an unusual site for this period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Los Casarejos, San Martín de Losa
    A Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Los Toscanos
    A Punic settlement in Iberia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Los Villares (Huétor-Tájar)
    Los Villares (Huétor-Tájar) is an archaeological site located in the community of Los Villares (Huétor-Tájar). Here remains of a significant settlement dating to the third to sixth centuries CE have been discovered.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Los Villares necropolis
    The site of a pre-Roman Iberian necropolis, dating sixth to fourth centuries BCE located in the municipality of Hoya-Gonzalo (Albacete, Spain).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Loughbrickland Crannóg
    A Bronze Age crannog settlement located south west of Banbridge, County Down, Northern Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Loughcrew (Megalithic Landscape)
    Loughcrew (County Meath, Ireland) is the site of a funereal landscape of the fourth millennium BCE that includes more than twenty megalithic tombs spread across four hilltop areas: Carnbane East, Carnbane West, Carrickbrack, and Patrickstown Hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Loughton Camp
    Loughton Camp is an Iron Age hill fort located in the Epping Forest in England. The earthworks of the fort cover approximately 4 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lower Church at Banganarti
    Church dating to the 7th century CE in Nubia that was succeeded by St. Raphael Church II. The site is located in the modern Sudanese village of Banganarti.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Lower Main Street
    Irregular W-E street located on the eastern edge of the Dura-Europos city grid.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Lu Brandali
    A nuragic settlement dating to the latter part of the second millennium BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Lucus Stimulae
    A grove sacred to Stimula, located at the southwestern foot of the Aventine hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ludus Magnus
    A gladiatorial training school adjacent to the Flavian Amphitheater in Rome. The structure is attested on the Severan marble plan of Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lupercal
    A cave located at the foot of the Palatine Hill in Rome in which the she-wolf was said to have been found suckling the twins, Romulus and Remus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Lurg Moor
    A Roman fortlet located on Lurg Moor dating from the Antonine period, ca. AD 140.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Luxmanda archaeological site
    A large settlement in Tanzania dating to the Pastoral Neolithic period in eastern Africa.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Lyne
    A Roman auxiliary fort in Scotland guarding the road from Trimontium to Castledykes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ma’allanate Archive 1
    An archive, sold on the antiquities market, can be located at Ma’allanate. The site has not been precisely identified, but two suggestions have been made regarding its location. The first situates it in the upper Balikh valley, northern Syria, while the other places it further east, on the Habur river between Tell Halaf/Guzana and Al-Hasakah. Recent opinion favours the first location. 49 cuneiform tablets have been attributed to Ma’allanate. These are mostly written in Assyrian, but three use Babylonian script and dialect. In addition to these texts, 24 documents are written in Aramaic. The archive belonged to Ḫandi, who had the title “steward of the palace“ was active from 700 to 665 BC, his son Ḫarranayu, who was active from 661 to 644 BC, and Ser-nuri, active from 652 to 622 BC. The relationship between Ser-nuri and the father and son is unclear. The archive contains loan documents of silver and barley, payments of loans, purchase documents of slaves and land, and other documents.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Mably
    A group of Gallo-Roman houses was identified on the banks of the Loire river in 1824, with some archaeological investigation in 1962-68. Associated finds date the site to the second century A.D. A Gallo-Roman villa was also identified at the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Macellum Magnum
    The great market hall built by the emperor Nero on the Caelian Hill and dedicated in the year 59. The market hall is known from numismatic imagery and some of its archaeological remains have been documented on the Caelian hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Madānu Canal Gate
    The Neo-Babylonian kings Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. That mudbrick wall is reported to have had 120 towers and 5 entrances, including the Madānu Canal Gate. This access point to the city was probably located on the eastern stretch of the wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Madonna del Passo
    A modern comune located in the territory of Rieti, Lazio. The Rieti Survey identified this as a likely Roman-period settlement covering more than 5 ha. Material evidence suggests occupation from ca. the sixth century B.C. until the sixth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Maecium
    Maecium or Mecium is a locality near Lanuvium where the Volsci encamped.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Maen Castle
    Maen Castle is an Iron Age promontory fort near Land's End in Cornwall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Maesia Silva
    An ancient forest of Etruria that originally was situated in the territory of Veii. Ancus Marcus conquered the area which most likely was located on the right bank of the Tiber.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mageroy Gallo-Roman villa
    The archaeological site of a well preserved Gallo-Roman villa located at Mageroy in Habay-la-Vieille, Arlon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Maidanetske, Ukraine
    Maidanetske, Ukraine is the site of two separate Neolithic to Chalcolithic settlements associated with the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture. A 2 ha settlement dating ca. 5000 BCE lies on the outskirts of Maidanetske, Ukraine while another, larger settlement (ca. 3700 BCE) was found west of Maidanetske on the left bank of the Tal'ianki River.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Main Street
    The centermost and comparatively wider W-E street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Maison romaine du Parking Pasteur, Aix-en-Provence
    A well-appointed Roman domus was discovered at the site of what is now a parking structure in Aix-en-Provence.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Makli, Thatta
    Thatta was the capital of three successive dynasties and later ruled by the Mughal emperors of Delhi. The expansive necropolis is thought to have grown around the fourteenth-century shrine of Muhammad Hussain Abro.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Makronissos tombs
    Burial site in southern Cyprus containing burials dated to the Hellenistic and Roman periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Máli
    Near modern Khostia/Prodromos in Boeotia, Máli is the modern name of a peak on a ridgeline where extensive remains of an ancient site, possibly a "refuge site" for the polis of Khorsiai, have been discovered. The population of Khorsiai are thought to have relocated back to the original nucleus of the community at nearby Kástron Khostíon sometime in the early Archaic period.
    Creators: Michael Karabogias; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Malkata
    Site located south of the Theban Necropolis containing a New Kingdom palace complex constructed by Amenhotep III of the 18th Dynasty.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Maltepe Tumulus
    The Maltepe Tumulus is located in Manole, Bulgaria. The tumulus measures 125 – 130 m in diameter and some 21 m in height.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Malvaccaro Roman villa
    An imperial Roman villa located near Potenza.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mandzhikiny Burial Ground
    Burial ground in Kalmykia, Russia with 17 burial mounds from the Bronze Age and Early Iron Age.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Mané-Vechen, Plouhinec
    A Gallo-Roman villa excavated in 1970-1971. A possible fanum was identified 50 meters to the northwest of the villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mangadu Megalithic Site
    An archaeological site with Iron Age funerary megaliths located in the vicinity of the modern Moonamkutty-Mangad Road in the northeastern portion of India's Kollam municipality. The site was damaged by cashewnut tree farming and is now not visible due to habitation on the site.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Marcellinus and Peter
    An ancient Christian catacomb located at the third milestone of the Via Labicana. The name refers to two Christian martyrs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mardaman
    Early and Middle Bronze Age city in northern Mesopotamia.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Marduk Gate
    The Marduk Gate is one of Babylon's eight city gates and it is situated on the eastern side of the inner city, directly east of the Kullab quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Marigny à Fleurville Gallo-Roman Villa
    Remains of a Gallo-Roman Villa at modern Château de Marigny at Fleurville, France.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Marina di Palo Roman villa
    An Imperial maritime villa located in Ladispoli, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Marino Mithraeum
    A Mithraic shrine of unusual size discovered at modern Marino, Italy in 1963.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Marki Alonia
    Marki Alonia is a prehistoric settlement in central Cyprus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Marlik
    Burial site in northern Iran containing over fifty burials dated to the mid-2nd millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mars, Aedes
    A temple sacred to Mars located on the Via Appia. The shrine was located between the first and second milestones and was dedicated in the fourth century BC. According to Livy, Titus Quinctius dedicated the temple on 1 June 387 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Masath / Massa (river)
    The Massa River of southern Morocco.
    Creators: Brian Z. Lund; J. Desanges; M. Euzennat; M. Joann McDaniel; Mary E. Downs; R. Talbert
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Massaciuccoli Romana - Padiglione "Guglielmo Lera"
    The site of a Roman imperial-period villa in the modern Italian comune of Massaciuccoli Romana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Massaciuccoli Romana - Padiglione "Il Cantiere"
    The site of a Roman imperial-period villa in the modern Italian comune of Massaciuccoli Romana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Masseria Caronella
    A Roman villa rustica located near Taranto.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Masseria De Carolis
    A Roman villa with an associated bath complex destroyed by the AD 79 eruption of Vesuvius, the Masseria De Carolis site is located in the comune of Pollena Trocchia near Naples, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Masseria Petrolio
    The substruction (basis) of a Roman villa rustica dating to the late republican period located near the course of the Garigliano river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Masseria Ponte
    Roman bridge, Masseria Ponte
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Matarrah
    Hilltop settlement in northern Iraq representing one of the oldest villages of the Near East. Archaeological evidence shows that this was an early location of agricultural practices.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Matieni (mountains)
    A mountain range that defines the center of Matiene.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mausoleo di Monte dell'Incastro
    A circular, domed, apsidal subterranean structure of the Hadrianic period that is referred to as a tomb but may have had a cultic function.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleo di San Vito at Puteoli
    A mausoleum in the so-called San Vito necropolis that dates to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Mausoleo di Ummidia Quadratilla
    A Roman tomb located in the archaeological area of Casinum that dates to either the first or second centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum and Sacred area of Hecatomnus
    A mausoleum and sacred precinct associated with Hecatomnus of Mylasa, who was the satrap of Caria under Artaxerxes II (404–358 BC).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum Campo Barbarico
    The Campo Barbarico Mausoleum is a third-century CE Roman "temple tomb" located at the fourth mile of the Via Latina. The tomb's position is immediately to the south of the archaeological area of the Tombs of the Via Latina. In 2022, additional in situ tracts of the Via Latina's pavement were excavated adjacent to the mausoleum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum of Bibi Maryam at Qalhat
    The Mausoleum of Bibi Maryam at Qalhat was built for Baha al-Din Ayaz, the successor of Mahmud b. Ahmad al-Qusi al-Qalhati, the founder of the Hormuz empire which flourished from the eighth to the fourteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum of Diocletian
    A mausoleum built to entomb Diocletian at his retirement palace that was constructed around 295 CE and is located in modern day Split, Croatia.
    Creators: Kiel Papa; Luka Bayon-Fraise
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Mausoleum of Galba
    The so-called mausoleum of Galba is a Roman period tomb located in Monte San Biagio Latium, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum of Lucius Sempronius Atratinus
    A first-century B.C. circular funerary monument at Gaeta.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum of M. Coelius Vinicianus
    A mid-first century B.C. tomb at Tusculum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mausoleum of Menenius Agrippa
    The so-called mausoleum of Menenius Agrippa stands along the Via Nomentana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Medina Azahara
    The Caliphate City of Medina Azahara is a city built in the mid-tenth century CE by the Umayyad dynasty as the seat of the Caliphate of Cordoba.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Medina of Essaouira
    The Medina of Essaouira, formerly Mogador, is a late eighteenth century fortified town with ancient Phoenician origins. It is located on the Atlantic coast of Morocco.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Megali Koryfi
    Megali Koryfi, an archaeological site on the island of Aegina in proximity to the Christian chapel of Ag. Antonios that is noted for the presence of substantial remains of drystone fortifications dating to the Mycenaean period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Mercurius, Aedes
    A temple dedicated to Mercury and Maia that was located on the slopes of the Aventine Hill overlooking the Circus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Merimde
    Neolithic settlement in Egypt. This settlement was inhabited in the 5th millennium and was the typesite for the Merimde culture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Meteora
    Metéora comprises a complex of six Eastern Orthodox monasteries built on natural sandstone pillars of the Thessalian plain. The site was listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1988.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Metroon at Olympia
    Temple at Olympia constructed in the late 4th or early 3rd century BCE
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Metsamor
    A prehistoric site with megalithic standing stones.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Metsopay-Vank
    Armenian monastery and find place for a Urartian stele.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Mettet
    A Gallo-Roman villa located in the vicinity of Bauselenne.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Meyrargues aqueduct
    Remains of a Roman aqueduct.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Middle Citadel Gate
    One of two gates providing access from the west through the southern end of the citadel defense walls at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Middle Mithraeum
    Second phase of a sacred space dedicated to the worship of the god Mithras at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Midhowe
    A large Neolithic chambered cairn located on the island of Rousay, Orkney, Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Military Base
    Intramural military base located on the north and east side of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Military camp
    The Gallo-Roman castrum or military camp at modern Jublains.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Military Campus
    Intramuros military assembly and training ground on the eastern side of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Military Zeus Temple
    Small temple with pitched roof presumably dedicated to Zeus, located in the military campus zone Block A1 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Minar-i Chakri
    Minar-i Chakri, located in the Kabul province of Afghanistan, was the site of a Kushan-era pillar dating to the second or third century AD that was destroyed in the later twentieth century by the Soviet army.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Minoan Palatial Center (Knossos)
    An extensive, multi-period bronze age palace complex, located south of modern Heraklion in central Crete.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Andrew Shapland; Maija Gierhart
  • Minshat Abu Omar
    Cemetery site in Northern Egypt with burials from the predynastic period as well as the late Roman period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Mira Lanza
    The remains of an Archaic period structure at Mira Lanza, located in Via Luigi Pierantoni.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Miṣr (early Islamic province)
    The Rashidun Caliphate expanded westward into the Byzantine province of Egypt between 639-646 CE, winning victories in key battles at Heliopolis in 640 and Alexandria in 641 and 646. A new capital was established at Al-Fusṭāṭ in 641.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mithraeum at Mundelsheim
    A second-century Mithraeum is located in the area of the municipality of Mundelsheim in the Ludwigsburg district of Baden-Württemberg, Germany.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mithraeum at Riegel
    A temple once sacred to Mithras located in Riegel am Kaiserstuhl (Baden-Wuerttemberg, Germany).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mithraeum of Lucretius Menander
    The Mithraeum of Lucretius Menander located in ancient Ostia dates to the third century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Moab (kingdom)
    An ancient Levantine kingdom located in what is today the modern state of Jordan.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mochlos archaeological site
    A multi-period settlement site in use by a number of civilizations dating ca. 3100 B.C. to A.D. 1200.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mochlos (island)
    Mochlos is an island in the Gulf of Mirabello, although in antiquity it was likely connected to the Cretan mainland. The island is the site of an ancient Minoan settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mokha
    Mokha, a port city on the Red Sea, is a key trading center that reaches its peak in the seventeenth century. It succeeds the ancient Mouza Emporion.
    Creators: Dhruvan Nair
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mokraya Balka cemetery
    Burial site in the North Caucasus associated with the Alanic culture, containing nearly 100 burials dated from the 5th-12th centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Monastero di San Benedetto Sacro Speco
    The Shrine of the Sacred Cave of St. Benedict (Sacro Speco di San Benedetto) at Subiaco is a significant monastic shrine connected to the Roman Catholic saint Benedict. At the site is found a fresco-adorned cave linked to the saint dating to the eighth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monastery of Saint John the Theologian
    The Monastery of Saint John the Theologian (also known as the Monastery of Saint John the Divine) is a Greek Orthodox monastery dating to AD 1088 on the island of Patmos.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monastery of San Juan de Caaveiro
    A Christian monastery established in AD 934.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monastery of S. Elia Vecchio
    A ruined ninth century Christian monastery in Calabria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monastery of Simeon Stylites the Younger
    A sixth century AD monastery named for Simeon Stylites the Younger who lived atop a pillar on Thaumaston Oros.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monkodonja
    A Bronze Age fort of the Castellieri culture in Istria with megalithic architecture.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Abatone necropolis, Caere
    A necropolis of ancient Caere with particularly important evidence of funerary assemblages showing the influence of the Orientalizing period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Aguzzo tumulus
    Monte Aguzzo di Formello (Rome), the site of a tumulus along the road leading for Veii to the Ager Faliscus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Baranta
    A pre-nuragic architectural complex near Olemdo, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Bernorio
    Monte Bernorio is the site of a fortified Cantabrian settlement covering more than 120 hectares.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Montebuono
    The remains of a villa were excavated near the church of San Pietro ad centum muros in the nineteenth century. Based on epigraphic evidence, the site is connected with M. Vipsanius Agrippa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Catria
    A mountain of the central Apennine range; the highest peak rises to 1,702 metres (5,584 ft) above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Cornacchia
    Monte Cornacchia is the highest peak in the Daunian Mountains and the region of Apulia region (1,151 m (3,776 ft)).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Dell'Incastro (Guidonia Montecelio)
    The Monte Dell'Incastro in Guidonia Montecelio, Lazio, is a hill that is the site of ancient construction activity, including villas, a nymphaeum, and a subterranean cult of Hercules.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Montefortini
    A monumental Etruscan tumulus that covers two chamber tombs that were looted in antiquity but that likely dated to the seventh and sixth centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Gentili
    A villa associated with Aulus Vitellius Germanicus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Montelabate
    The Montelabate estate of the Gaslini foundation has been investigated by means of both field survey and excavation. This upland area sits astride a frontier zone, one that separates Perugia (Etruria) from Gubbio (Umbria). Simon Stoddart, Maurizio Matteini Chiari, Gabriele Cifani, and other scholars have noted that this ancient frontier zone was in place by the fifth-fourth centuries BC and denotes the differential urbanism practices of Etruscans and Umbrians, respectively.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Luna Necropoleis
    Two adjacent funerary landscapes located south of modern Senorbì on the island of Sardinia, with burials ranging from the 6th century BCE to the 6th century CE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Monte Novo do Castelinho
    A Roman earthen embankment dam of ca. 56 m length.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Montereggi
    An Etruscan settlement in proximity to the course of the Arno river that was active from the fifth to the first centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Rovello
    Monte Rovello was an important Etruscan settlement covering ca. 5 hectares with occupation stretching from the Bronze Age to the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte San Giovanni Campano
    Monte San Giovanni Campano is the site of ancient first millennium BC fortifications, atop which was built the eleventh century fortress, Castello di Monte San Giovanni Campano, where Thomas Aquinas was imprisoned.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Santa Vittoria Megalithic Enclosure
    A megalithic enclosure that includes a circular Nuragic building.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Savello (Rome)
    Monte Savello is an area located in Rome's Sant'Angelo district, between the pons Fabricius and the Capitoline Hill. Its status as 'monte' is owed to the fact that an artificial mound of debris accumulated in the area of the Circus Flaminius and the Theater of Marcellus, a mound that came to serve as a de facto quarry for spoliated building materials. "Savello" refers to the post-eleventh century incorporation of the area within the fortifications of the Savello family. Modern excavations have revealed Roman, post-Roman, Medieval, and more recent settlement horizons.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monte Tamburino
    A peak rising to 594 meters above sea level.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Monte Torre Maggiore
    An Italic temple complex in Umbria of the first millennium B.C. that includes the so-called "Ara maior".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Montione
    A large villa platform, perhaps measuring 150 meters square, located near Grottaferrata, southeast of Rome. The earliest phase belonged to the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Monumental Mid-Republican Building Complex
    This monumental complex of buildings at the city of Gabii was likely constructed in the mid-third century BCE as a public area for feasts, bathing, and ritual activities.
    Creators: AJ Adler; Shannon Well-Moran
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter; Shannon Wells-Moran
  • Mooghaun Ringfort
    A first millennium B.C. ringfort in County Clare, Ireland, with three concentric rings of fortifications. At 27 acres, this is one of the largest hill forts in Iron Age Europe.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Moregine
    Moregine, immediately to the south of the archaeological site of Pompeii, is the findspot of an important archaeological assemblage buried by seismic activity that preceded that final eruption of Vesuvius in A.D. 79.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Moron
    A Spanish village located in the southeast of the province of Sevilla that belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X. It is now known as Morón de la Frontera.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mortuary Temple of Hatshepsut
    The Mortuary Temple of Hatshepsut at Deir el-Bahari was built for the Eighteenth dynasty Pharaoh Hatshepsut.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Mortuary temple of Mentuhotep II
    The Mortuary temple of the Eleventh Dynasty pharaoh Mentuhotep II at Deir el-Bahari would inspire the later mortuary complexes of Hatshepsut and Thutmose III that are also found at the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mound at Banāt al-Hassan (Adams 100)
    Part of a group of mounds in central Mesopotamia, this settlement (number 100 in Adams 1972) containing remains dated from the Akkadian through Larsa periods.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Mound at Banāt al-Hassan (Adams 130)
    Part of a group of mounds in central Mesopotamia, this settlement (number 130 in Adams 1972) contains remains dated from the Jemet Nasr through Akkadian periods.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Mound at Banāt al-Hassan (Adams 131)
    Part of a group of mounds in central Mesopotamia, this settlement (number 131 in Adams 1972) contained remains dated to the Early Dynastic I-Old Babylonian periods (chiefly Ur III-Larsa). The site also contains a number of burials from the Parthian period, fragments of Sasanian pottery, and the remains of an Early Islamic structure.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Mount Caburn hill fort
    Atop Mount Caburn are the remains of a Pre-Roman Iron Age hill fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mount Mugh
    Small, remote mountain peak in Tajikistan with a castle used in the 7th-8th centuries CE as a refuge by the Sogdian rulers of Panjakent. The site was the source of a major find of Sogdian documents.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mousa
    Mousa is an island in Shetland, Scotland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Muel dam
    A first century AD Roman gravity dam.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Muggia
    Muggia's beginnings as a prehistoric fortified village (castelliere) came ca. the eighth and seventh centuries B.C. This territory came under Roman control in the 170s BC. In 931, king Hugh of Italy donated Muggia to the Patriarch of Aquileia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Muir O' Fauld
    A first-century Roman watch tower on the Gask Ridge.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mulhacén
    A mountain peak Mulhacén, rises to 3,479 m (11,414 ft), making it the highest mountain of the Iberian Peninsula. It is part of the Sierra Nevada range in the Cordillera Penibética.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mülheim-Kärlich
    A Roman villa dating to the second and third centuries A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mullissu Gate
    The Mullissu Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Mullissu-muddišat-ḫiṣbi ("The Goddess Mullissu Is the One Who Restores Abundance"), is the fourth of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the second of the north-facing entrances to the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Murat Höyük
    Settlement on the Murat River in Eastern Anatolia inhabited in the Early Bronze Age (ca. 2500-2200 BCE), the Early-Middle Iron Age, and the Medieval Period. It is located near, but distinct from, the Urartian and Byzantine site of Murat Tepe.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Murat Tepe
    Settlement on the Murat River inhabited during the Urartian and Byzantine periods. It is located near, but distinct from, the Bronze Age-Medieval site of Murat Höyük.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Muro da Prega
    A Roman dam located west of Beja, Portgual.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mushabbak Basilica
    The remains of a well-preserved Byzantine church (ca. 470) located five km west of the Monastery of St Simeon. The ruins lie near the town of Daret A'zzeh.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Mu-Sharet Burial Ground
    Burial ground with 25 graves in 11 mounds located 10km Northeast of Manych, Kalmykia. These graves are largely from the Bronze Age and early Copper Age with some early Iron Age and Medieval graves also present.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Must Farm Bronze Age settlement
    A well-preserved pile-dwelling settlement site dating to the Late Bronze Age that is located in Cambridgeshire, United Kingdom.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Mutatorium Caesaris
    An imperial property opposite the Baths of Caracalla that is mentioned in the Regionary Catalogues and also preserved on a fragment of the Severan marble plan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Muweilah
    A fortified settlement dating to the Iron Age II period (ca. 1,100-600 BCE).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Myskhako necropolis
    A burial area on the Black Sea coast that is associated with the settlement of Myskhako. In 1978-1979 excavations were conducted that uncovered 81 burial sites dating to the Bronze Age, the Classical period, and the Middle Ages.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Mysomacedones
    A tribe located in the area of Ephesus, concentrated on the area around the river Mysius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nabû temple (Khorsabad)
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) had a temple to the god Nabû, the god of scribes, built in the citadel of his new capital, Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad). Building H is the largest temple in Sargon’s newly-constructed city and it was built on a platform in the western side of the citadel, rather than on the palace terrace. The Nabû temple was connected to the temple district, which formed part of Sargon’s royal residence, by a stone bridge.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Nag' el-Scheima
    Christian settlement on the Nile protected by defensive walls and a fortress and featuring churches and a cemetery probably dating until the 5th century CE. The site was flooded by the High Aswan Dam.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Nairi
    A people or confederation in Eastern Anatolia and the South Caucasus referred to in Assyrian texts from the 13th-7th centuries BCE. The southernmost extent of this polity was in the region of Lake Urmia, and its northernmost reaches in the vicinity of Erzurum. It was related in some way to Urartu, though the nature of the relationship is unclear.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Najafabad
    Najafabad (Persian: نجف‌آباد‎) is a city in Iran and the capital of Najafabad, Isfahan Province. The discovery of a stele of the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) indicates that the settlement’s ancient name, at least in the eighth century BC, might have been Kišesim.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Nausharo
    Archaeological site in Balochistan, Pakistan associated with the Indus Valley civilization. The site shows signs of habitation from the early third-early second millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Necropoli di San Vito
    A Greek necropolis located at Puteoli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Necropoli Giambertoni
    A Hellenistic and Roman necropolis at Agrigento (second century BC to the third century AD) that includes the Tomb of Theron.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropoli Orti della Maddalena
    A Hellenistic and Roman period necropolis located in Messina, Sicily, in the area now referred to as "Orti della Maddalena".
    Creators: Valeria Vitale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jonathan Prag
  • Necropoli Romana
    A Roman necropolis at Brixia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necròpolis fenicia de Jardin
    A Punic necropolis located in Los Toscanos, Spain, that was in use from the sixth to the fourth centuries BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis near Randazzo, Sicily
    A necropolis with remains dating to the fifth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Campo della Fonte
    The Campo della Fonte at Rusellae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Campovalano
    A Picene necropolis located near Campovalano (Campli) in the province of Teramo. While more than 600 tombs were identified, there may have been as many as 20,000 originally.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Necropolis of Filigosa
    A Chalcolithic necropolis near Macomer in Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Grottini di Rota
    An Etruscan necropolis located in the middle of the Mignone river valley in the comune of Canale Monterano.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Madonna d'olivo
    An Etruscan necropolis located about 2 km south-west of Tuscania that overlooks valley of the Marta river. The necropolis takes its name from the adjacent Church of the Madonna dell’Olivo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Oretum
    An archaeological site connected with ancient Oretum, now located adjacent to the Ermita-Santuario de Nuestra Señora de Oreto y Zuqueca.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of San Germano
    Burial ground containing 28 burials dated to the Etruscan period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Necropolis of Santa Maria in Borraccia
    A seventh- and sixth-century B.C. Etruscan necropolis located in the territory of Heba.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Necropolis of Sant'Andrea Priu
    A prehistoric necropolis in Sardinia associated with the Ozieri culture and dating to the Final Neolithic period (ca. 3500-2900 BC).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Negrar Roman Villa
    Remains of a Roman villa with mosaic pavements located near the modern comune of Negrar di Valpolicella were first discovered in 1922.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Neolithic Settlement at Knossos
    A neolithic settlement on a hill known today as Kephala, south of Heraklion on the island of Crete. It preceded the Bronze Age (Minoan) palace and settlement on this site.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Andrew Shapland; Jeffrey Becker
  • Nevalı Çori
    An early Neolithic settlement in the middle Euphrates river valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • New City/Newtown
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, New City (ālu eššu) was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained two temples and one dais. This city quarter dates back to the late Old Babylonian Period (as demonstrated by a commercial archive excavated in the Merkes).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • New Kalabsha Island
    New Kalabsha is a promontory located near Aswan. It currently is the site of several ancient temples relocated to avoid the rising waters of Lake Nasser created by the construction of the Aswan High Dam.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • New Palace at Assur
    The Middle Assyrian king Tukultī-Ninurta I (1233–1197 BC) built himself a new royal residence at Assur. That palace, which went by the Sumerian name Elugalumunkurkurra (“House of the King, Lord of the Lands”), covered an area of about 27000 m². After Tukultī-Ninurta I’s reign, the so-called “New Palace” was no longer maintained and, thus, fell into ruins.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • New Year's Festival House at Assur
    As part of his post-689-BC religious reforms, the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib (704–681 BC) had a new New Year’s festival house (akītu-house) constructed outside the western wall of Assur. This was an attempt to replicate the cultic topography of Babylon. The Sumerian ceremonial names of that holy building and its cella are Eabbaugga ("House Where Tiāmat Is Put To Death") and Edubdubabba ("House That Makes Tiāmat Tremble”) respectively.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Niebla
    A Spanish village located in the northeastern part of the province of Huelva that once belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Nineveh Archive 1
    The Palace of Sennacherib (South-Palace Palace) at Nineveh remained in use until the Assyrian capital was captured, looted, and destroyed in 612 BC. Numerous tablets discovered in Rooms XL and XLI, as well as in some of the adjoining rooms, nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of a library, including many clay tablets inscribed with literary texts. During the reign of Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC), the last great king of Assyria, the tablets found in this archive repository were probably part of his tablet collection.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Nineveh Archive 2
    In the Palace of Sennacherib (South-West Palace) at Nineveh, in Room LXI, nineteenth-century British excavators discovered about 450 clay bullae. Most of these had seal impressions on one side and indications on their backsides that they were fastened with rope to perishable materials (for example, papyrus and leather). These bullae are probably the remains of an archive of Aramaic documents.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
  • Nineveh Archive 3
    In the Palace of Sennacherib (South-West Palace) at Nineveh, in Room LIV, nineteenth-century British excavators found the remains of an archive consisting of cuneiform tablets, some of which also included summary notes in Aramaic.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny
  • Nineveh Archive 4
    In the Palace of Ashurbanipal (North Palace), in Room C, nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of an archive of clay tablets. This find yielded records for military officers and possibly literary texts (although this has yet to be conclusively proven).
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
  • Nineveh Archive 5
    In the Palace of Ashurbanipal (North Palace), in the southwest corner nineteenth-century British excavators unearthed the remains of a library, including many clay tablets inscribed with literary texts. During the reign of Ashurbanipal (r. 668–ca. 631 BC), the last great king of Assyria, the tablets found in this archive repository were probably part of his tablet collection. Because these tablets were excavated very close to the Nabû temple (Ezida), which also had its own archival repository, some of the tablets thought to have come from the so-called “Library of Ashurbanipal” might have actually belonged to the neighboring Nabû temple. Today, the North Palace library material is not clearly differentiated from that of Ezida, due to the fact that the excavators did not provide detailed information about the exact findspots of the tablets.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors:
  • Nineveh Archive 6
    A clay pot with about thirty clay tablets was found to the north of the Šamaš Gate at Nineveh, in a secondary context. The archive, whose texts are dated between 669 BC and the fall of Nineveh (612 BC), belonged to Ninurta-šarru-uṣur (“the son of the palace”), as well as to several other people, including some Egyptians. This small archive consists of loan and purchase documents, legal texts, as well as a piece of correspondence.
    Creators: Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Jamie Novotny; Tom Elliott
  • Ninfeo della Lucchina
    A nymphaeum of the third century CE that was identified in 1990 and was likely one component of a larger villa complex in the north-west suburbium of imperial Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ningal temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the goddess Ningal.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ninurta-mukīn-temmēn-ālišu-ana-labār-ūmē-rūqūti
    The Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) surrounded his new capital Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") with a rectangular-shaped, 16,280-cubit-long inner and outer city wall. The name of the outer/lower city wall (šalḫû) was Ninurta-mukīn-temmēn-ālišu-ana-labār-ūmē-rūqūti ("The God Ninurta Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of His City for (All) Days to Come") according to some Akkadian royal inscriptions, but Ninurta-mukīn-temmēn-adušši-ana-labār-ūmē-rūqūti ("The God Ninurta Is the One Who Establishes the Foundation of the Wall for (All) Days to Come") according to other texts written in the name of Sargon II.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ninurta temple (Kalhu)
