    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. The most important of those was dedicated to the god Ninurta, the patron deity of city, which Ashurnasirpal had constructed between his palace and the ziggurat, a building also consecrated to Ninurta.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ninurta temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the god Ninurta.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Noddule nuragic complex
    A multi-period settlement site with occupation stretching from ca. 4000 B.C. to the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Normandykes
    A Roman marching camp.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • North Citadel Gate
    Gate providing access from the northwest through the citadel defense walls at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Northern Cluster
    The Northern Cluster of rock-cut churches at Lalibela.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Northern necropolis at Apulum
    Cemetery site near the town of Apulum containing over a thousand burials dated to the late 1st-mid-3rd century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Northern Postern Gate
    Postern gate located on the northwest side of the city walls, near Tower 2.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Northern Stelae Field
    An expansive area of funereal monuments at Aksum in Ethiopia, built between the third and fourth centuries A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • North Palace at Babylon
    The Neo-Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed a new royal residence for himself at Babylon. This grand palace was constructed north of the so-called “South Palace,” the traditional royal residence of the kings of Babylon. The building, which is referred to as the “new palace” (ēkallu eššu) in Achaemenid-period texts, is generally called the “North Palace,” “Nordburg,” and “New Palace.”
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • North Palace at Deir el-Ballas
    Royal palace in the Upper Nile in use from the Second Intermediate Palace to the early New Kingdom.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Nossa Senhora da Tourega
    An imperial villa located in the territory of Ebora.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Noues
    Pottery workshop site in Gaul near the modern village of La Boissière-École containing several workshop sites used from the first-third centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Nubt
    Type-site of the predynastic Naqada Culture, containing a settlement, a necropolis, and a step pyramid constructed ca. 3500 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Numeira
    Archaeological site on the eastern shore of the Dead Sea with signs of habitation dated to the Early Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Numinienses
    One of the lost peoples of Latium as enumerated by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Asoru o Basoru
    Nuraghe Asoru o Basoru located in San Vito, Sardinia, Italy
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Baccu Idda
    A nuragic site located near Chia, Sardinia, Su Nuraxi de Baccu Idda is located atop a 78 m hill close to the course of the Riu di Chia, a stream that irrigates the plain south-east of the nuragic complex.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Bardalazzu
    Nuraghe Bardalazzu, a ruined nuragic site located near Dualchi, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Biriola
    A Nuraghe with a complex plan located near Dualchi, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Cabudbbene
    Nuraghe Cabudbbene I is a single tower nuraghe built of trachyte.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Nuraghe Conca Niedda
    A nuraghe that is located atop a trachytic rock at a bend in the Rio d'Aridda, a river that has carved a deep valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Corbos
    A Middle Bronze Age nuragic monument in Silanus, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Diana
    A single-tower nuraghe located near Quartu Sant'Elena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Gibe Truttiri
    A nuraghe located near the beach of Cala Marina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Maronzu
    Remains of a nuraghe in the territory of the comune of Olbia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Ponte, Dualchi
    Nuraghe Ponte, Dualchi is located near the archaeological complex of Frenegarzu. The site consists of a single circular tower (diameter 13.25 m; height 11.80 m) built upon a foundation of large roughly-hewn polyhedral blocks that support the structure built of neatly squared ashlars.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Rumanedda
    A nuraghe located near Tottubella in the territory of Sassari.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Santa Giusta
    A nuragic site located near Tortoli, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Sa Ucchiusura
    A monopteral nuraghe built of trachite. The ruined walls stand to at least four meters in height.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Su Nuraxi 'e Pauli
    A nuraghe with a single, truncated tower.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuraghe Terra Tenera
    A single-tower nuraghe located near Sassari, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Nuragic settlement, Antas
    A Nuragic settlement that pre-dates and, in some cases, is re-occupied during the Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • nu-x-ù
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, nu-x-ù/nu-HAR-UD (name fragmentary and not reconstructable) was one of the four city districts of the western half of the inner city of Babylon.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Nymphaeum of Egeria
    A nymphaeum connected with Egeria, the divine advisor of Numa Pompilius. This iteration of Egeria's spring dates to the time of Herodes Atticus in the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oakley Down
    A Bronze Age barrow cemetery.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oakmere hill fort
    Oakmere hill fort is an Iron Age hill fort located in the county of Cheshire in northern England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Odeon at Pausilipum
    The Roman odeon at Pausilipum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Odèon/Ekklesiasterion
    The Bouleuterion of ancient Region (modern Reggio Calabria).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Odeon of Herodes Atticus
    A large theater in Athens, built during the Roman period on the south-western slope of the Acropolis around 160 to 174 CE.
    Creators: Kyle Nash; Ryan Dooley
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Odeon of Lyon
    The Odeon is a small theater in modern day Lyon, France built specifically for musical performances around the beginning of the 2nd century CE.
    Creators: Clara Leach; Elin Hansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Offemont
    A Roman-period pottery production workshop dating to the second century CE, located in the modern French commune of Offemont (Territoire de Belfort).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Oldberry Castle
    Oldberry Castle is an Iron Age hill fort in Somerset, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Old Kandahar citadel
    Tradition holds that the Iron Age and Achaemenid citadel of Old Kandahar was re-established during the time of Alexander the Great. It functioned as a local seat of power for at least two millennia.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Oletandros
    An island of the Aegean Sea mentioned only by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Olten
    A vicus and fort on the Aare river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oostvoorne
    Oostvoorne may correspond to a putative Roman period place that once protected the Meuse river estuary (Helinium) and therefore may have carried its name. Coastal change has long since consumed any remains of the Roman site; a Medieval castle is still attested.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Oppidum du Castellas de St Martin
    An oppidum located in the vicinity of the modern commune in the Alpes-Maritimes department of southeastern France.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Oppius Mons
    The Oppian Hill is the southern spur of Rome's Esquiline Hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oracular sanctuary at Oinoe
    Located to the east of the medieval tower at Oinoe are the remains of a rectangular peristylar building measuring approximately 13.60 x 17.30 meters. The peristyle used marble columns set atop marble pilasters. Spyridon Marinatos discovered the site in 1972.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oram's Arbour
    Oram's Arbour, now a park, was the site of Iron Age occupation prior to the establishment of Venta. Location based on OpenStreetMap.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oroanda
    A settlement in the mountains of Pisidia, near the south-western shore of lake Trogitis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Orridroxiu
    Two nuraghi located in the valley of Riu Accu 'e Nius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Orticello, Spello
    A suburban villa outside Hispellum at the base of Mount Subasio, near a road linking the Via Flaminia to Perusia and Asisium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Osi
    A tribe (perhaps Illyrian?) mentioned by Tacitus and located to the east of the Marcomanni and west of the Hercynia Silva.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Osmanthorpe Roman vexillation fortress
    The remains of Osmanthorpe Roman vexillation fortress are situated on a hilltop in the valley of the River Greet.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ostrusha mound
    A Thracian tumulus located near Shipka, Bulgaria, the so-called Ostrusha mound dates to the middle of the fourth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Otesini
    An ancient tribe of northern Italy, perhaps located in the vicinity of Bononia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Oued Cherchira Roman Bridge
    A bridge over the Oued Cherchira in Tunisia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Oxynion
    Oxynion is an unlocated settlement of Thessaly.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pachia Ammos Minoan Cemetery
    Minoan cemetery located on a sandy beach in use from very early times until the Late Minoan period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Padinates
    A people of Gallia Cispadana known from Pliny.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pagliano Roman port
    A riverine port near the confluence of the Tiber and Paglia rivers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Pagus Augustus Felix Suburbanus
    The ancient Pagus Augustus Felix Suburbanus corresponds to the territory of today's city of Boscoreale and Boscotrecase. Originating around 80 B.C. with the name of Pagus Felix Suburbanus, it included many farms.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pagus Epotius
    A pagus located in the civitas Vocontiorum, perhaps modern Upaix.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Palace G at Ebla
    Palace at Ebla dated to the early Bronze Age (24th century BCE), built atop the remains of an older palace (designated G2). Palace G, destroyed around 2300 BCE, contained an extensive archive of clay tablets.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Palace of Adad-nārārī III
    The Assyrian king Adad-nārārī III (r. 810-783 BC) constructed a palace for himself at Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud). This royal residence, whose walls were covered with white plaster and painted with geometric and floral motifs, was built immediately to the south of the palace of his great-grandfather Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palaiochora
    A fortified Medieval settlement of Aegina. Built in the ninth century, the site was the island's capital until 1826.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Palaiosouda (island)
    An islet also known as Marathi.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne
    Contributors:
  • Palamari
    A fortified site located on the island of Skyros with Early Bronze Age activity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Palatial complex at Pteria
    Enclosed area at the Iron Age city of Pteria (modern Kerkenes Dağ) containing an audience hall and other elite structures. The complex is in an area of the city that was destroyed by fire, most likely in the mid-5th century BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Palatial House at Rhodes
    A building at the foot of the Acropolis at Rhodes that occupied an entire insula and contained luxurious reception rooms and a large bath suite
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palatium Sessorianum
    Palatium Sessorianum is of unknown origins. It was situated at the extreme south-east of Region V and it adjoined the amphitheatrum Castrense. It pre-dated the Aurelian wall. The portions of the complex within the line of the walls was an imperial residence by the time of Constantine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Palazzo Barberini Mithraeum
    The Palazzo Barberini Mithraeum numbers among the best-preserved mithraic shrines in Rome. It is situated in via delle Quattro Fontane. Construction work revealed the site in 1936. A portion of the original structures of the second century CE was transformed into the mithraeum in the third century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Paleochristian Church, Lin
    A paleochristian church located in Lin, Korçë County, Albania, with fourth- and fifth-century mosaics.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Paleokastro, Nisyros
    The classical and Hellenistic period acropolis of the island of Nisyros dates from the sixth to the fourth century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Palma
    The Spanish village of Palma was located in the western part of the province of Córdoba. In the thirteenth century, it belonged to the kingdom of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Palmyrene Gate
    Main entrance gate in the western city walls of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Pānṛ I
    Buddhist temple complex in Swat, Pakistan occupied from the 1st century CE until the end of the 4th-5th centuries CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Pantanello necropolis
    Burial ground located 3.5 km west of Metaponto containing tombs dated from 600-280 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pantano di Grano necropolis
    A necropolis in the territory of Veii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Paradimi Neolithic Tomb
    Neolithic tomb located 1km east of the modern village of Paradiimi in Northeastern Greece.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Parco archeologico Griso-Laboccetta
    An Archaic to Hellenistic sanctuary sacred to Demeter.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Parque Arqueológico El Molinete
    An extensive urban archaeological area (more than 26,000 square meters) in Cartagena with archaeological horizons stretching from the third century BCE to the twentieth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Parys Mountain
    Parys Mountain is the site of ancient copper mining, with activity in the Bronze Age as well as in the Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pasas (island)
    A small island that is part of the Oinoussai island group, located between Chios and the Ionian peninsula. Its ancient name is unknown.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Patriarchal Basilica of Santa Maria Assunta of Aquileia
    The Basilica di Santa Maria Assunta, Aquileia dates originally to the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Paturro Roman villa
    A luxury terraced villa in Spain's Murcia region that was first built in the Republican period and then abandoned by the third century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pausilipum
    Pausilipum was an ancient Graeco-Roman settlement on the Bay of Naples.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Pavlopetri
    A now submerged Bronze Age settlement in coastal Laconia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pazarlı Höyük
    Settlement located about 30 km. from Alaca Höyük in modern Turkey's Çorum province. The site contains structures dated to the Neolithic, Hittite, and Phrygian periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Pecile at Hadrian's Villa
    An artificial terrace surrounding a large pond, 30 m wide x 116 m long, located at the western end of Villa Adriana.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Pedroches Roman Bridge
    A Roman bridge over the arroyo Pedroches near Corduba, Spain. The bridge lies along the ancient road to Augusta Emerita.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Pelargikon wall
    Pelargikon refers to a line of defensive walls located at the western foot of the Athenian Acropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Pelathousa Slag Heap
    A copper-smelting slag heap located in the village of Pelathousa in western Cyprus, dating to the 4th-6th century CE and likely derived from ore mined at the Limni mine, which is approximately 1 kilometer to the northwest.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Pellana (Mycenaean cemetery)
    Mycenaean chamber tombs located to the north of Pellana in Laconia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Pennymuir
    Temporary Roman marching camps along the line of Dere Street.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Penteskouphia
    A hill surmounted by a Frankish fortress located ca. 1200 m SW of Akrocorinth.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pentrich
    A Roman fortlet with a small rectangular earthwork lying within a larger enclosure.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Perrotte Aqueduct tunnel, aqueduct of Nimes
    The aqueduct tunnel known as the Tunnel de la Perrotte stretches for more than 60 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Persian and Hellenistic Administrative Building (PHAB), Tel Kedesh
    The Persian and Hellenistic Administrative Building was constructed at Tel Kedesh by the Persians in the mid-4th century BCE and was in use through the middle Hellenistic Period (around 143 BCE).
    Creators: AJ Adler; Kiel Papa
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Per-Sopdu
    Ancient Egyptian town that was the capital of the 20th nome of Lower Egypt and was a major cult site, dedicated to Sopdu, the god of the eastern borders of Egypt. The site is now under the modern town of Saft el-Hinna.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Peshwaran
    An archaeological site located in Afghanistan's Nimruz Province, some 25 km south of Lash Juwain. Materials on the site ate to the period between the ninth and thirteenth centuries. A large archaeological complex estimated at 9.5 by 13 km has been documented, containing numerous smaller sites. A large citadel is the primary feature of Peshwaran. It measured 200-300 m in diameter and had brick walls standing to 17 m in height. There were at least two large towers. According to Ball there has been no significant fieldwork since the works carried out in 1936 by the DAFA survey (Delegation Archaeologique Française en Afghanistan).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Petras Minoan Settlement
    Minoan palatial settlement located on a hill 1.5km from Seteia, Crete.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Phaleron cemetery (Attica)
    A cemetery at Phaleron with burials ranging in date from the Archaic to the Classical period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Phaneromeni Burials (Chiliomodi)
    A monumental sarcophagus of archaic date was excavated in situ in 1984 at a place known today as Phaneromeni in the eastern part of modern Chiliomodi's (Greece) village territory. Its location provides evidence for the urban extent of ancient Tenea.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Philopappos Monument
    The Philopappos Monument, located on Mouseion Hill in Athens, is a funerary monument dedicated to Caius Julius Antiochus Epiphanes Philopappos, a prince of the Kingdom of Commagene, and dates after 116 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Phocian Wall
    Herodotus describes the so-called Phocian Wall at Thermopylae as the most significant element of the built fortifications at the pass.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Phoenician cemetery at al-Bass
    Cemetery at the Al-Bass site in Tyre containing burials, funerary urns, and stelae dated to the Phoenician period (8th-6th century BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Pian della Conserva
    An Etruscan necropolis located 5 km from Tolfa with tombs stretching from the Orientalizing period to the later Hellenistic.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Pian del Vescovo
    The Pian del Vescovo is the western necropolis of Blera and perhaps the most extensive. A variety of tomb types dating to the seventh and sixth centuries BCE are attested.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pian di Mola necropolis
    A monumental rock-cut necropolis at Tuscania.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Piazza d'Oro at Hadrian's Villa
    One of the largest and most luxurious complexes of Villa Hadriani. It is situated at the northern end of the Villa, and consists of a vast building, with a vaulted, octagonal vestibule to the north, a cenatio to the south, and a central quadriporticus, down the middle of which runs a canal.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Piazza Pitagora
    An in situ segment of the Roman-period paving stones of the Via Salaria was discovered in Piazza Pitagora in 2022 during utility works.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Piazza Ronchi Roman cistern
    A Roman cistern dating to the second-third centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pierredon, Éguilles
    The Iron Age oppidum of Pierredon.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pietra Dell’Oglio (bridge)
    A Roman bridge crossing the Aufidus (modern Ofanto) river at the border between the modern Italian provinces of Campania and Basilicata. The bridge is one of two candidate identifications for the "Pons Aufidi" shown on the Peutinger map (the Ponte S. Venere), a possibility bolstered by recent comparative archaeological studies of the two bridges. The Pietra Dell'Oglio remains in use today for the Strada Comunale Fs di Monteverde, which connects to the Strada Statale 401 dir dell'Alto Ofanto e del Vulture at the southeast end of the bridge.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Pieve di San Giovanni Battista a Sillano
    A ruined church that was once part of the diocese of Volterra, San Giovanni Battista a Sillano is unique in Tuscany for having a Romanesque-Norman façade. The ruined edifice likely dates to the twelfth and thirteenth centuries although the parish exists as early as the mid-tenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pī-Kasî
    Site for the city of Pikasi dating back to the Old Babylonian period. A large number of cuneiform tablets were discovered there during excavations around year 2000.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Pimentel, Necropoli di S'Acqua Salida e di Corongiu
    A necropolis of the second millennium B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pini di Sirolo
    "I Pini di Sirolo" is the name given to the archaeological site of a Picene necropolis of the first millennium BCE in Italy's Marche region. The necropolis included a large tumulus of the sixth century BCE that included two chariots.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pi-Ramesses
    Capital city built by New Kingdom pharaoh Ramesses II at the modern Egyptian village of Qantir. The site is near the old capital, Avaris.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Pisuertes
    An ancient people of Umbria whose territory is now unlocated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Pitulum
    An ancient settlement in Umbria mentioned only by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Plattetombe of Waasmont
    The Plattetombe (flat tomb) is a Gallo-Roman burial bound of the second century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Platyskinos (settlement)
    Settlement on Crete from the Late Minoan period near Achladia.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Platyskinos Tholos Tomb
    A late Minoan tholos tomb in the area of modern Platyskinos/Platyschino on Crete.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Zachary Rosalinsky
  • Plinth in D Street Outside The Temple of Artemis Azzanthkona
    Probable statue base placed outside the temple of Artemis Azzanathkona at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Podere Cannicci (Civitella Paganico - GR)
    The site of Podere Cannici has been investigated by means of both non-invasive geophysics and by excavation. Data reveal multiple phases of activity and occupation.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Podere Tartuchino
    An Etruscan farm site located in the Albegna valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Poggibonsi
    Poggibonsi is an ancient and medieval center in the province of Siena on the Elsa river. The city sits along the Via Francigena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne; Tom Elliott
  • Poggino necropolis
    An Etruscan necropolis in Chianti in use between the seventh and fifth centuries BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Poggio all'Aglione
    A cistern likely connected with a Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Poggio Civitella
    The hill of Poggio Civitella near Montalcino, Italy, rises to a height of 661 meters above sea level. Beginning in 1993, excavation campaigns revealed a series of settlement horizons dating to the first millennium BCE, ranging from the archaic to the Hellenistic periods. The hilltop was fortified during this period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Poggio di Moscona
    The Poggio di Moscona is a hill on the northeastern edge of the plain of Grosseto and the basin of the ancient lake Prile.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Poggio la Guardia
    The site of a Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pokrovka-4 mound
    Burial mound near the Sentelek River in Altay, Russia, containing remains associated with the Afanasievo Culture (31st-29th centuries BCE) and the Pazyryk Culture (4th-3rd centuries BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Polygonal masonry wall
    An extant segment of a Polygonal masonry wall in Caiazzo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Polygonal wall of Signia
    The circuit wall of ancient Signia realized in polygonal masonry.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pompeii II.3.7 garden entrance
    Pompeii II, 3, 7 is a garden entrance linked to II, 3, 8 and II, 3,9. II, 3, 8 is identified as a workshop, either the Officina vasaria or caupona of Nicanor. This complex was positioned across the street from the Palaestra.
    Creators: Yuyao Liu
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pons Agrippae
    A debated bridge upriver from the modern Ponte Sisto.
    Creators: Echo Smith; Edward Keogh; Sara Hales
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Pont de Bornègre
    A Roman aqueduct bridge connected to the Roman aqueduct of Nîmes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Pont de Valmale
    The so-called Pont de Valmale is part of the Roman aqueduct system supplying Nîmes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pont du Diable (Céret)
    A Medieval bridge spanning the Tech river that dates between 1321 and 1341.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Acque Alte
    A Roman bridge along the Via Appia near Cisterna di Latina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Ponte Altinate
    A late Republican Roman segmented arch bridge in Padua, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Brabaciera
    A second century Roman bridge on the Riu Brabaciera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Caldaro
    A Roman bridge of the Via Flaminia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; John Muccigrosso
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Ponte Camillario
    A Roman bridge on the Via Cassia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Corvo
    A Roman segmental arch bridge across the Bacchiglione river in Padua, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte d'Arli
    A Roman bridge along the Via Salaria near Ascoli Piceno.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte d'Augusto
    A Iulio-Claudian bridge located in Ariminum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte del Diavolo
    A bridge in the territory of Blera known as the "Devil's Bridge".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte del Diavolo
    Site of an ancient Roman bridge across the Raganello near Civita. The ancient bridge was largely rebuilt in 2005.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte del Gran Caso
    A Roman bridge across the Torrente Gran Caso located south of Ascoli Piceno.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Ponte delle Chianche, Buonalbergo
    A Roman bridge of the second century A.D. along the Via Traiana that crosses the torrente Buonalbergo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte dell'Ospedalato
    A Roman bridge located near Praeneste.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Annibale
    An arched Roman bridge across the Titerno near Cerreto Sannita in Campania.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Annibale - Sant'Angelo
    A Roman bridge known by a variety of local toponyms that crosses the Savuto river. It is located in the modern Italian municipality of Altilia, Calabria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ponte di Apollo, Punicum
    A Roman bridge.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Capua
    A Roman bridge crossed the Volturno river at Capua, some elements of which remain in the site of modern bridge.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Nona
    A Roman-period bridge along the via Praenestina built of lapis Gabinus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Pietra
    A Roman segmental stone arch bridge located near Augusta Praetoria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Pioraco
    A single-arch Roman bridge built during the principate of Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Pratolungo
    Remains of a Roman Republican bridge crossing the Fosso di Pratolungo along the line of the via Tiburtina.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Ponte di San Lorenzo
    An early segmental arch bridge, built between 47 and 30 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte di Traiano
    A Trajanic bridge along the Via Appia that crosses the fosso Striscia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Etrusco, Gallese

    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Ettori
    A Roman bridge crossing the river Temo; the bridge is said to have originally had a five-arch span.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Ezzu
    Ponte Ezzu or Pont'Ezzu is a Roman bridge of the first century A.D. that crosses the Rio Mannu near Ozieri, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Maggie Britton; Sterling White
    Contributors: Thomas Landvatter
  • Ponte Fabio Massimo
    The so-called "Ponte Fabio Massimo" or "Ponte del Diavolo" originally dates to the third century BC with subsequent reworking and reuse continuing to the Middle Ages.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Fratto
    The remains of a late Republican bridge near Benevento (in Località Serretelle).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Funicchio
    A Roman bridge dating to the late second century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Gobbo
    A Medieval bridge across the river Trebia that is said to have Roman origins.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Leproso
    A bridge of Roman origins crossing the Sabato river on the outskirts of Benevento.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Ponte Lucano Roman Bridge
    A Roman bridge over the modern Aniene river adjacent to the Tomb of the Plautii, which is located north of the Villa of Hadrian at Tivoli.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ponte Lupo
    Remains of a portion of the Aqua Marcia aqueduct located near Gallicano nel Lazio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Molino
    A Roman segmental arch bridge across the Bacchiglione river in Padua, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Nomentano
    A Roman bridge over the Aniene river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Papaloppe
    A ruined bridge located near Nuoro in Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Romano Di Largo Impero, Santa Marinella
    The remains of a Roman bridge located in the comune of Santa Marinella.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte romano di Santa Giusta
    A Roman bridge dating between the first century BC and the first century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Romano di Viale Roma
    The ruins of a Roman bridge located in the Viale Roma, Santa Marinella, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Sanguinario (Narni)
    A Roman bridge located near Narni, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte sul Fosso Tre Ponti
    A Roman bridge on the Via Amerina between ancient Nepet and Falerii.
    Creators: W.V. Harris
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
  • Ponte Tufaro
    A bridge of Roman origins located near Montesarchio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ponte Valentino
    A Roman bridge located east of Benevento, Italy, and built by Flavius Iulius Valens.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pont gaulois dit de Sainte-Catherine
    The Gallic bridge of Sainte-Catherine is located at Kergonan, between the towns of Plounévézel (Finistère) and Treffrin (Côtes-d'Armor), in the Brittany region. It may date to the seventh century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pont Romà
    A Roman bridge on the island of Majorca (Pollença, Mallorca, Spain).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Por(d)oselene (island)
    An island between Lesbos and Asia Minor, attested in multiple ancient sources and site of the homonymous city. The island has been identified with the modern Cunda Adası, Turkey.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Porta Borsari
    A first century A.D. gate at Verona, the point at which the Via Postumia entered the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porta Collina
    A gate in Rome's Servian Wall located on the Quirinal Hill.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Porta Eburnea
    The so-called Porta Eburnea or the Arco della Mandorla is an ancient gate of the Etruscan walls of Perusia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porta Marzia
    The so-called Porta Marzia at Perugia began as a third century B.C. gate of the Etruscan city and was engulfed in the fortifications of the Rocca Paolina in 1540.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Porta Mediana necropolis
    Porta Mediana necropolis is a necropolis at Cumae containing some 70 tombs, dating from the fourth century BCE to the fifth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porta Metronia
    Porta Metronia, a gate in the Aurelian Walls of Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porta Mugonia
    The Porta Mugonia was one of the three gates of the original Palatine city of Rome (often referred to as "Roma quadrata"). Its precise location can no longer be established and it remains a hotly debated issue for topographers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Porta Portuensis
    The Porta Portuensis was one of the gates of the Aurelian Wall of Rome, located in the Transtiberim. The original gate carried an inscription of Honorius and was destroyed during the reign of Pope Urban VIII. The present Porta Portese, built by architect Vincenzo Maculani in 1644, occupies its site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Porta Salaria
    A gate of the Aurelian Walls of Rome (ca. 271-275 CE) by means of which the Via Salaria exited the city, heading northward. The date was damaged during the bombardment of Rome in 1870 and was subsequently replaced (1873). The replacement gate was demolished in 1921. The site of the Porta Salaria is today occupied by Piazza Fiume.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Porta Trasimena
    The Porta Trasimena or Arco di San Luca is a third-century B.C. gate in the Etruscan wall of Perusia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Porta Trigemina
    Now lost, the Porta Trigemina was one of the main gates of the Servian Wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Porta Vesuvio
    The so-called "Porta Vesuvio" was damaged in the earthquake of A.D. 62.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porticus Aemilia
    A utilitarian porticus and storage building located outside the Porta Trigemina, the Porticus Aemilia was erected in 193 BCE by Marcus Aemilius Lepidus and and Lucius Aemilius Paullus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porticus Liviae
    A complex dedicated in honor of Livia Drusilla in 7 BCE on the Esquiline Hill. The complex was erected on the site of the former estate of Vedius Pollio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porticus margaritaria
    A place located in regio VIII that was connected with jewelers. While the porticus itself is mentioned only in the Regionary Catalogues, numerous extant inscriptions attest to the shops of jewelers in the vicinity of the Sacra Via.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Porticus Pompei
    A porticus built in 55 B.C. in connection with the Theater of Pompey. The Curia Pompei, site of Iulius Caesar's assassination in 44 B.C., was likely located within the portico.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Elizabeth Robinson
  • Porticus Vipsania
    The Porticus Vipsania was a public complex located along the eastern side of the via Lata in the Campus Martius. This complex contained a map commissioned by Agrippa. The project was begun under Polla (Agrippa's sister) and completed under Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Portone necropolis at Volaterrae
    The so-called Portone necropolis is a major Hellenistic necropolis outside the walls of Volaterrae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Posta Vecchia
    Remains of a Roman imperial villa incorporated into a post office that later became a hotel.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Potto Codinu
    A necropolis in use from the Neolithic period through to the Iron Age with numerous hypogeum-type tombs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Poundbury hillfort
    A Middle Bronze Age hillfort near Dorchester, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pozzo sacro di Sa Testa
    An architectural complex dating to Sardinia's nuragic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Praedia Galbana
    A suburban tract of land located southwest of the Aventine Hill that would come to be the location of the Horrea Galbae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Praesidium Si Aioun
    A Roman fort along the Limes Tripolitanus in Africa Proconsularis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Praetorium at Gortyna
    The Praetorium at Gortyna dates to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Stefano Costa
    Contributors:
  • Pre-Mithraeum Building(s)
    Fragmentary remains of three phases of pre-Roman period buildings under the foundations of the Mithraeum at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Principia
    Military headquarters building at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Prokhorovka
    Burial ground with four mounds from the early Sarmatian period. The site is located near the modern town Prokhorovka in Orenberg Oblast, Russia.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Proposed location of Artulu 2 (Kayseri)
    Another proposed location of ancient Artulu is at or in the vicinity of modern Kayseri.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Propylaea at Athens
    A monumental gateway at the western end of the Athenian Acropolis. As an element of the Periklean remaking of the Athenian Acropolis, the Propylaea project commences in 437 BCE and concludes in 432 BCE, although the project was never fully realized. The architect Mnesikles is responsible for the Propylaea.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Public Bath of Pella
    The Public Bath at Pella is a bathing complex constructed and continuously renovated between the 4th and the 1st centuries BCE.
    Creators: Delaney Neal; Emily Hart
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Public building (?) area at Halos
    According to Reinders, the slope above the lower town of Halos was probably used for public buildings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Robin Iversen Rönnlund
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Public Square at Italica
    A small triangular plot near the northern wall of Italica that contained a garden in antiquity.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Puentecillas
    A bridge of Roman origin in Palencia, Spain, that was remodeled in the fifteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Puente Tablas Iberian Oppidum
    An Iberian settlement at the modern town of Puente Tablas (Jaén, Andalucia), with initial settlement in the late Bronze Age that continued until the 4th century BCE. The site was reoccupied during the Islamic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Puig Castellar (Biosca)
    A hilltop fortified site southwest of modern Biosca in Catalonia, Spain. The site exhibits architecture and pottery indicating its function as a Roman military castellum during the second century BCE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Puig de Castellet
    A pre-Roman oppidum located in the municipality of Lloret de Mar and occupied by the Ausetani. The site was short-lived and abandoned after the Roman conquest.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Puig des Molins necropolis
    A Carthaginian necropolis on the island of Ibiza.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Punic-Roman Sanctuary, Kamart
    A Punic-Roman sanctuary, possibly of Hygieia/Salus or Aesculapius/Eshmun was identified to the northwest of Carthage in the direction of Cape Kamart (Tunisia), mostly on the basis of an assemblage of extremely fragmentary polychromatic terracotta statues, numbering at least 30.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Punta de Muros
    A coastal fortified settlement dating to the late Bronze and early Iron Ages, known in modern times as Castro de Cociñadoiro and A Punta de Muros. The site was excavated ahead of its complete destruction in the first decade of the 21st century as part of the development of the Porto Exterior da Coruña at Punta Langosteira.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Puskan Castle
    Sassanid fort located about 3.5km south of the Iranian town Puskan. The fort is square shaped with a round tower at each corner.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Pust-i Gau
    A large, multi-period site in modern Afghanistan. One of its key feature is a large, fortified enclosure with 48 towers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Pustynka
    Late Bronze Age settlement on the Dnieper River in Northwestern Ukraine covering over 30,000 square meters.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Puy de Dôme volcano
    The Puy de Dôme volcano is a lava dome and volcano located in the Chaîne des Puys region of the Massif Central in France. This volcanic feature emerged approximately 10,700 years ago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pyla-Kokkinokremos
    A late Bronze Age settlement on Cyprus, abandoned after a brief occupation.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Pyramid K.1 at El-Kurru
    The oldest tomb at El-Kurru.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Pyrgouthi
    Settlement featuring a Hellenistic tower west of the cemetery in the Berbati Valley occupied from the Iron Age to the Early Roman period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Qalaat al-Madiq
    A town and medieval fortress in northwestern Syria adjacent to the site of ancient Apamea.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Qa`la Bost
    Qa`la Bost is an ancient fortress within the ancient city of Bust, located on the Helmand River in southern Afghanistan and overseeing a major crossroads linking Kandahar and India to eastern Iran. Standing remains at the site predominantly date to the Islamic Middle Ages, but archaeological finds suggest an occupational history dating back to at least the first millennium BCE.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Qal‘at ‘Awaynah
    Stronghold with traces of Assyrian buildings where inscribed blocks have been found. Possibly ancient Alše.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Qal’eh-i Imam
    Qal’eh-i Imam (“Imam Fortress”), also call Qal’eh-i Marivan (“Marivan Fortress”), is one of the most important castles and fortresses in the Kurdistan Province, Marivan District, Iran. This now-ruined military fortification played a key role during the Safavid Period (1502–1737) and was an administrative venter of Ardalanians and Babanians rulers in Kurdistan. The discovery of a stele fragment of the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in the drystone wall enclosing one of the buildings of the village Barqaleh might attest to a settlement there in the eighth century BC.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Qaleh Kharabeh fortress
    A fifth-century fort in the modern Iranian province of Golestan, located two kilometers south of the Great Wall of Gorgan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Qalhat
    An ancient city in Oman that was a key location for Indian Ocean trade networks.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Qamişvan/Değirmendüzü
    Değirmendüzü (formerly Qamişvan/Kamişvan) is a modern village situated ca. 8 km in the east of Pathos (Aznavurtepe / Anzavurtepe) in the Ağrı Province in eastern Turkey. Here a column base with an inscription of the Urartian king Minua, son of Išpuini (9th/8th century BCE) has been found (CTU I A 5-70)
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Qasr al-Abd at Tyrus
    A Hellenistic palace constructed in the second century CE at the southern end of the Tyrus/'Iraq al-Amir site.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Qasr el-Sagha temple
    Temple located north of Lake Qarun in the Fayyum Depression. Tentatively dated to the Old Kingdom period, the temple may have been dedicated to the god Sobek.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Qasr Libya, West Church
    At Qasr Libya, the ancient Theodorias, two churhes have been identified. The Byzantine settlement was refounded under Justinian in 539 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Qidfaʻ 1
    Site of a 2nd millennium BCE tomb located in Qidfaʻ, Fujairah Emirate, United Arab Emirates. The site was damaged by farming in the area.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Qlejgħa tal-Baħrija
    Plateau on the western coast of Malta that was the site of a village in the Middle and Late Bronze Age (ca. 15th century BCE-8th century BCE). The site shows additional, lesser signs of human activity dated to the Phoenician, Punic, and Roman periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Quarries at Aquae Albulae
    Travertine quarries in the vicinity of Tibur and Aquae Albulae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; L. Quilici; S. Quilici Gigli
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; R. Talbert
  • Quarries at Molara (Grottaferrata)
    Stone quarries at Molara (Grottaferrata, Italy). Caves produced by quarry activity were also sites of paleochristian activity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Quartucciu
    The archaeological site of Pill'è Matta preserves remains of a Punic-Roman necropolis in use from the fourth century B.C. until the fifth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Quinta da Bolacha
    A Roman villa located near several productive sites.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rabana-Merquly
    A major, but relatively short-lived, fortified site in the Zagros mountains of modern Iraqi Kurdistan comprising two settlement loci within a large fortified area. Remains include stone foundations for mudbrick fortification walls and buildings, a stone-cut stairway, and two rock-reliefs depicting an unnamed ruler in elaborate costume. The complex has some evidence for reoccupation in Sasanian, Islamic and modern times.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Thomas Mertens
  • Rabati Malik
    An eleventh-century caravanserai along the Silk Road, now located in Uzbekistan. Rabati Malik Caravanserai was built under Karakhanid Shams-al-Mulk Nasr, son of Tamgachkhan Ibragim who ruled in Samarkand from 1068 to 1080. The site was added to the UNESCO World Heritage Tentative List in 2008.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Radlett
    A Roman villa and bath building, dating between the second and fourth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Radwell Roman villa
    A Roman villa site in Hertfordshire, England, Radwell Roman villa is located 500 meters west of Ermine Street and some 4 km north of the small Roman town at Baldock.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rainsborough Camp
    A bivallate Iron Age hillfort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ramappa Temple
    A thirteenth-century temple that was built during the period of the Kakatiya ruler Ganapati Deva.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ras ben Sakka
    The northernmost point of the continent of Africa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ras Siyyan
    A peninsula in the Obock Region of Djibouti located on the Bab-el-Mandeb strait between the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Pierre Schneider
  • Rathgall Hillfort
    Rathgall Hillfort is a multivallate Bronze Age fort located in County Wicklow, Province of Leinster, Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rathlin Island
    An island offshore from modern Northern Ireland with evidence of human habitation stretching back to the Mesolithic period. It is one possible identification for an ancient "Riginia" island mentioned in ancient sources.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Ravenglass Roman Bath House
    The Ravenglass Roman Bath House, also known as "Walls Castle", is linked to the second-century CE fort at Glannoventa. English Heritage dates the site ca. 130 and deems it one of the tallest surviving Roman ruins in Britain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Razliq
    Razliq is a village situated ca. 13 km north of the city Sarāb in Eastern Azerbaijan (Iran). Here a rock inscription of the Urartian king Argišti II, son of Rusa (end of 8th / first half of 7th century BCE), has been found which reports military campaigns of Argišti II to this region. As well as the rock inscription of Nashteban (CTU A 11-5) it is situated on the southern slope of the Sabalān Mountains at an altitude of 4810 m. Although the inscription reports the building of a fortress named ‘stronghold of Argišti’ no such archaeological remains have been discovered so far. Together with the rock inscriptions found in Nashteban (CTU A 11-5) and Shisheh (CTU A 11-6) the rock inscription found near Razliq is one of the Urartian inscriptions found furthest to the east.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Redones
    A Celtic tribe living in the area of modern Brittany counted among the civitates maritimae or Aremorica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio II (Caelimontium)
    According to the Regionary Catalogues, Regio II contained 7 streets (vici), 7 shrines, 3,600 blocks of flats, 127 houses, 27 grain warehouses (horrea), 85 bath-houses; 65 cisterns; 15 bakeries/mills, and had a circumference of 12,200 paces. The region had 48 vicomagistri and 2 curators.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio III (Isis et Serapis)
    The third Augustan administrative region of the city of Rome was centered on the Oppian Hill and derived its name from the Isis et Serapis on the Via Praenestina. In addition to the named monuments, the region included 12 streets, 12 shrines, 2,757 blocks of flats, 60/160 houses, 17 horrea, 80 bathhouses, 65 cisterns, and 16 bakeries or mills. The region had 48 magistrates and two curators. The perimeter of the region was 12,350 Roman feet.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio III, Ostia Antica
    The third region of ancient Ostia comprises the western sector of the archaeological area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio III, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio III, a largely unexcavated archaeological subdivision located in the northeastern section of Pompeii, contains a mix of residential and commercial structures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Regio II, Ostia Antica
    The second of Ostia's archaeological regions.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio II, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio II, an archaeological subdivision located in the eastern section of Pompeii, includes the Amphitheater and the Large Palaestra, as well as a number of residences and commercial structures.
    Creators: Yuyao Liu
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio I, Ostia Antica
    The first archaeological region of Ostia includes the area of the forum and elements of the original Republican castrum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio I, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio I, an archaeological subdivision located in the southeastern section of Pompeii, contains a mixture of residences and commercial structures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio I (Porta Capena)
    Regio I (Porta Capena), one of the administrative regions of the city of Rome instituted by Augustus in 7 BCE. In addition to the named monuments and buildings, the Regionary Catalogues indicate that this district also included 10 vici (streets), 10 shrines (aediculae), 3,250 blocks of apartment buildings (insulae); 120 houses (domus); 16 grain warehouses (horrea); 86 bath-houses (balinea); 81 or 87 cisterns/fountains (lacos), and 20 bakeries or mills (pistrina). Its administrative apparatus included 48 vicomagistri and two curators (curatores). Its circumference is given as 12,211 paces (pedes).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio IV, Ostia Antica
    The fourth region of the city of Ostia includes the Porta Marina and its surroundings, as well as extramural baths, tombs, and the Ostia Synagogue.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio IV, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio IV is a largely unexcavated archaeological subdivision located in the northeastern section of Pompeii.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio IV (Templum Pacis)
    The fourth Augustan region of Rome includes the Subura as well as the valley between the Esquiline and the Viminal hills, along with the no-longer-extant Velian Hill. This region reportedly contained eight shrines (aediculae), 88 domūs, 18 warehouses (horrea), 75 bath houses, and 78 loci. Its perimeter is given as 13,000 Roman feet (approximately 3.84 km).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio IX (Circus Flaminius)
    The ninth administrative region of the city of Rome was created under the Augustan reforms of 7 BCE. According to the Notitia et Curiosum, this region contained 35 shrines (aediculae), 140 townhouses (domūs), 25 warehouses (horrea), 63 bathhouses, and 120 fountains). The region was subdivided into 35 vici (districts) and 2,777 insulae (blocks). It had two curators and 48 Roman magistrates.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio IX, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio IX, an archaeological subdivision located in the central section of Pompeii, contains a mix of residential and commercial structures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio V (Esquiliae)
    The fifth Augustan administrative region of the city of Rome, the Esquiliae took its name from the Esquiline Hill. It includes parts of the Oppian and Cispian hells, as well as areas outside of the Servian agger. Its northern limits were marked by the Vicus Patricius and the Clivus Suburanus bounded it to the east. The fourth-century sources estimate the region's perimeter as 15,600 Roman feet (approximately 4.61km). In addition to the named monuments, Regio V contained 15 aediculae (shrines), 180 domūs (patrician houses), 22 horrea (warehouses), 75 balneae (baths), and 74 fountains.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio VI (Alta Semita)
    The sixth administrative regio of Augustan Rome, Regio VI (Alta Semita) derives its name from the street that crossed over the Quirinal Hill. This is a large district that includes the Viminal Hill, the lower slopes of the Pincian Hill, in addition to the valleys between these hills. The region also contained 17 aediculae (shrines), 146 domūs (patrician houses), 18 horrea (warehouses), 75 bath houses, and 73 fountains.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio VIII (Forum Romanum)
    The eighth administrative region of ancient Rome was created by the Augustan reforms of 7 BCE. Regio VIII contained 34 shrines (aediculae), 130 townhouses (domūs), 18 warehouses (horrea), 85 baths (balneae), and 120 fountains.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio VIII, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio VIII, an archaeological subdivision located in the southwestern section of Pompeii, contains a theatre, a sanctuary dedicated to Venus, and a mix of residential, administrative, and commercial structures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio VII, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio VII, an archaeological subdivision located in the central western section of Pompeii, contains a mix of residential and commercial structures, as well as the Stabian Baths.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Regio VII (Via Lata)
    Regio VII (Via Lata) was one of the administrative regions of the city of Rome instituted by Augustus in 7 BCE. In addition to the named monuments and buildings, the Regionary Catalogues indicate that this district also included 15 shrines (aediculae), 120 townhouses (domūs), 25 warehouses (horrea), 75 baths (balneae), and 76 fountains.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio VI, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio VI, an archaeological subdivision located in the northwestern section of Pompeii, contains shops and residential buildings, including the House of the Faun.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio V, Ostia Antica
    The fifth archaeological region of Ostia is bounded to the north by the Decumanus Maximus and extends southward.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio V, Pompeii
    The so-called Regio V, a largely unexcavated archaeological subdivision located in the northern section of Pompeii, contains a mixture of commercial and domestic structures, including a gladiators' barracks.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Regio XI (Circus Maximus)
    The eleventh region of Rome created under the Augustan administrative division. According to the Regionary catalogues, this region contained 19 shrines (aediculae), 89 townhouses (domūs), 16 warehouses (horrea), 15 bath houses), and 20 fountains).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio XIII (Aventinus)
    The thirteenth administrative region of ancient Rome was created by Augustus in 7 BCE. This district contained 17 shrines (aediculae), 130 townhouses (domūs), 35 warehouses (horrea), 60 bath houses, and 88 fountains in addition to a list of monuments enumerated in the Regionary Catalogues.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio XII (Piscina Publica)
    The twelfth administrative region of ancient Rome was created in 7 BCE by Augustan reforms.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio XIV (Transtiberim)
    The fourteenth regio of imperial Rome was created by the Augustan administrative reform of 7 BCE. This region contained, in addition to the named monuments, the statio of the seventh cohort of the Vigiles, 78 shrines (aediculae), 150 townhouses, 22 warehouses (horrea), 86 bathhouses, and 180 fountains. At the beginning of the fifth century, the Regio was subdivided into 78 districts or vici and 4,405 insulae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Regio X (Palatium)
    Regio X (Palatium) is one of the Augustan regions of the city of Rome. The Regionary Catalogues indicate that this regio contained 20 shrines (aediculae), 89 townhouses (domūs), 48 warehouses (horrea), 44 bath houses, and 89 fountains. Its perimeter was recorded as 11,510 Roman feet (approx. 3.4 km).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Remains of Sasanian Persian Siege Ramp in Dura-Europos
    Ramp associated with Sasanian Persian siege and eventual fall of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Remstecken
    Site of a Roman villa rustica, dating from the first to third centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Restormel
    A Roman fortlet overlooking the River Fowey.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ribadiso Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge located in the Provincia da Coruña, Galicia, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ribchester Roman Bath House
    Roman baths at Ribchester dating ca. 100 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rieti survey area
    An archaeological field survey carried out in the territory of Rieti from 1988 to 1991.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rio Maior
    A Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • River Gate
    Gate in the eastern city walls of Dura-Europos, no longer extant.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Rocca Calascio
    A tenth-century fortress located in the Province of L'Aquila in Abruzzo, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rocca Guidonesca di Rocchettine
    A ruined twelfth-century castle located in the Italian comune of Torri in Sabina
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rocca Sillana
    A Medieval fortress in the modern territory of Pisa, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Rochemaure milestone
    A Roman milestone of the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Rock Carvings in Tanum
    The Rock Carvings in Tanum is a collection of petroglyphs located near Tanumshede, Bohuslän, Sweden. This heritage landscape is composed of at least 600 rock-cut panels covering an area of some 51 ha (126 acres). Many of the figural motifs are maritime in nature and pertain to the European Bronze Age.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Rock inscription near ‘Ayn-i Rūm
    Site for Urartian rock inscription.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Röekillorna Spring
    A spring that was a cult site used in the Early Neolithic, Middle Neolithic, Late Neolithic, Early Bronze Age, pre-Roman Iron Age, and Roman Iron Age, the Röekillorna Spring is located in modern south-east Scania, Sweden.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Rollright Stones
    A complex of three Neolithic and Bronze Age megalithic monuments dating from the fourth to second millennia B.C. located on the borders of Oxfordshire and Warwickshire in the English Midlands.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman amphitheater at Abella
    The Roman amphitheater at Abella has been compared to the amphitheater of Pompeii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Album Ingaunum/Albingaunum
    The Roman amphitheater at Albegna.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman amphitheater at Amiternum
    A Roman amphitheater dating to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman amphitheater at Ariminum
    The Roman amphitheater at Ariminum is dated to the second century, perhaps during the reign of Hadrian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Augusta Raurica
    The Roman amphitheater at Augusta Raurica accommodated ca. 13,000 spectators and was built ca. A.D. 170.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Bern
    The remains of a small Roman amphitheater at Bern, measuring ca. 27.5 x 25.3 meters, are visible on satellite images.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker

    The Roman amphitheater at Bulla Regia
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

  • Roman amphitheater at Carsulae
    The Roman amphitheater at Carsulae dates to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

    The Roman amphitheater at Cyzicus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman amphitheater at Emporiae
    The Roman amphitheater at Emporiae developed during the second century. It is located outside the city walls.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Eporedia
    The extramural Roman amphitheater at Eporedia is evidence of the expanding suburbium of the Roman settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:

    The Roman amphitheater of Flavia Solva.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman amphitheater at Grumentum
    Grumentum's amphitheater (first century B.C.) is the only known example in Lucania. The arena measures ca. 62.5 by 60 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Interamnia Praetuttiorum
    A Roman amphitheater of the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Iol Caesarea
    The Roman amphitheater at Iol Caesarea was of moderate size, with room for about 16,000 spectators.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Libarna
    The remains of the Roman amphitheater at Libarna are located in Serravalle Scrivia, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Lucera
    An amphitheater dating to the time of Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Lucus Feroniae
    The Roman amphitheater at Lucus Feroniae was financed by one M. Silius Epaphroditus, who in turn received the title patronus. The structure dates to the reign of Tiberius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Marruvium
    The Roman amphitheater at Marruvium measures 95 by 75 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman amphitheater at Patavium
    The Roman amphitheater at Patavium dates to the Augustan period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:

    An amphitheater that originated under Hadrian and that was then rebuilt in stone ca. A.D. 157.

    The Roman amphitheater at Sipous/Sipontum.

    The Roman amphitheater at Theveste dates to the fourth century.

    The Roman amphitheater at Trebula dates to the Augustan period.

  • Roman amphitheater at Tusculum
    Today the Roman amphitheater at Tusculum is poorly preserved. These ruins have never been systematically investigated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

    An extramural Roman amphitheater was to be found at Vercellae.

    The ruins of a sizable Roman amphitheater at Volaterrae came to light in 2016.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker

    Remains of a Roman aqueduct.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman aqueduct, Spello
    An aqueduct carrying water to Spello from the hills below Collepino.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman arch (Medinaceli)
    A triple-bay Roman Imperial arch near Medinaceli, Spain, that was originally dedicated to the emperor Domitian and later re-dedicated to Trajan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman bath at Fregellae
    A two-phase complex of public baths at Fregellae dating to the third and second centuries BCE represents an important point in the transition from "Greek" bathing culture to "Roman" bathing culture.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Bath-House at Little Chart, Kent
    The remains of a Roman bath house were discovered in a field to the west of the village of Little Chart, Kent in 1942. These remains included fragments of mosaic pavement. Excavations in 1942 and later in 1947 identified the site as a Roman bathing complex.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman bath house, Callendar Park, Falkirk
    The remains of a Roman bath house were discovered in Callendar Park, Falkirk in 1980.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Bath House, Prestatyn
    At the Prestatyn Roman Site, a bath complex was identified via excavation (1934-7; 1981). The bathhouse measures approximately 11.7 by 4.5 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman baths at calle Reyes Huertas
    The Roman baths at calle Reyes Huertas date to the third century CE. They were located outside of the ancient city center in an area that has been categorized as industrial. Their exact nature is difficult to determine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman baths at Carnuntum
    The Roman baths at Carnuntum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman baths at Fundi
    Imperial baths located on Fundi's decumanus maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman baths, Carsulae
    Baths of the early imperial period at Carsulae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; John Muccigrosso
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman baths, Malvindi
    The remains of Roman baths located in the ager of Mesagne.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Baths of Como
    The Roman Baths of Como were in use from the later first century until the third century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Baths (Parium)
    Public baths at Parium used from the second century BCE and renovated several times in the late Roman and Byzantine periods, likely being used until at least the seventh century CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Roman baths, Spoleto
    Roman baths located at Spoletium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman bridge at Habitancum
    Structural remains of a Roman bridge located on the River Rede in the vicinity of Habitancum Roman fort. The bridge lay along the ancient Watling Street.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman bridge over Rio S'Adde
    Remains of a Roman bridge, north of Makopsisa (modern Macomer in Sardinia).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman Camp
    One of two Roman siege camps at Burnswark Hill that flank the Iron Age hillfort. The camps are linked to the campaigns of the Roman commander Quintus Lollius Urbicus ca. 140 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman circus of Carthage
    The circus of Carthage could accommodate ca. 45,000 spectators and may date to the third century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman cistern
    A Roman cistern of the early second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman colonia at York

    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Roman Countermine Near Tower 19
    Subterranian mine aimed at deterring the Sasanian Persian siege and eventual fall of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman dam of Nossa Senhora da Represa
    A Roman dam in Cuba, Portugal, that takes its colloquial name from a nearby chapel, thus it is referred to as Nossa Senhora da represa or 'Our lady of the dam'.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Fortress at York

    Creators: Scott Vanderbilt; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Charlotte Tupman
  • Roman forum at Cupra Maritima
    The Roman forum at Cupra Maritima.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman harbor at Carthage
    Roman engineers began modifying the Punic harbor by the late second century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman Mausoleum
    A Roman tower-type tomb that some local traditions label as the tomb of Cnaeus Pompeius Magnus. The structure is located at the so-called Villa di Pompeo, south of Castel Gandolfo in Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman mausoleum at Bou Arada
    The mausoleum of Caius Iulius Augustus Felix in Bou Arada, Tunisia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman Mausoleum at Palio Scholeio (Chiliomedio)
    A monumental Roman mausoleum, originally installed over a Hellenistic cemetery, was excavated in 2017 at a site known as "Old School" to the south of modern Chiliomedio in Greece. Its location helps indicate the extent and date of cemeteries at the ancient site of Tenea.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman Military Palace
    Palace building located at the northeast within the military sector at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman necropolis at al-Bass
    The Tyre necropolis, part of the UNESCO World Heritage site of Tyre, contains a triumphal arch and hundreds of stone sarcophagi dated to the Roman and Byzantine periods. It is located adjacent to an older Phoenician burial site.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Roman necropolis at Carmo
    A necropolis of the Roman period wherein most tombs date between the first century BC and the second century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman necropolis at Melano
    Roman necropolis in the modern town of Melano, Switzerland, containing 29 burials dated to the 1st-2nd centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Roman necropolis at Šempeter v Savinjski Dolini
    Šempeter v Savinjski Dolini lies along the former Roman road from Aquilea to Poetovio. The necropolis, dating to the first through third centuries A.D., may be associated with anicent Celeia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Romano-British Bath House
    A bathhouse located at Orpington, Kent was excavated between 1971 and 1975. The site flourished between ca. 270 and 400 CE. Its post-abandonment phase includes Anglo-Saxon graves of the fifth and sixth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman Odeon of Gortyn
    The Roman Odeon of Gortyn dates to the first century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman odeon, Vienne
    The Roman odeon at Vienne.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman quarries of Cartagena
    Sandstone quarries located some 4 km west of Cartagena, in the Diputación de Canteras.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman quarry of Antas
    A Roman quarry located approximately 800 meters from the Temple of Antas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman road
    The remains of a Roman road in southeastern Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman road, Catribana
