    The remains of a paved Roman road near Catribana in Portgual that is part of a cultural heritage assemblage that includes a bridge and ancient water mills.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman temple, Capo Mulini
    The remains of an early Imperial Roman temple on Sicily's Cape Mulini.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman temples at Chieti
    Structures thought to be temples set within a sacred area that includes a sacred well.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Amiternum
    The Roman theater at Amiternum could seat approximately 2,000 people. It was abandoned after the fourth century and became a necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Roman theater at [Augusta] Ambianorum
    The Roman theater lies to the east of the ancient settlement.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Casinum
    The Roman theater at Casinum dates to the Augustan period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Gortyna
    The Roman theater at Gortyna dates to the second century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Stefano Costa
  • Roman theater at Interamnia Praetuttiorum
    A Roman theater dating to the Augustan period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Italica
    The Roman theater at Italica could accommodate 3,000 spectators. It predates the Hadrianic rebuilding of the city.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Iuvanum
    The Roman theater at Iuvanum is located at the foot of the acropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Libarna
    The Roman theater at Libarna dates to the first century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Metellinum
    The Roman theater at Metellinum (modern Medelin, Spain) dates to the late first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Ocriculum
    The Roman theater at Ocriculum dates to the early imperial period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Pelusium
    The Roman theater at Pelusium (Tell Farama).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Perge
    The Roman theater at Perge was built ca. 120 AD and renovated ca. 250 AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater, Atri
    The Roman theater of Atri.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Soloi/Aipeia?
    The Roman theater at Soloi, Cyprus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Suessa Aurunca
    The Roman theater at Suessa Aurunca was built in the first century A.D. and then restored under Antoninus Pius. Amedeo Maiuri initiated excavations at the theater site in the 1920s. The excavation was not completed until 2003.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Sufetula
    The Roman theater at Sufetula.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Teate
    The Roman theater at Teate measures 80 meters in diameter.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Terracina
    The ancient Roman theater of Terracina dates from the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Thignica
    The Roman theater at Thignica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Tusculum
    The Roman theater at Tusculum was first excavated in 1839.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Utica
    The Roman theater at Utica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater at Verona
    The Roman theater at Verona dates from the late first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater, Jublains
    The Roman theater at modern Jublains.
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Roman theater of Adraha
    Ruins of a Roman theater located at modern Dar'a in Syria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Roman theater of Privernum
    The Roman theater of Privernum is attested mainly by means of epigraphic evidence.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater of Vienne
    A first century Roman theater in Vienne.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater, Singilia Barba
    The Roman theater of Singilia Barba
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman theater, Tipasa
    The Roman theater at Tipasa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Roman Theatre at Caere
    The Roman theater at Caere (modern Cerveteri, Italy) is known especially for the sculptural program honoring Julio-Claudian emperors, including Tiberius and Claudius.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Roman vicus and harbor at Lousonna
    The site is located in modern Lausanne-Vidy
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa
    Archaeological remains of modest Roman villas in the theater district of Colonia Iulia Carthago.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa
    Remains of an early imperial period Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa at Híjar en Las Gabias
    A Roman villa, of which the pars fructuaria has been excavated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa at Santa Lucia
    A villa constructed in the 4th century CE.
    Creators: Qianli Jiang
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Roman villa at Santo André de Almoçageme
    A Roman villa located in Santo André de Almoçageme, Sintra, Portugal, and occupied from the second to the sixth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa at Tourmont
    Remains of a large Roman villa and site of a significant coin hoard of the third century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa of Capo di Massa
    A villa at the Capo di Massa that has frequently been associated with Pollius Felix, a magistrate from Puteoli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa of Cortijo Robledo
    A Roman villa rustica dated between the first and fifth centuries. The site occupies a low hill located to the south of Cerro de Robledo, near the Roman settlement of Aratispi. Archaeological fieldwork has demonstrated that the site was involved in the production of olive oil until the later Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa of Valle Mara, Sant’Angelo Romano (RM)
    The remains of a Roman platform villa complex located to the south of the comune of Sant'Angelo Romano in Lazio. The complex is dated to the late republican period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman villa, via Michelangelo Tilli
    The remains of the Roman villa located in via Michelangelo Tilli are located close to the Aniene. The late republican villa remained in use until the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman wall, Gijon
    A Roman fortification wall that dates initially to the third or fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Roman walls of Lugo
    Late Roman fortifications.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Rotes Haus (Tell Schech Hamad)
    The so-called "Red House" is a large building at Dūr-Katlimmu that was built and occupied between the sixth and fifth centuries BCE. The structure included administrative, reception, and living areas, and a few Assyrian cuneiform texts were recovered during its excavation.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Sebastian Hageneuer
  • Rowberrow Camp
    Rowberrow Camp is the site of an Iron Age defended settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Royal Palace of Māri
    Royal residence of the rulers of the kingdom of Mari. Constructed in the 24th century BCE, the site is also known as the Palace of Zimri-Lim, the ruler who completed extensive renovations of the structure around 1800 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Royal Palace V at Pergamum
    The so-called Palace V has been interpreted as a royal residence at Pergamum containing a peristyle watered by cisterns. It is noted for its mosaic decoration.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Royat Roman Baths
    Ruins of Roman baths at Royat, France, that were listed as a registered monument in 1889.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Rukeis
    A fortress or fortified settlement in northern Jordan dated to the Middle Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Rutland Roman Villa
    A Roman villa, identified and initially excavated since 2018, located in the modern district of Rutland (England, United Kingdom), east of Foster's Bridge and southwest of Ketton.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Ruzai
    A Roman municipium, listed on the Peutinger map on a route between "Syda" (Bida, modern Djemaa Saharidj, Tunisia) and Saldae (modern Béjaïa, Algeria) whose precise location cannot be determined today.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Saar al-Jisr Burial Field
    Burial ground near the Dilmun temple at Saar also from the Dilmun culture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Saar Site
    Early Dilmun settlement founded as early as 2300 BCE, with the main phase of the town being built around 1900 BCE. The site, which is located in modern Bahrain, continued in use around 100-200 years after the establishment of this main phase.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sabratha amphitheater
    The Sabratha amphitheater dates to the later second century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sa Carcaredda
    A nuragic complex consisting of a 'megaron-type' temple and a giant's grave.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sace
    An ancient oppidum near the Red Sea in the Sudan mentioned by Pliny the Elder.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sacred Animal Necropolis (Ṣaqqārah)
    Sacred Animal Necropolis at North Ṣaqqārah, Egypt, used from the Archaic to the Ptolemaic Period, with the remains of the Christian settlement of Apa Antinos superimposed upon the remains of the necropolis.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sacred well of Predio Canopoli
    The sacred well of Predio Canopoli is a monument of the nuragic culture located in Perfugas, Sassari province, in front of the present parish church of Santa Maria degli Angeli. The well is built of isodomic blocks of limestone
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sagzabad Cluster
    Group of three Neolithic, Bronze, and Iron Age tells located in Iran's Qazvin Plain.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Saidu Sharif Monastery
    Buddhist monastery in Saidu Sharif, Swat, Pakistan with a stupa and a courtyard. The site was likely in use from the 1st through 5th centuries CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert
    The abbey of Saint-Guilhem-le-Desert or Abbey Gellone, is Benedictine abbey founded in A.D. 804 by Guillaume Gellone. The abbey is a listed historical monument in France and was listed on the UNESCO World Heritage list in 1998 .
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Saint-Martin-le-Bas, Gruissan
    An archaeological site covering some 3 ha in the modern French commune of Gruissan (Aude department), with occupation beginning in the first century BCE and continuing to Late Antiquty.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Saint-Nizier-sous-Charlieu
    The site of a Gallo-Roman villa known since 1884.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Plancard
    The Chapel of Saint Jean is built atop a temple once dedicated to Iuppiter Optimus Maximus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Romain-en-Gal
    An urban quarter of Roman Vienne, now presented as an archaeological museum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Saphorin
    A Roman villa located near the shores of Lake Geneva.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Saturnin-du-Bois Gallo-Roman villa
    Remains of an extensive Gallo-Roman villa located in the modern French commune of Saint-Saturnin-du-Bois (Charente-Maritime department).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Saint Simeon Monastery (Aswan, Egypt)
    The fortified Saint Simeon Monastery (Aswan, Egypt) originally dates to the seventh century. It was initially sacred to the local saint Anba Hedra. The site was rebuilt in the tenth century and re-dedicated to Saint Simeon. The monastery was partially destroyed by Saladin in 1173.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Saint-Thibéry Roman Bridge
    A segmental arch bridge on the Via Domitia in southern France, typically dated to the reign of Augustus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Salkhityn Am
    Cemetery site in northern Mongolia containing 35 burials dated to the Early Xiongnu period (200-50 BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • S'Altare de Logula
    The Tomb of the Giants Sa Perda 'e S'Altare is a giants' tomb located in the municipality of Birori, province of Nuoro, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Salteras
    An ancient and medieval Spanish village located north of Sevilla that belonged to the thirteenth-century kingdom of Alfonso X.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Salut
    Settlement in Oman featuring a castle, inhabited from the Early Bronze Age to the early Islamic Period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sam'alla (kingdom)
    Sam'alla (šmʾl; also known as Bīt-Gabbāri and yʾdy) was a small Aramean kingdom/city-state during the first half of the first millennium BC. It is named after its capital city Sam'al (modern Zincirli Höyük).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sam'alla (province)
    The eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Shalmaneser V (r. 726-722 BC) conquered Sam'al and its territory and established the city as the administrative capital of an Assyrian province named after it.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Šamaš Gate
    The Šamaš Gate, which was given the Akkadian ceremonial name Šamaš-mušakšid-ernittīya ("The God Šamaš Is the One Who Makes Me Triumph"), is the first of the eight city gates of Dūr-Šarrukīn ("Fort Sargon") listed by Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) in inscriptions recording the construction of his new capital. This gate is the first of the east-facing entrances to the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Šamaš temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the god Šamaš.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Samḥa (island)
    Samḥa is located between the main island of Socotra and Somalia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Basilio
    A Roman bath complex that was reused first as a monastic complex and then as the Medieval church of San Basilio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctae Mariae in Palmis
    A Medieval Christian sanctuary along the Via Appia, perhaps best known as the Church of Domine Quo Vadis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Sanctuaries of Apollo Deiradiotes and Athena Oxyderkes
    At Argos, Pausanias mentions both the sanctuary of Apollo Deiradiotes (Apollo of the ridge) and the sanctuary of Athena Oxyderkes (Athena the clear-sighted).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary 18/19
    Small temple building E7-19 with tenemos E7-18 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sanctuary at Fondo Iozzino
    An extra-urban sanctuary located outside of the Porta Nocera of Pompeii. Excavations at the sanctuary have revealed votive activity in multiple periods, including the pre-Roman phases of Pompeii. Inscribed bucchero pottery indicates connections with leading Etruscan families of central Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary at San Casciano dei Bagni
    An ancient sanctuary located near the village of San Casciano dei Bagni, located south of Siena, Italy, has produced, following archaeological excavation, a large cache of metallic votive offerings - coins, figurines, statue, anatomical votives - dating to the late republican and early imperial periods. These votives were recovered from waterlogged mud deposits associated with the thermal springs at the site that have been frequented since at least the first millennium BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary of Aphrodite Paphia
    A major sanctuary to Aphrodite on Cyprus; activity is found as early as the 3rd millennium BCE.
    Creators: Hayley Curtis; Rose Gatlin
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Sanctuary of Apollo Phanaios
    A partially excavated artificial platform and temple at modern Kato Phana on the Greek island of Chios (ancient Phanai).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Valeria Vitale
  • Sanctuary of Asklepios, Balagrae
    The Sanctuary of Asklepios at Balagrae in Cyrenaica is dated to the Hadrianic period on the basis of epigraphic evidence.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary of Demeter (Knossos)
    The sanctuary sacred to Demeter is located on the Gypsadhes hill, just south of the Minoan 'palace' complex. On this hill, D.G. Hogarth excavated a series of Minoan houses beginning in 1900. Within this area, a first-millennium BCE sanctuary would develop. Excavation reports note the comingling of Minoan remains and Hellenistic deposits. The Classical sanctuary was suspected in 1927 on the basis of sporadic finds, but significant excavations did not begin until 1957.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Sanctuary of Hathor (Serabit el-Khadim)
    Sanctuary of Hathor built in the Middle Kingdom at Serabit el-Khadim.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sanctuary of Heqaib (Elephantine)
    Middle Kingdom sanctuary of Heqaib located on Elephantine Island near the Temples of Satis and Khnum.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sanctuary of Kalabsha (Elephantine)
    Ptolemaic sanctuary originally situated in Kalabsha, relocated to the southwestern tip of Elephantine Island in 1961.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Sanctuary of Poseidon at Kalaureia, Poros
    A sanctuary sacred to Poseidon on the island of Poros.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sanctuary of Poseidon at Tainaron
    A famous ancient sanctuary of Poseidon located at the southern end of the modern Mani peninsula of the Peloponnese. Literary and archaeological evidence indicate that the sanctuary featured a temple, a cave treated as a mouth of the underworld, and other structural and monumental components. It seems to have served as a sanctuary site for suppliants and a context for the formal manumission of enslaved persons.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • San Demetrio ne' Vestini
    A settlement that was an important center of the Vestini in the Abruzzo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Felice Roman villa
    The villa site is located approximately 1 km. south of the presumed ancient course of the Via Appia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Giovanni in Oleo
    A sixteenth-century chapel near the Porta Latina that is believed to commemorate the location where the Christian apostle John was reportedly unharmed after being immersed in a vat of boiling oil in 92 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • San Manno hypogeum
    An Etruscan hypogeum tomb dating either to the third or the second century BCE. The tomb is located beneath the medieval church of San Manno in the comune of Perugia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Martino ai Monti
    San Martino ai Monti is a minor basilica in Rome. The basilica was founded on a site donated by Equitius during the reign of Pope St. Sylvester I in the fourth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Menna
    The church of San Menna in Rome was recorded by the anonymous pilgrim author of the Einsiedeln in the eighth century. It was located along the Via Ostiensis. Likely founded in 589, the church is not attested after the tenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Pancrazio al Fango
    San Pancrazio al Fango is an early medieval abbey built between the eighth and ninth centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • San Pedro del Arroyo
    A late Roman villa complex that continued in use during the Visigothic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Potito Sannitico
    A Roman villa in the locality of Torelle at San Potito Sannitico.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • San Rocco Military Complex (Trieste)
    A Roman military fortification at modern Trieste, dating from the third to the first centuries BCE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • San Saba, Rome
    The Basilica of San Saba is located on the "Piccolo Aventino" in Rome. The basilica's origin is traced to 645 when fugitive monks from Mar Saba in Palestine traveled to Rome to attend the Lateran Council. They subsequently remained on the Aventine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santa Cecilia in Trastevere
    A church in Trastevere with origins in the fifth century CE. Pope Urban I likely founded the first church on the same site in the third century CE. Its venerated saint is a Christian martyr of the third century CE. Pope Paschal I rebuilt the church in 822 CE, and moved the relics of St Cecilia to the site from the Catacombs of San Callisto on the Via Appia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Cristina in Caio a Buonconvento (Siena)
    An ancient vicus with a thermal complex (first century BCE to fourth century CE) with phases of post-ancient re-use. The site is located in the modern Italian municipal territory of Buonconvento, Tuscany.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santa Croce in Gerusalemme
    A minor Catholic basilica in Rome, Santa Croce in Gerusalemme is also a titular church in rione Esquilino and one of the Seven Pilgrim Churches. The church was consecrated ca. 325 to house relics of the Passion of Jesus Christ brought to Rome from the Holy Land by Empress St. Helena.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santa Liberata
    A coastal platform villa conneted with the Domitii Ahenobarbi.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Lucia in Selci
    The church of Santa Lucia in Selci was founded by the eighth century and perhaps as early as the sixth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria di Devia
    The church of Santa Maria di Devia is a Romanesque church of the eleventh century with Byzantine frescoes dating to the twelfth through fourteenth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa María do Castro
    The castro of Santa María de Cervantes is located on the banks of the Ancares river the municipality of Cervantes, in the province of Lugo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria in Legarano
    Site of a large Roman villa, the remains of which were incorporated into the church of Santa Maria in Legarano. The early phases of the villa likely date to the early imperial period. At some point the villa became an Imperial property as it was donated to Pope Sylvester by Constantine.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria in Portuno
    A vicus and villa of the Roman period that lay along a route connecting the Via Flaminia to the coast. Archaeological evidence for the production of ceramics and tiles has been identified. A Christian monastery is established in 1090.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria in Tempulo
    A deconsecrated Christian church on the flank of Rome's Caelian Hill, Santa Maria in Tempulo is connected with the ancient tradition of the spring and grove of Camenae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria Nova
    A multi-period site with medieval and modern remains atop Roman levels, including a medieval farmhouse built atop a Roman cistern. Excavations revealed multi-phase evidence, including a bath building decorated with mosaics. The structures may have been related to the nearby Villa dei Quintilli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Maria Sopra Minerva
    A first century B.C. temple dedicated to Minerva by Gneus Caestius and Titus Caesius Priscus, who were two of the Assisi's quattuorviri. The temple was converted to the church of Santa Maria Sopra Minerva in 1539.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santa Marina (Villa)
    A large seaside villa on two terraces overlooking the modern Santa Marina bay near Varbiga, Croatia. The villa lies on the northern coast of a headland; the major amphora workshop at Loron occupies the southern coastal site.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Sant'Angelo Romano
    Sant'Angelo Romano is the area of the Castello Orsini-Cesi-Borghese dating from the late fourteenth century onward. The environs of Sant'Angelo Romano are dotted with ancient sites, in particular the ruins of Roman-period platform villas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sant'Annea
    At Sant'Annèa are the remains of an extensive Roman villa located near the port of Gargano, about 3 km south of Lake Lesina. The villa probably originates in the late republican period and flourishes in the third and fourth centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santa Susanna
    The current Church of Saint Susanna at the Baths of Diocletian located on the Quirinal Hill in Rome dates from 1585. A titular church has existed on the site since ca. A.D. 280. The remains of an elite house (domus) are preserved beneath the church.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sant'Egidio del Monte Albino aqueduct
    A subterranean Roman aqueduct in the modern Italian province of Salerno.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sant'Ilario
    A paleochristian site located at the thirtieth mile of the ancient via Labicana, near to the ancient road station 'ad Bivium'.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santi Quaranta
    The remains of a long, early Imperial-period Roman cryptoporticus at Beneventum that was re-used in the Middle Ages. It is situated between the modern San Lorenzo district and the rural area of Cellarulo, near the Basilica of the Madonna delle Grazie in Benevento, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santi Quattro Coronati
    Santi Quattro Coronati is an early Christian basilica on Rome's Caelian Hill begun by Pope Miltiades in the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santuario di Fondo Patturelli
    A Samnite sanctuary of ancient Capua that was initially discovered in 1845. Active from the sixth century B.C. until the first century B.C., the Santuario di Fondo Patturelli is noted for its architectural terracotta as well as for the presence of a sacred maternal cult.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Santuario di Santa Maria di Barbana
    The Santuario di Barbana is an ancient Marian shrine that dates ca. 582. It is said that Elia, the Patriarch of Aquileia, built a church near the hut of a hermit from Treviso by the name of Barbanus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Santuario di Santa Maria Regina di Anglona
    A Marian sanctuary located on the hill of Anglona in the province of Matera, Italy, that originates in the eleventh century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sarakenos Cave
    Cave with Neolithic, Mesolithic, Palaeolithic, and Bronze Age remains in Boeotia, Greece
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sarapieion A
    The earliest of the three shrines sacred to Serapis identified by archaeologists working at Delos in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sarapieion C at Delos
    One of three shrines sacred to Serapis identified by archaeologists working at Delos in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sarmaç
    Sarmaç is a modern settlement located on the northwestern slopes of Warak (Erek, Erk) Dağ about 10km to the east of Van in the Van Province in Eastern Turkey. In the monastery of Sarmaç (previously called Kohbants) three stone blocks with inscriptions of the Urartian king Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) were found which describe the construction of a susi temple for the god Ḫaldi, a fortress, a gate and the ‘barzudibiduni building of Minua’.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Šarrat-niphi temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the goddess Šarrat-niphi (an aspect of Ištar).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Sasaei
    An ancient Illyrian tribe.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sasasanian Mine Near Tower 19
    Subterranian mine associated with Sasanian Persian siege and eventual fall of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sauve Pre-Roman oppidum
    A pre-Roman and Gallo-Roman oppidum in the territory of the Volcae Arecomici.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Savignano sul Rubicone Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge on the Rubicon at Savignano sul Rubicone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sboryanovo Historical and Archaeological Reserve
    Protected area located between the villages of Sveshtari and Malak Porovets in northeastern Bulgaria containing over 140 identified archaeological sites from different historical periods. Among the sites in the landscape is the Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari, a Unesco World Heritage site.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Schola Quaestorum et Caplatorum
    The Schola Quaestorum et Caplatorum is a place in ancient Rome that is mentioned only in the Regionary Catalogue for Regio III. It was likely located between the lacus Pastorum and the Baths of Titus. While the name and place remain obscure, related epigraphic evidence attests to collegia of caplatores, men who pressed olive oil.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Scoppieto
    An ancient settlement occupied from the fourth century B.C. to the fifth century A.D. noted for an Italic sanctuary and a production center for terra sigillata.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Seashore Gate
    The Neo-Babylonian kings Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. That mudbrick wall is reported to have had 120 towers and 5 entrances, including the Seashore Gate. This access point to the city was probably located on the southern stretch of the wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Sebetti temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the divine Sebetti. The location of this building is not known.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Sebetti temple (Khorsabad)
    A temple dedicated to the Sebetti, the divine seven, was excavated by Iraqi archaeologists in 1957. This temple at Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad) is located just west of the citadel, near Citadel Gate A and City Gate 7.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Secondary Gate
    Minor gate in the western city walls of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Segontium: Roman Bath House
    The Roman Bath House at Segontium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Segouiola
    Segouiola was an old Spanish village located in the west of the province of Sevilla during the kingdom of Alfonso X. Previously, the Arab population called it Boriauenzohar. Afterwards, this place assumed other names, including Torre del Guadiamar. Since the nineteenth century, Torre del Guadiamar county has been part of Benacazón.
    Creators: María Jesús Redondo
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Segusio aqueduct
    A Roman aqueduct of Segusio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Selva del Lamone
    The Selva del Lamone is a modern forest reserve that preserves undeveloped natural and cultural landscapes of Lazio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Selvasecca di Blera
    A Republican period villa located near Blera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • S’Ena ’e Thomes
    A well-preserved 'giant's tomb' dating ca. 2000-1600 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sendim Roman villa
    A Late Roman villa site dating to the fourth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Septizonium
    The Septizonium (or Septizodium) is a monument located at the extreme at the extreme southeastern corner of the Palatine hill built by the Severan emperors. It is attested textually in the Historia Augusta, its footprint appears on the Severan marble plan (Forma Urbis Romae), and its foundations have been explored via excvavation.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sepulcrum Statiliorum
    A columbarium tomb of the slaves and freedmen of the Statilii, and of M. Statilius Taurus, consul in A.D. 44.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Serapieion B at Delos
    One of three shrines sacred to Serapis identified by archaeologists working at Delos in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Serpent Column
    An ancient bronze column that was displayed in the Hippodrome of Constantinople, the Serpent Column was part of a monument originally installed at Delphi and relocated to Constantinople by Constantine I in A.D. 324. The monument was originally built to celebrate the Greek defeat of the Persian Empire at the Battle of Plataea in 479 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Serra del Cedro (Basilicata)
    The hill of Serra del Cedro in Basilicata (858 meters above sea level) is occupied already in the archaic period. By the fourth century BCE the settlement covers some 30 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Serra Orrios
    An important nuragic complex that includes remains of a megalithic megaron-type structure.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Serzhen'yurt
    An ancient settlement located in Chechnya that is associated with the Koban Culture, an archaeological culture of the northern and central Caucasus. The site was inhabited during the Bronze and Iron Ages (11th-7th centuries BCE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sestiae
    A place in Adriatic Italy that is included on the Peutinger map.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sette Sale
    Cisterns of the imperial period on the Oppian Hill that once supplied the Baths of Trajan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Seven Wells
    A place in Arabia that is mentioned in Strabo's discussion of the ultimately unsuccessful eastern campaign of Aelius Gallus. It was located eleven days marching from Negrana. From Seven Wells Gallus proceeded to Chaalla and Malothas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shahr-i Ghulghula
    A fortified Parthian-Sassanid city with extensive remains of mudbrick architecture.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shahr-i Kuhna
    A fortified Early Islamic town (tenth to the thirteenth century) located in Afghanistan's Helmand province.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shah Tepe (Afghanistan)
    Shah Tepe (Afghanistan) or Nayibabad is located in Samanghan Province northwest of Tashkurghan. This is an area of tepes that range in date from the Epi-paleolithic (seventh millennium B.C.) to the sixteenth century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shalfak
    A Middle Kingdom fortress that was originally located on the Nile's west bank at the Second Cataract of the Nile River. The ruins of the fortress are now situated on an island in Lake Nubia in northern Sudan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shalmaneser Gate
    The “Shalmaneser Gate” gave access from the lower town of Kalhu to the citadel. This entrance, which was flanked by a pair of inscribed stone lions, was located on the east citadel wall, just north of the Nabû temple Ezida. This gate, which its excavators named after the ninth-century-BC Assyrian ruler Shalmaneser III (r. 858–824 BC), is assumed to have been the main east citadel gate, especially since a road ran between it and the armory (Fort Shalmaneser) located in the southwest corner of the city.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Shamshir Ghar
    Cave in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, 3.5 miles NNE of Panjwai town, with archaeological remains from the Kushan period (100 BCE to 300 CE), Kushano-Sassanian (transition) period (300 to 700 CE), and the Early Islamic period (700 to 1222 CE).
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Sharon plain
    Central coastal plain between the Carmel and Joppe in modern Israel.
    Creators: Annette von Stockhausen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sharpenhoe Clappers
    Sharpenhoe Clappers is the site of an Iron Age hill fort in Bedfordshire, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Shaytanskoe Ozero II
    Site on the western bank of Shaytanskoe Lake, Sverdlovsk Oblast, containing remains dated to the early Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Sheikh Abd el-Qurna
    A necropolis located on the West Bank at Thebes in Upper Egypt that is now part of the archaeological area of Deir el-Bahari.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sherabad Oasis
    Oasis region in Southern Uzbekistan centered around the city of Sherabad/Sherobod containing 126 archaeological sites dating from the 2nd half of the 2nd millennium BCE to the 5th century CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Shiqmim
    One of the largest Chalcolithic settlements in Israel located 1km east of Mizad Aluf in the northern Negev desert. The site was later occupied in the Byzantine period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Shisheh
    Shisheh is a village in the Ahar county of the East Azerbaijan Province of Iran, situated about 40 km northeast of the city Ahar. Near the village a rock inscription of the Urartean king Argišti II, son of Rusa, has been found (A 11-6). The inscription reports a military campaign of Argišti to the land Arhu (which is apparently the name the Urartians used for the respective region). Furthermore, Argišti states that he built a fortress named “stronghold of the god Haldi” (Haldiei irduši) and a city at this place.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors:
  • Shop of Acastus
    The so-called "Shop of Acastus" was a taberna in Pompeii that stood to at least two stories. It is located in the same block as the public bath complex at VII, 5, 24.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sidorovka Burial Ground
    Burial ground in modern Omsk Oblast, Russia from the Sargat Culture with five burial mounds.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Siebenlinden
    Site located in modern Rottenburg am Necker with remains from the Middle Mesolithic, Late Mesolithic, Neolithic, and La Tène Iron Age culture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Silla de Papa
    The archaeological site of an oppidum of either Punic or bastulo-Punic origin located in the Spanish municipality of Tarifa (Cádiz). It was likely a precursor of Baelo Claudia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Silla de Papa church
    The remains of a church belonging to the early Medieval period (perhaps the seventh century) that perhaps was a project of Pymenius, Bishop of Asidonia. This edifice is located on the hill that was the site of the oppidum referred to as Silla de Papa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sillian milestone

    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • S'Illot
    A Talaiotic village dating between the ninth and second centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Silva Ciminia
    A forest in ancient Etruria that was a feared and trackless wilderness in the middle Republican period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • S'Imbalconadu Roman villa
    A multi-phase rustic structure (fattoria) located near Olbia, Sardinia. The quadrangular structure consists of twenty-some rooms arranged around a central courtyard; the built surface covers ca 1,000 square meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Šindarara
    A fortress in the vicinity of Til-garimmu fortified by the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC) against Kasku.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Siniyah Island Monastery
    A church and possible monastic complex identified in 2021/2022 on modern Siniyah Island in the emirate of Umm al-Quwain, UAE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Yonatan Miller
  • Sîn temple (Kalhu)
    When Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud) became the principal administrative center of the Assyrian Empire in the ninth century BC, king Ashurnasirpal II (r. 883–859 BC) built (or rebuilt) numerous temples. One of those was dedicated to the moon-god Sîn. Although its location is not known, the Sîn temple at Kalhu is thought to have been situated within the Ninurta temple complex, in the northwest corner of the citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sîn temple (Khorsabad)
    As part of the palatial complex of Dūr-Šarrukīn (modern Khorsabad), the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) constructed six temples, including one to the god Sîn.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Šinuhtu
    A city in Tabal mentioned in royal inscriptions of the Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721-705 BC). Its precise location in the area of the modern country of Turkey is uncertain: both modern Niǧde and at or near modern Aksaray have been proposed.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sirkap
    A Graeco-Bactrian city founded ca. 180 B.C. by the king Demetrius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sisi, Kephali tou Agiou Antoniou
    Kephali tou Agiou Antoniou is an archaeological site in Agios Nikolaos, located near Sisi on the north coast of Crete. Remains of monumental Minoan architecture have been documented there.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Six Windows Building Complex at Sikait
    A complex of three stone-built structures in the ancient settlement of Sikait in Egypt's Eastern Desert. The structure seems to have served a primarily residential function, certainly during the 4th and 5th centuries CE and (in a previous phase) during an as-yet undetermined earlier period. It may also have had a commercial function.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Skarkos Hill
    Site of a prehistoric settlement of the Cycladic civilization on the island of Ios.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Skerki Bank
    The Skerki Bank is an area of relatively shallow open sea lying between Sicily and Tunisia. The presence of several reefs made the area perilous for ancient mariners and, from 1988 onward, ancient shipwrecks have been investigated in this area.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sklavokampos
    A Late Minoan structure that first excavated in the 1930s. The Sklavokampos complex contained at least 17 rooms and yielded a range of evidence, including at least 39 sealings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Skopje aqueduct
    A Roman aqueduct in Macedonia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Skotino cave
    A cave sacred to the Minoan peoples of Crete that continued to be used by Greeks, and later, Romans. Arthur Evans carried out the initial archaeological exploration of the cave.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Skvort͡sovskiĭ Mound
    Settlement mound in Northwestern Russia with archaeological remains from the 8th-1st millennium BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Small Down Knoll hill fort
    Small Down Knoll is the site of a Bronze Age hill fort near Evercreech in Somerset, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • S. Martín de Montiña Roman Dam
    S. Martín de Montiña on arroyo of same name, 4 miles SW Mazarambroz.
    Creators: P.O. Spann
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert; R. Warner
  • So-called "Building C"
    The site of a masonry building in Aquae Sulis, modern-day Bath.
    Creators: Syvanne Aloni
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called "Buildings A and B"
    Site of masonry buildings in Aquae Sulis, modern-day Bath.
    Creators: Syvanne Aloni
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called "No.4 Abbeygate Street"
    Remains of large building found in the settlement of Aquae Sulis, modern Bath.
    Creators: Syvanne Aloni
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • So-called Tempio di Venere e Cupido
    The so-called Temple of Venus and Cupid at Rome is part of the complex of buildings associated with the Sessorian palace. The structure's modern assignation is owed to the discovery of a fragmentary statue of Sallustia Orbiana in the guise of Venus Felix. Sallustia Orbiana was the wife of Alexander Severus. The statue is now held in the Museo Pio Clementino in the Vatican Museums.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • So-called Temple of Hercules
    A site on the Via Appia that is likely commercial in nature but that has long been associated with a shrine mentioned by Martial.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • So-called 'Tomb of Cicero' at Formiae
    A 24-meter tall tower tomb on the Via Appia at Formiae is traditionally considered as a possible location of the Tomb of Cicero.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sokolova Mohyla
    Burial mound of Sarmatian nobility from the 1st century CE in modern Mykolaiv Oblast, Ukraine with earlier remains from the Bronze Age. The mound has since been demolished by bulldozer.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Solaize Roman Milestone
    A Roman milestone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Solestà Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge over the Truentus river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sol et Luna, Aedes
    A temple sacred to Sol ("The Sun") and Luna ("The Moon") that likely predated the imperial construction of the Circus Maximus. Given this dating, the preexisting temple came to be incorporated into the cavea of the circus. The temple is iconographically represented in coin issues of the reign of Trajan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Son Bou Basilica
    A three-aisled Paleochristian basilica of the fifth century A.D. located in the village of Son Bou in Menorca, Spain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Son Espases Roman Camp
    This Roman camp, discovered in northern Palma, Mallorca, during construction of the Hospital de Son Espases, dates to Metellus' conquest of the island ca. 123-121 BCE. The visible remains on the north side of the hospital were consolidated and moved from the larger site, which is no longer visible.
    Creators: Joel Bellviure
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Joel Bellviure
  • Sorgenti della Nova
    An eleventh and tenth century B.C. settlement in south Etruria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies
  • Sororium Tigillum
    Sororium Tigillum describes a wooden beam that stretched across a branch of the Sacra Via that climbed the Oppian Hill near the Compitum Acilii. The monument was flanked by altars of Iuno Sororia and Iuno Curiatius. It is an ancient monument about which there are many stories, the primary one being a link to the Horatii and Curiatii and Publius Horatius' slaying of his own sister.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Souda (island)
    An islet located in Souda Bay on the northwest coast of Crete.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Ryan Horne
    Contributors:
  • Souskiou-Vathyrkakas Cemetery
    Cemetery site in southwest Cyprus lying 1.5km southwest of Souskiou Village with archaeological remains from the chalcolithic period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • South Citadel Gate
    One of two gates providing access from the west through the southern end of the citadel defense walls at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Southeastern Cluster
    The Southeastern Cluster of rock-cut churches at Lalibela.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Southern Gate
    Gate located between Tower 8 and Tower 9 in the southern city walls of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • South Etruria Survey area
    The original and pioneering South Etruria Survey was led by J.B. Ward-Perkins of the British School at Rome from the 1950s to the 1970s. The initial focus was the territory of the city of Veii (Ager Veientanus). A revisiting of this survey area and the project's outcomes was part of the Tiber Valley Project led by Helen Patterson and initiated in 1997.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • South Palace at Deir el-Ballas
    Two-story palace near the western bank of the Nile used as an administrative center from the Second Intermediate Period to the early New Kingdom.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Southwest Palace at Kalhu
    The seventh-century-BC Assyrian king Esarhaddon (r. 680–669 BC) started building a royal residence in the southwest corner of the citadel of Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud). Sculpted and inscribed limestone slabs from the Central Palace (constructed by Tiglath-pileser III [r. 744–727 BC]) and the Northwest Palace (built by Ashurnasirpal II [r. 883–859 BC]) were used as building materials for this royal residence, which very likely remained unfinished at the time of Esarhaddon’s death in 669 BC. Its excavators called it the “Southwest Palace” since it was located in the southwest corner of the citadel.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • S. Passera hypogeum
    A hypogeum connected with the S. Passera complex.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Spathari (quarry)
    A limestone quarry located just south of the modern Acarnanian village of Lepenou with clear evidence of having been used as a source for the construction of the temple of Zeus and other monuments at nearby ancient Stratos.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Spathari (temple)
    A temple in Acarnania, located between Stratos (modern Sourovigli) and modern Lepenou. The temple seems to have been constructed in the Greek Archaic period on the site of an earlier Helladic settlement. The temple continued in operation into the Roman period.
    Creators: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Spetisbury Rings
    Spetisbury Rings, also known as Crawford Castle, is a hillfort with Pre-Roman Iron Age earthen embankment fortifications located in north Dorset, England, near the River Stour. Tradition holds that invading Romans razed this indigenous stronghold in the first century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Spurie (island)
    An island now known as Yılanlı Island.
    Creators: Philipp Pilhofer
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sra Ghundai, Ghazni
    Remains of a walled ancient city in the Ghazni province of Afghanistan. Its remains date to various periods according to W. Ball (1982): Late Sassanian and Turki Shahi (sixth–ninth century AD) and Early Islamic (tenth -twelfth century).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sri Ahobila Narasimha Swamy Temple
    Main temple in Ahobilam dedicated to the man-lion form of the Hindu god Vishnu built or expanded in the 14th century, sacked by the Mughals in 1578, then restored and expanded at various times up to the present day.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Stadium at Anazarbos
    A stadium south of the city proper at Anazarbos (modern Dilekkaya in Turkey)
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Stadium at Laodicea ad Lycum
    The ancient Stadium at Laodicea ad Lycum dates initially to the later first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Stadium-garden at Hadrian's Villa
    A garden at the Villa Hadriani imitating the shape of a stadium, situated between the Three Exedras' Hall (to the west) and the Winter Palace (to the east), with a semi-circular nymphaeum at its southern end.
    Creators: Joshua Rosenheim
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Stadium-Gymnasium Complex at Messene
    The stadium-gymnasium complex at Messene was built in the third century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stadium of Perge
    A well-preserved stadium of the Roman period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Staigue stone fort
    An Iron Age ring fort, dating perhaps to the fourth century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stancija Blek
    The archaeological site of Stancija Blek (Tar-Vabrega, Istria-Croatia) is located on the west coast of Istria. In antiquity, the site would have been located in the territory of Parentium. Archaeological investigation has documented more than 1,500 years of occupation, beginning perhaps with a Roman-period agricultural establishment (villa) that was subsequently followed by Late Antique and Medieval phases that include a so-called tower. Nearby are the remains of the church of Santa Croce.
    Creators: Francis Tassaux
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Stanwick Iron Age Fortifications
    Stanwick Iron Age Fortifications or Stanwick camp is an Iron Age site in Britain covering approximately 300 hectares.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stari Ras
    Stari Ras, the first capital of Serbia, is the site of an impressive group of medieval monuments consisting of fortresses, churches and monasteries listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • St. Catherine's Hill
    St. Catherine's Hill, Hampshire, England, is the site of an Iron Age hill-fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Steinerner Steg - Ponte Romano
    A two-arched, stone-built footbridge across the Passer in Merano, South Tyrol.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stele of Caius Vibius Quartus
    The stele of a Roman military officer dating to the first century A.D. located at modern Dikilí Tas (Ντικιλί Τας), an archaeological site with evidence for both prehistoric and Byzantine occupation. The stele stands just to the east of modern Krenides, only 2km from the center of the ancient city of Philippi, which lies on the west side of the modern town.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Stele Ponte di Apollo
    A stele carrying a Latin inscription that dates to the Severan period (ca. 206 CE) recording the restoration of the bridge that had been destroyed by the "fury of the sea".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stepushka
    Burial site in the Altai region dated to the Syanbi-Zhouzhan period (4th-5th century CE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • St. Hilarion Castle
    A Byzantine castle in Cyprus likely in the late eleventh century. The site was a holiday retreat for Cyprus's Frankish rulers, and the Venetians destroyed it in the fourteenth century.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • St Michael's Mount
    A tidal island located in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, England. Known for the castle crowning the island, this place has been inhabited since the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Stoa at Lokroi Epizephyrioi
    A large U-shaped stoa dating to the seventh and sixth centuries BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • St. Pauls villa
    A Late Roman villa discovered ca. 2005.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • St Peters Church, Flawford
    A ruined Medieval church located on the site of a Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • St. Pierre Cathedral
    Church in Geneva, Switzerland that was originally a Roman Catholic cathedral but was converted into a Protestant church during the Reformation. The original church was built in the 4th century but the present building began construction around 1150.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • St. Raphael Church II (Banganarti)
    Mid-11th to mid-18th century church built on top of an older church that was an important pilgrimage site in Nubia. The church is located in the modern Sudanese village of Banganarti.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Strategeion
    Palace located in block C9 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Strebersdorf
    Roman military encampment located approximately halfway between Savaria and Scarabantia, containing remains dated to the 1st-2nd centuries CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Studforth Hill
    The remains of a Romano-British amphitheater were discovered on Studforth Hill, just outside the village of Aldborough between Harrogate and York in northern England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Šuanna
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Šuanna was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained two temples. Šuanna is also a name of Babylon itself (starting in the twelfth century BC).
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Subura
    Subura (or Suburra) refers to an area of ancient Rome, although the precise spatial definition of this area is unclear. In the earliest instances, this toponym may refer to the valley lying between the Oppian and the Caelian. As such it corresponds to one of the four urban regions known as the "Servian" regions. In later times the Subura referred to a part of the Augustan regio IV which was known as a densely populated area between the Esquiline, Quirinal, Viminal, and Cispian hills and had a rough and seedy reputation.
    Creators: Echo Smith; Edward Keogh; Sara Hales
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Su Coddu
    A prehistoric settlement covering some 10 hectares with evidence for approximately 150 huts located in Selargius, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Sudelfels
    The site of a Gallo-Roman sanctuary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Su Fraigu
    A Punic necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Šūhi Canal Gate
    The Neo-Babylonian kings Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. That mudbrick wall is reported to have had 120 towers and 5 entrances, including the Šūhi Canal Gate. This access point to the city was probably located on the northeastern stretch of the wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Sukhoe Ozero II
    Cemetery site in Khakassia containing numerous burials associated with the Karasuk Culture (14th-8th centuries BCE). The site was inundated following the construction of the Krasnoyarsk Hydroelectric Power Plant.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Sulayman Mountain
    The Sulayman-too Sacred Mountain (Taht-I-Suleiman, Sulayman Rock or Sulayman Throne) located in the city of Osh was once a major place of Muslim and pre-Muslim pilgrimage. The mountain is located in the plains the Fergana Valley.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Summanus, Aedes
    "Aedes Summanus" or "Templum Summanus" was a temple built near the Circus Maximus during the war with Pyrrhus. It could have been located on the slope of the Aventine Hill. The temple was likely built after the terracotta statue of Summanus included in the pedimental sculpture of the Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus on the Capitoline Hill, causing the statue's head to be flung into the river Tiber.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Summerston
    A Roman military installation of 2.4 ha associated with the Antonine Wall that was identified in 1980.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sun of the Gods Gate
    The Neo-Babylonian kings Nabopolassar (r. 625–605 BC) and Nebuchadnezzar II (r. 604–562 BC) constructed an outer wall around the eastern side of Babylon. That mudbrick wall is reported to have had 120 towers and 5 entrances, including the Sun of the Gods Gate. This access point to the city was probably located on the southern stretch of the wall.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Surt
    Medieval Arab settlement, located 55km east of modern Sirte, Libya. Roman-period spolia in the medieval settlement, as well as evidence from the Roman itineraries, place the ancient site of Charax/(I)Scina here or somewhere in the vicinity.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Surtiĭn dėnzh
    Ritual complex in central Mongolia consisting of eight deer stone monuments surrounded by nine stone rings and several cairns.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Susa Roman amphitheater
    The Roman amphitheater at Segusio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Susegana bridge
    A Roman bridge along the Via Claudia Augusta.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Su Tempiesu
    A nuragic spring sanctuary in use from the thirteenth to ninth centuries BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ṣuwwānet eth-Thanīya
    Settlement area 2.8km north of the center of modern Jericho with archaeological remains from the Early Roman period, Iron Age, and Late Chalcolithic. The site was at least partially destroyed by agriculture and construction of a road in the area.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Swarthy Hill
    A Milefortlet of the Roman Cumbrian coast defenses, contemporary to Hadrian's Wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Sweet Track
    Sweet Track is an ancient timber causeway of Britain built at the end of the fourth millennium BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Synagogue Phase 1
    Synagogue adapted from a private house building in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Synagogue phase 1
    Synagogue adapted from a private house building in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Synagogue phase 2
    Renovation of the synagogue at Dura-Europos c. 244 CE. The date for the renovation and expansion of the Synagogue (phase 2) is based on Aramaic inscriptions painted on decorative ceiling tiles from the building's assembly hall.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Synagogue Phase 2
    Renovation of the synagogue at Dura-Europos c. 244 CE.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tablis
    A place located between Lugdunum Batavorum and Noviomagus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tabriz: Iron Age Cemetery
    In 1997, during work to restore and consolidate the "Blue Mosque" in modern Tabriz, Iran, an extensive Iron Age cemetery was discovered and excavated. Since 2007, the site has been partly open to the public as an open-air museum.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Tadrart Acacus
    The Acacus Mountains are known for rock-art dating from 12,000 BC to 100 AD and were inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985 because of the importance of these paintings and carvings.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tagliata Falisca Cava di Sant'Egidio
    An instance of a 'via cava' located near Corchiano, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tal-i-iblis
    Tell in the Bard Sir Valley in Iran occupied in the late 4th-early 3rd millennia BCE. This site was an important place for copper smelting from its earliest period of occupation. The site has been largely destroyed by mining.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tall Abū al-Dhahab
    Archaeological site in the marches of Dhi Qar where Iraqi excavations have revealed secular and religious buildings belonging to the First Sealand Dynasty 1740–1374 BCE including a number of objects bearing cuneiform inscriptions.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall Abu Danné
    Settlement in Syria. Archaeological excavation has revealed layers inhabited from the Neo-Babylonian Period to the beginning of the Roman period
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Tall al-Umayri
    An archaeological site of western Jordan that dates from the Early Bronze Age (3200–2100 BC) to the Hellenistic period (323–30 BC).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tall Bāzy
    Early to late bronze age town and citadel, ancient name was probably Armium or Armanum.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall Bint al-Amīr
    Babylonian site where find of cuneiform inscription has been made.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tall Dāmiyā
    Iron Age site in the Central Jordan Valley, sometimes identified with the historical place Adama.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tall-e Geser
    Village in Iran inhabited since the 6th millennium BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tall el Hammam
    Tell el-Hammam or Tall al-Hammam is an archaeological site located in Jordan near the mouth of the Jordan River. The site has substantial occupational remains from the Chalcolithic, Early, Intermediate, and Middle Bronze Age, and from Iron Age II.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tall-i-Gap
    Site in Southern Iran, just north of the village Tajabad, with seven tells from a time-frame equivalent with the Ubaid to early-Uruk periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tamiryn Ulaan Khoshuu
    Burial site located near the northern bank of the Tamir River in Mongolia. The site contains nearly 300 burials dated to the Xiongnu period (ca. 3rd century BCE-1st century CE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tananir
    Settlement in modern Jordan with remains from the late Chalcolithic period to the late Bronze Age, as well as the late Roman to early Byzantine periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tanella Angori
    A circular Hellenistic tomb of the second century BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tanella di Pitagora
    A third to second century B.C. tomb in the hinterland of Cortona.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tang-i Var Rock Relief
    The Tang-i Var rock relief of the eighth-century-BC Assyrian king Sargon II (r. 721–705 BC) is carved on a rack face of the Kūh-e Zīnāneh in the Tang-i Var pass in Iranian Kurdistan, about 50 km southwest of Sanandaj and 85 km northwest of Kermanshah. This difficult-to-reach relief was carved in a niche cut into the cliff face about 40 m above ground level. The Akkadian inscription, now badly weathered, records several of Sargon II’s campaigns, especially the military expeditions against the land Karalla, against which the Assyrian army campaigned in 716, 713, and 706 BC.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tapah Daylam
    Place where cuneiform inscription has been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tap o' Noth hill fort
    Tap o' Noth hill fort is located in Aberdeenshire, Scotland; a well preserved vitrified wall survives at the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tarasov Mound Site
    Area with 17 Early Iron Age mounds located near the modern village Tarasovo and the Kama river in Russia's Udmurtia state. All mounds had settlements except Tarasov I, which was the location of a religious sanctuary and cemetery. The site has been partially destroyed by oil digging in the area.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tarr Steps
    Tarr Steps is a prehistoric bridge over the River Barle in England. The current phase dates to the Medieval period, although the original phase of the bridge is dated ca. 1000 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tasgoduni
    An ancient tribe of Gallia Narbonensis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tassiesholm
    According to Canmore, "a major Roman complex (Flavian to Antonine) at Milton (Roy's Tassieholm) was excavated between 1938 and 1950 by J. Clarke."
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tassili n'Ajjer
    Tassili n'Ajjer is a mountain range of the Sahara Desert, covering an area of 72,000 square kilometers. The mountain range is the site of more than 15,000 rock art drawings and engravings dating from 6000 BC to the first centuries of the present era.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tatev
    A ninth-century monastery located on a large basalt plateau in southeastern Armenia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tatev Monastery
    Armenian monastery located in Syunik Province, Armenia. Constructed beginning in 848, the monastery complex was expanded several times from the 10th-13th century.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tavoliere delle Puglie
    A plain of northern Apulia, the Tavoliere delle Puglie covers some 3,000 square kilometers. It is particularly noted as a landscape in which both settlement and ritual activity took place during the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tawilan
    Settlement near the village of Tawilan, Jordan, just west of Petra, with archaeological remains from the Iron Age and Persian period. Notably, there is no evidence of Nabataean occupation at this site despite its proximity to Petra.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tech (river)
    The Tech river flows some 84 km from its source is the Parcigoule Valley to the Mediterranean Sea.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • TE.E
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, TE.E (read as either Tê or Kisīri) was one of the six city districts of the eastern half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained one temple and two daises.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tel 'Aroer
    Tell in the Negev desert with archaeological remains from an Iron Age town and a Hellenistic-early Roman settlement.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tel Ḥarasim
    Tell in northern Israel with remains from the Late Bronze Age, Iron Age, Persian period, and Byzantine period. The tell was not fortified but did have a fortress in the Iron Age.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tel Kisson
    Tel Kisson, also known as Tell Keisan, is an archaeological site located 8 km from the Mediterranean shoreline in Israel's Galilee region. Human occupation at the site of the tel begins in the Chalcolithic period. By the middle Bronze Age, the site was prosperous and fortified. It experiences possible destruction in the twelfth century BCE and recovers, though at a reduced scale. From the later eleventh century BCE, the site is occupied as perhaps an economic enclave of Phoenician Tyre.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Abbas
    Tell in the Hamrin Basin with a Parthian settlement, possibly featuring a defensive moat. The area was flooded by the creation of the Hamrin Dam in the late 1970s.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Abu al-Kharaz
    A Bronze and Iron Age archaeological site in Gilead in the eastern valley of the Jordan river
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Tell Afis
    Iron Age settlement in Syria. The site has been tentatively identified as Hadarikka/Hazrek, the capital of the region of Luhuti/Luash, which became part of the kingdom of Hamath around 796 BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tell Aḥmad al-Ḥattū
    Early dynastic necropolis in southern Mesopotamia. The site was inundated by the creation of Lake Hamrin in 1981.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell 'Ali
    A small site on the left bank of the Lower Zab where an archive of ca. twenty-five Middle Assyrian texts was discovered. The town was situated more or less where travellers from Aššur to the cities Nuzi and Arrapha would have crossed the Lower Zab. Tell 'Ali is identified with ancient Atmannu.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Carolin Johansson
  • Tell Baqrta
    Tell Baqrta, an archaeological site located 28 km south of Erbil, may be the Neo-Assyrian town known as Baqarru.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Bazmusian
    A site on the right bank of the Lower Zab that was excavated by Iraqi archaeologists in 1956–58. Tell Bazmusian, whose ancient name is not known, is one of the largest archaeological sites in the Ranya Plain (Sulaymaniyah Governorate, Iraq). The city was occupied from the sixth millennium BCE to the ninth century CE. A small group of Middle Assyrian tablets were discovered in a pit outside the city’s temple. Tell Bazmusian is now submerged under Lake Dukan.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Deinit
    Settlement in western Syria inhabited from the 3rd Millennium BCE through the Byzantine period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tell ej-Judeideh
    A tell located southeast of Gath in Israel that has been identified with the biblical Moresheth-Gath.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell el-Ajjul
    Tell el-Ajjul was a fortified Bronze Age settlement located in what is now Gaza. Evidence from the site indicates economic interaction with ancient Egypt.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell El-Farah (South)
    An archaeological site located in the Northwestern Negev Desert in modern Israel with identified with the Biblical city of Sharuhen. Two Middle Bronze Age cemeteries are located next to the site.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell El Kowm
    Neolithic site in Syria with signs of habitation dated to the 7th-6th millennia BCE.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell el-Mazar
    A small but tall settlement mound located in the Jordan Valley with archaeological remains from the 8th-4th centuries BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell en-Nasbeh
    Tell en-Naṣbeh is an archaeological site ca. 12 km north of the Old City of Jerusalem. The site is often identified with the biblical Mizpah in Benjamin.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Noah Kaye
  • Tell er-Rameh
    Tell er-Rameh is an ancient settlement mound located in the plain of the River Jordan, some 12 miles from Jericho.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell er-Rumeith
    Settlement in the Irbid Plain in northern Jordan near modern Ramtha. Finds from the site have been dated to the Iron Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tell es-Sweyhat
    Tell es-Sweyhat or Sweyhat refers to an ancient settlement mound or tell located along the Euphrates river in what is now the Raqqa Governorate of northern Syria. This human settlement was occupied from the beginning of the third millennium BCE until its collapse in the early second millennium BCE. The site remained occupied during the Early Bronze-Middle Bronze age transition. There is later reoccupation of the site during the Hellenistic and late Roman periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Esur
    Tell in the northern Sharon Plain and one of the main protohistoric settlements in the northern Sharon Plain and Samaria. The tell is surrounded by the springs of 'En Esur. Archaeological remains have been found at this site from the Middle and Late Bronze Age, Iron Age, as well as the Byzantine and Ottoman Periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Faq'ous
    Citadel on the modern banks of Lake Assad in Syria located near the Emar site and containing remains dated to the late Bronze Age.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tell Farukhabad
    Settlement site in the Deh Luran Plain in Iran rich in pottery remains. The site has remains from the Chalcolithic, Uruk and Early Dynastic, Elamite, Parthian, and Sasanian periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell Fekheriye
    Tell Fekheriye is the site of ancient Sikkan in Syria's Khabur river valley. Sikkan was part of the Aramaean kingdom of Bit Bahiani.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Halawa
    Tell in the Hamrin Basin with settlement remains from the Early Dynastic, Early Akkadian, Late Akkadian, Ur III, Old Babylonian, and Partho-Sassanian periods. The site was flooded by the creation of Lake Hamrin in 1981.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Hazna I
