    Religious and administrative center in Syria with two temple complexes. This site was in use in the Early Dynastic Period and the Uruk and Abaid periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Imlihiye
    Tell in the Hamrin Basin with a small Kassite settlement. The area was flooded by the creation of the Hamrin Dam in the late 1970s.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell 'Ira
    Tell located on the 'Ira mountain spur at the southernmost spur of the Hebron hills in the northeastern Negev. Tell 'Ira has archaeological remains from the Early Bronze Age, Iron Age, Hellenistic and Roman periods, Byzantine, and early Islamic periods.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Ischali
    Tell Ishchali is an archaeological site in Iraq's Diyala province. Its main floruit in antiquity was from ca. 2700–1800 BC, primarily Dynastic through the Isin–Larsa period. The site was part of the city-state of Eshnunna.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Kannâs
    Settlement site on the Euphrates river with evidence of habitation from the 9th millennium BCE. The site declined under the Sumerians, was revived to be an important defensive location for the Akkadians, and continued to be inhabited until the 12th century BCE. The site was flooded by the creation of Lake Assad in 1974.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Karanovo
    Neolithic settlement in the Azmak River Valley inhabited from the 7th-2nd millennia BCE. The hilltop settlement is the type site of the Karanovo culture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Khaiber
    A tell in southern Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq located 13 km kilometers west of Nasiriyah and 25 km south of the ancient city of Larsa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell Mureybet
    A settlement mound in Syria that was occupied between 10,200 BCE and 8,000 BCE. The site was submerged by the creation of the Tabqa Dam in 1976. The site was a locus of settlement for the Mureybetian culture (Pre-Pottery Neolithic A).
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Qraya
    Hilltop settlement on the Euphrates settled sometime in the 6th-5th millennium BCE, reached a peak towards the end of the 4th millenium, was abandoned at the beginning of the 3rd millennium, and was reoccupied in the Old Babylonian period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell Ras Budran
    An unusual circular "fort" dating to the Old Kingdom period of ancient Egypt.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Sabi Abyad
    An archaeological site located in the Balikh River valley of northern Syria. The site consists of four prehistoric settlement horizons that archaeologists describe as Tell Sabi Abyad I to IV.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tell Sabi Abyad
    Tell Sabi Abyad is located in the Balih River Valley, in northern Syria. The ancient name of the site is not yet known.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Sabra
    Tell in Mesopotamia occupied during the Proto-Dynastic period I, the early Akkadian period, and the Seleuco-Parthian period. Tell Sabra was submerged with the creation of the Hemrin Dam in 1981.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tell Selenkahiye
    Mound east of Aleppo, Syria which was inhabited from 2400 BCE until its destruction in 2000 BCE. The site was deluged by the creation of the Tabqa Dam in 1973.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tell Sheikh Hassan
    Tell in northern Syria first settled in the Early Neolithic, resettled in the Chalcolithic Ubaid period, resettled again in the mid-late Uruk period, and finally resettled again in the Iron Age, from which point the site was continuously inhabited until the early Islamic period. The site was deluged by the creation of Lake Assad in 1974.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tell Zubeidi
    Tell in the Hamrin Basin with a Kassite settlement dating from the 13th century BCE to the first half of the 12th. The area was flooded by the creation of the Hamrin Dam in the late 1970s.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tel Mor
    Archaeological site on the northern bank of the Lachish River with signs of habitation dated from the Late Bronze Age to the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tel Qashish
    Village in the Jezreel Valley inhabited throughout the Bronze and Iron Ages.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tel Yarmut
    Bronze Age site near Tel Beit Shemesh in Israel. The site shows signs of habitation from the 17th century BCE-4th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Temple 200 at Naga
    Temple structure located south of the main Amun Temple complex at Naga, constructed during the reign of King Nebmaatre Amanakhareqerema (1st century CE).
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple A
    So-called "Temple A" is a structure of the third century B.C. and is likely the Temple of Juturna that was vowed by Caius Lutatius Catulus following his victory against the Carthaginians in 241 B.C. It was later converted into a church, the apse of which remains visible.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple C
    The so-called "Temple C" of the Largo Argentina sacred area may be dedicated to the Italic goddess Feronia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple complex at Kommos
    Multi-phase temple site in the city of Kommos in southern Crete. Temple A was constructed by the late 11th century CE. A larger structure, Temple B, was built over it in the 9th century CE. The temple complex reached its maximum extent when Temple C was built over the site and its surroundings in the 7th century CE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Temple D
    The temple referred to as "Temple D" in the Largo Argentina is likely the Aedes Lares Permarini, sacred to the lares who protect sailors. The largest of the temples in this sacred area, "Temple D" dates to the second century B.C. and remains largely unexcavated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple d'Appolon
    The ruins of a Roman-period temple dedicated to Apollo located at the Oppidum de Gaujac (Gard, France).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple de Saint-Gervais
    Church in Geneva, Switzerland that has existed in some form since the 4th century CE. The 4th century building was followed by a 10th century Romanesque church which was destroyed by fire in the 14th century. The current church was constructed in the 15th century.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Temple Grove of Nikephorion at Pergamum
    A temple grove at the Nikephorion in the settlement of Pergamum. Mentioned by Polybius, the precise location of the grove is not known today.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temple in Block X7
    Small temple located to the northeast inside the military sector at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Adonis
    Temple located in block L5 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Amada
    The Temple of Amada is the oldest Egyptian temple known in Nubia. Founded by Pharaoh Thutmose III (18th dynasty), the temple was dedicated to Amun and Re-Horakhty. The decorative program is attributed to Amenhotep II, his son and successor. The temple was relocated to its current position in 1964 along with the Temple of Derr.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Amenhotep, son of Hapu
    A mortuary temple located in the Theban Necropolis that was dedicated to one Amenhotep, son of Hapu, an official in the court of the 18th Dynasty pharaoh Amenhotep III. Numerous roles are attributed to Amenhotep, son of Hapu, including those of priest, scribe, and architect. Likely he received special dispensation for the construction of the mortuary temple.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Amon (Karnak)
    Middle Kingdom temple of Amon at the heart of the Karnak Temple Complex.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Anu and Adad at Assur
    A distinctive feature of the city of Assur is the double-temple of the gods Anu and Adad. This building, together with its twin ziggurats, was constructed no later than the Middle Assyrian period; it underwent a major rebuilding in the reign of Tiglath-pileser I (1114–1076 BC). The existence of an (unnamed) Adad temple at Assur, however, is known from inscriptions of the Old Assyrian rulers Erišum I and Ikūnum. The various parts of this axisymmetric, double-temple was given Sumerian names: Anu’s temple and ziggurat were called Ešaan and Emelamanna; and Adad’s temple and ziggurat went by the names Ešuddegeštuku and Egišlamšaršar.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Aphlad
    Temple building located in the southwest corner of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Aphrodite (Thessalonica)
    The remains of a marble temple executed in the Ionic order.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Ares
    The sanctuary with a temple dedicated to Ares is located south of the Altar of the Twelve Gods in the Athenian Agora. The temple was originally erected at Pallene ca. 430 BC and sacred to Athena Pallenis at Pallene. The structure was moved to the Agora in the early first century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Artargatis
    Temple located in block H2 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Artemis (Corfu)
    An Archaic Greek temple of the Doric order built ca. 580 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of "Artemis Epikrateia"
    A classical/hellenistic temple located in the likely territory of Acarnanian Alyzeia. The temple site lies over 6km southeast from the ancient walled city (about a kilometer south of modern Paliovarka, Greece) at a site known in modern times as Drymonas Archontochoriou. It is perched on rising ground with a view westward to the channel and the island of Karnos (modern Kalamos). Inscriptions have been recovered from the site, and an unlooted portion of a votive deposit was scientifically excavated in the 1990s.
    Creators: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Artemis Nanaia
    Temple located in block H4 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Artemis Orthasia
    Remains of a sanctuary located on Mt. Kotilon northwest of the Bassai temple.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Artemis (Thasos)
    Temple of Artemis on Thasos Island with remains from the Archaic period to the 1st century CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Asclepios
    The Asklepieion at Lissus, Crete.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Aššur at Assur
    From the second half of the third millennium BC until 614 BC, there was a temple in Assur dedicated to the city’s tutelary deity Aššur. The temple was excavated by W. Andrae in 1903–05 and 1909–12. The earliest and latest textual records for construction work on Aššur’s temple date respectively to the time of Šalim-aḫum, an early old Assyrian king, and the reign of Ashurbanipal (668–631 BC), Assyria’s last great king. According to the Middle Assyrian king Shalmaneser I (1263–1234 BC) and the Neo-Assyrian ruler Esarhaddon (680–669 BC), Ušpia, a tribal ancestor of the Old Assyrian king Šamšī-Adad I (ca. 1808–1776 BC), was the building’s founder. In 614 BC, when the city was captured by the Medes, the temple was destroyed.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Athena Alea at Tegea
    An ancient sanctuary at Tegea dedicated to Athena Alea. The extant phase of the temple is attributed to Skopas who was responsible for rebuilding following a fire in 394 B.C.
    Creators: G. Reger; J. McK. Camp II
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; DARMC; R. Talbert
  • Temple of Athena (Ilium)
    The Temple of Athena at Ilion was a peripteral temple executed in the Doric order with a 12 x 6 columnar arrangement. Its creation is traditionally ascribed to Lysimachus (ca. 301-281 BCE), though it was later restored under Roman influence, likely during the principate of Augustus. Little of the temple, save its forecourt, remains in situ. It is mostly known from membra disiecta, including metopes uncovered during Schliemann's excavations.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Athena Lindia
    A Doric temple dating ca. 300 BC located on the acropolis of Lindos. The sanctuary stands above a grotto that likely housed the earlier phases of the cult. The amphiprostyle temple has an elongated floor plan and measures 7.75 x 21.65 m.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Athena (Miletus)
    The Temple of Athena in Miletos dates originally to the sixth century BCE, although the visible remains on site today belong to the Classical rebuilding of MIletos (ca. 479-450 BCE). The temple had a peripteral plan and was executed in the Ionic order. Unusually, its axis is oriented north-south.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Athena Nike
    A temple dedicated to Athena Nike constructed on the Athenian Acropolis between 449 and 420 BCE.
    Creators: Hector Meredith; Katha Rajan
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Temple of Athena (Thasos)
    An archaic temple of Athena on the acropolis of Thasos was dismantled in the 5th century BCE. Planning, procurement of materials, and construction of its replacement seem to have begun shortly thereafter, but were never finished.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Augustus et Livia
    The so-called Temple of Augustus et Livia dates ca. 10 B.C. and was originally dedicated to Roma and Augustus. The temple was located on the ancient forum of the city. By the fifth century the temple had become a Christian church. It was extensively restored in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Baalshamin
    Temple in Palmyra dedicated to the Canaanite god Baalshamin.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Bêl
    Temple building located on the northwest side of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Bel at Dura-Europos
    A temple building located on the northwest side of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Dedwen
    An ancient Egyptian temple that was dedicated to Dedwen, the Nubian serpent goddess. It was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979, as part of "Nubian Monuments from Abu Simbel to Philae". It was relocated to its current location.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Temple of Demeter and Kore
    A Punic and Roman temple sacred to Demeter and Kore located at Bagoi, Perdaxius, Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Derr
    A rock-cut temple (speos) located in Lower Nubia, the Temple of Derr was built by Pharaoh Ramesses II (19th Dynasty). The temple was relocated to its current position in 1964 along with the Temple of Amada.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Diana
    The temple in the forum of Augusta Emerita is conventionally known by the misnomer "Temple of Diana", yet was actually dedicated to the Imperial cult.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Dionysos at Teos
    A Temple of Dionysos in the Ionic order begun in the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Ellesyia
    A small rock-cut temple dedicated to Amun, Horus, and Satis dated to the 18th Dynasty. Originally located near Qasr Ibrim/Premis, the temple was relocated to the Museo Egizio in Turin, Italy, in the 1960s prior to the area's flooding beneath the surface of Lake Nasser.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Enodia
    Pherai was the main cult center of the goddess Enodia. At the site are today the foundations of the temple of Enodia (or Ennodia).
    Creators: Dan Diffendale
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Fortuna (Jublains)
    Centerpoint of sanctuary at modern Jublains
    Creators: Johan Åhlfeldt; Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Hathor
    The Temple of Hathor at Deir el-Medina dates to the reign of the Ptolemies. It was later repurposed as a Christian installation known as Deir el-Medina or "Monastery of the City", from which the site's modern toponym is derived.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Hathor Miskar
    A Punic temple founded in the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Heracles
    The Temple of Heracles is one of the oldest temples in the Valley of the Temples in ancient Akragas, Sicily, dating from around the late 6th century BCE.
    Creators: Asta Rossi; Freya Schlaefer
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Temple of Hera, Mon Repos
    An archaic temple dating ca. 610 B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Hercules
    Remains of the fourth-century BCE Temple of Hercules are preserved in the edifice of San Marco d'Alunzio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Hercules at Montorio al Vomano
    A sanctuary of Hercules located in the territory of Teramo near the Vomano river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Hercules, Lanuvium
    The Temple of Hercules at Lanuvium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Horus at Edfu
    Monumental Ptolemaic temple dedicated to Horus, constructed between 237 BCE and 57 BCE at the settlement of Apollinopolis Magna.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee; Nate Nagy
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Ishtar at Assur
    From the late Early Dynastic period (ED III, ca. 2500/2400 BC) until 614 BC, there was a temple in the city of Assur dedicated to Ištar, a goddess who was revered in that important northern-Mesopotamian city in a few different forms. Several building phases (designated “Temples H–A,” from earliest to latest) were excavated by W. Andrae between 1905 and 1914. Periodically the location and orientation of the Ištar temple changed, especially during the reigns of the Middle Assyrian kings Tukultī-Ninurta I (1243–1207 BC) and Aššur-rēša-iši I (1132–1115 BC). The earliest and latest textual records for the existence of the temple date respectively to the time of Ititi, a local ruler of Assur during the Old Akkadian Period, and the reign of Sîn-šarra-iškun (626–612 BC), the penultimate king of Assyria.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jamie Novotny; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Iuno Moneta
    A major ancient sanctuary of the Capitoline Hill, the remains of which are likely to be found beneath Santa Maria in Ara Coeli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Janus, Autun
    A monumental first-century A.D. Romano-Celtic sanctuary located in Autun, Saône-et-Loire, France, to the northwest of the ancient city of Augustodunum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Jupiter (Silifke)
    A second-century CE temple sacred to Jupiter.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Kalabsha
    An ancient temple dated ca. 30 BCE was originally located at Bab al-Kalabsha (Gate of Kalabsha), some 50 km south of Aswan. It was relocated to its present site during the construction of the Aswan High Dam with sponsorship from the government of Germany.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Minerva at Theveste
    The Temple of Minerva at Theveste dates to the third century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Nabû of the ḫarû at Assur
    Sîn-šarra-iškun (626–612 BC), Assyria’s penultimate king, built a new temple for the god Nabû of the ḫarû at Assur. The temple was constructed in vacant lot that was next to the temple of the Assyrian Ištar. That Neo-Assyrian king modelled the temple’s plan on that the Nabû temple at Kalhu (Nimrud) and named it after the Nabû temple at Babylon. Egidrukalamasumu (“House Which Bestows the Scepter of the Land”) was destroyed in 614 BC, when Assur was destroyed by the Medes.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Olympian Zeus, Athens
    The Temple of Olympian Zeus is also known as the Olympieion. A colossal temple dedicated to Zeus, it was built in three stages, beginning in 515 BCE and ending in 131 CE.
    Creators: Celia Garb; Kyle Nash
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • Temple of Quirinus
    The Temple of Quirinus was located near the Capitolium Vetus. The temple was built ex manubiis by Lucius Papirius Cursor in 293 B.C., fulfilling the vow made by his father in 325 B.C. Tradition holds that the republican-period temple was sited on an even earlier altar dedicated by the Sabines. The topography and location of the temple are both matters of significant debate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Roma and Augustus, Leptis Magna
    The Temple of Roma and Augustus at Leptis Magna is a large temple (ca. 46 x 20 meters) situated on the so-called "Old Forum". It was initially erected between 8 BCE and 19 CE using limestone from Ras el-Hammam. The temple has a pseudo-peripteral temple and is oriented to the southeast. Reconstruction and restoration in the second century CE used marble instead of the original limestone.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Sîn and Šamaš at Assur
    A double-temple dedicated to the moon-god Sîn and the sun-god Šamaš existed at the city Assur from the Old Assyrian period onwards. The plan of this holy structure changed several times over the course of its long history, most notably in the Neo-Assyrian period, in the reign of Ashurbanipal II (883–859 BC). The Sîn temple was called Eḫulḫuldirdirra and the Šamaš temple went by the name Ebabbarra.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Soknebtunis
    A temple dedicated to a local form of the Egyptian god Sobek, Soknebtunis, at Tebtunis. The temple was built by Ptolemy I in the late fourth-early third centuries and was greatly expanded by Ptolemy XII in the first century BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Temple of Sulis Minerva
    1st century CE temple to Minerva at the Aquae Sulis in Bath, England in use roughly until 410 AD.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Tellus
    The Temple of Tellus at Rome was located on the Carinae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of The Gadde
    Temple at Dura-Europos named by excavators according to association with Gadde/Fortune of the city, but more recently recognized as a temple principally devoted to Malakbel.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Thelsae
    A well-preserved Roman period temple located in modern Dmeir, Syria. The sanctuary was later converted into a fortification.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of The Roman Archers
    Temple situated on a raised podium and accessed by stairs, dedicated to an unknown deity and located in Block A1 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of the Severan family at Cuicul
    A temple dedicated to the genius of the Severan family.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Thutmose III
    The Temple of Thutmose III at Deir el-Bahari was built ca. 1435-1425 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Trajan at Italica
    A sanctuary dedicated to Trajan in the 'urbs nova' of Italica that flourished under the patronage of Hadrian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Veiovis
    The Temple of Veiovis, also attested as Aedes Vediovis, was a temple of ancient Rome located on the Capitoline Hill in a location known as "inter duos lucos" that is interpreted to mean a saddle between the two summits of the hill. The remains of a temple podium were discovered beneath the northwest corner of the Palazzo Senatore in 1938-1939.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Venus Genetrix
    The Temple of Venus Genetrix located in the Forum Iulium was dedicated ca. 46 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Vespasian and Titus
    A temple in the Roman Forum dedicated to the deified Vespasian that was begun by Titus and completed under Domitian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Zeus at Lebadea
    The foundations of a temple sacred to Zeus at Lebadea. Pausanias reports that the temple was incomplete, owing perhaps to its over-ambitious size or to the nagging costs associated with warfare.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Temple of Zeus Kyrios/Baal-Shamin
    Temple building located on the southwest side of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Zeus Lepsinos at Euromus
    The Temple of Zeus Lepsinos at Euromus is located southeast of the ancient settlement. The well-preserved Corinthian temple dates to the reign of Hadrian.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Temple of Zeus Megistos
    Temple located in block C4 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Zeus Theos
    Temple located in block B3 at Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Temple of Zeus Trossou
    An epigraphically attested temple at or near ancient Atyochorion (modern Akkent in Turkey).
    Creators: Noah Kaye; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple or Large Administrative Building at Sikait
    A significant, large structure at Sikait in Egypt's Eastern Desert that has been variously identified as an administrative building and, most recently on basis of finds from the first systematic archaeological excavation of the structure, as a temple.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Temple to Nefertari at Abu Simbel
    The smaller of the two temples at Abu Simbel, dedicated to the goddess Hathor and the deified queen Nefertari. The temple was relocated between 1964 and 1968 to prevent its submersion under Lake Nasser after the construction of the Aswan High Dam.
    Creators: Nate Nagy; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies
  • Temple to Ramesses II at Abu Simbel
    The larger of the two temples at Abu Simbel, dedicated to the triad of Amun, Ra-Horakhty, and Ptah, as well as the deified Ramesses II. The temple was relocated between 1964 and 1968 to prevent its submersion under Lake Nasser after the construction of the Aswan High Dam.
    Creators: Nate Nagy; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies
  • Temple X9
    Temple of unknown dedication located in Block X9 of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • templum divi Claudii
    A temple dedicated to the emperor Claudius who was declared divus (deified) after his death in 54 CE. The platform temple occupied a large area of the Caelian Hill in Rome. The construction project was ultimately completed by the Flavians.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Templum Pacis
    The Temple of Peace in Rome was vowed by Vespasian following the Jewish War.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Templum Sol
    A sanctuary in the Campus Agrippae that was dedicated by Aurelian on December 25, 274, and funded by means of spoils taken from Palmyra.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Templum Veneris et Romae
    A double temple sacred to Venus Felix and Roma Aeterna built by Hadrian on the slope of the Velian hill to the north of the Sacra Via beginning in 121 CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tenuta della Lucchina
    An archaeological area in the suburbium of ancient Rome, now in the quartiere Ottavia, with multi-phase evidence for tombs of the Etruscan culture, a segment of a Roman road, and evidence for Roman villas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tepe Abdul Hosein
    Settlement site near Abdul Hosein village in Luristan, Iran dated to the Neolithic period. The site was occupied by non-sedentary people who left behind no structures besides a wall.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tepe Ghabristan
    Settlement in the Qazvin Plain intermittently inhabited from the 5th-1st millennia BCE; the westernmost of the three Bronze Age tells comprising the Sagzabad Cluster.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tepe Giyan
    An archaeological site located in the central Zagros mountain range where human occupation begins as early as the sixth millennium BCE.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tepe Sagzabad
    Tell site in the Qazvin Plain inhabited from the Neolithic through the Achaemenid periods; the central tell comprising the Sagzabad Cluster.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tepe Zagheh
    Chalcolithic settlement in the Qazvin Plain, Iran, occupied in the 6th-5th millennia BCE; the easternmost mound comprising the Sagzabad Cluster.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Termas Menores de Mura
    A Roman bath complex, located in the northeast part of the modern town of Liria in Spain's Valencia province.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Termas romanas
    One of the 19 Roman bath complexes identified in Mérida.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme Aquae Passeris
    A Roman bath located at Aquae Passeris.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme della Regina
    Terme della Regina, Tuscania (Italy).
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme di Caronte
    Mineral springs located at modern Lamezia Terme in Italy's Cantanzaro province. There is some archaeological evidence for exploitation of the springs in antiquity, but the current spa complex is completely modern in date. Some scholars have suggested that the Terme di Caronte may correspond to the "Aquae angae" mentioned on the Peutinger Map.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Terme di Cavascura
    A site of ancient thermal baths.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme di Tito
    The so-called "Terme di Tito" is a terraced Roman villa site located in the modern comune of Castel Sant'Angelo near Lago Paterno.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme Erculee
    The largest known bath complex of Roman Mediolanum, built in the late third to early fourth centuries CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme Romane
    Roman baths of ancient Luceria
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme Romane con Mosaici
    These Roman baths in modern Bevagna, Italy, date to the second century CE and were rediscovered in 1891.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Terme Romane, Ferento
    The Roman baths of ancient Ferentium are located adjacent to the Roman theater.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Terme romane (Regium)
    The excavations carried out following the earthquake of 1908 revealed a number of baths dating to the early centuries of the Roman Imperial period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tert-Aba
    Mound site in Khakassia containing burials associated with the Bronze Age Karasuk culture.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Thatcham, Berkshire
    A minor Romano-British Settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater at Arykanda
    The Theater at Arykanda dates to the first century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater at Cyrrus/Hagioupolis
    The Roman theater at Cyrrus dates ca. A.D. 100 - 220.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater at Madauros
    The Roman theater at Madauros in Africa Proconsularis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater at Patara/Arsinoe
    The Theater at Patara/Arsinoe dates to the reign of Tiberius and was subsequently renovated under the Antonines.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater at Pausilipum
    A small Roman theater with a capacity of approximately 2,000 spectators.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Theater of Assuras

    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Theater of Delos
    An ancient theater located in the settlement of Delos.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theater of the Muses
    A third- to second-century B.C. theater connected with the sanctuary of the Muses.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theater-temple complex, Monte San Nicola
    A theater-temple complex that stands within pre-Roman walls belonging to a period of Samnite occupation on Monte San Nicola in the municipality of Pietravairano.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theatre of Parium
    A Greek theatre at Parium that was reconstructed by the Romans in the second and early third century.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theban Tomb 359
    The New Kingdom tomb of the ancient Egyptian workman Inherkhau is located at Deir el-Medina and is part of the Theban Necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Theban Tomb 414 (TT 414)
    Originally the Saite tomb of Ankh-Hor, this site was reused from the 4th century BCE by the Late Dynastic/Ptolemaic period family of Pa-di-Amun-neb-nesut-tawy, a high-ranking priest of Khonsu.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Theban Tomb 69
    TT69 is located in the Theban Necropolis on the west bank of the Nile. It served as the tomb of an Egyptian official known as Menna, among whose titles were "Overseer of Fields of Amun", and "Overseer of Fields of the Lord of the Two Lands". The tomb is generally dated to the reign of Thutmosis IV.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • The Deir
    Monumental religious building carved out of rock in Petra, Jordan which was used for a variety of complex religious ceremonies and customs after the time of its completion in the mid-first century CE.
    Creators: Amir Weksler; Louise de Picciotto
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Thomas Landvatter
  • The Gordian Palace
    A large Roman Peristyle House with interior gardens, pools, and baths.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • "The Great Basilica" at Butrint
    The so-called "Great Basilica" is an early Christian basilica dating to the sixth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Theopetra Cave
    Located in Thessaly, the Theopetra Cave is an important archaeological site with evidence of multi-phase prehistoric human occupation. Radiocarbon dates indicate human activity beginning at least 50,000 years ago. Archaeogenetics have focused on evidence related to Mesolithic inhabitants of the cave site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • The Queen's Megaron (Palace of Minos)
    The Queen's Megaron is a room in the Minoan "Palace of Minos" at Knossos. It includes the famous Dolphin fresco.
    Creators: Patrick DeVarney; Tom Elliott; Austin Banda
    Contributors: Adam Rabinowitz; Andrew Shapland; Jeffrey Becker
  • Thermae Agrippae
    The Thermae Agrippae, built by M. Vipsanius Agrippa in the Campus Martius, were the earliest of Rome's great public baths.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Thermae Helenianae
    The Thermae Helenianae or Thermae Helenae was a thermal complex located in the Horti Spei Veteris, also referred to as the Horti Variani. The baths were situated near the arcus Neroniani adjacent to the Amphitheatrum Castrense. As Helena, mother of Constantine I, restored them following a fire in 323-326, they are named for her.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thermae Severianae
    Baths built by Septimius Severus were likely located south of the Baths of Caracalla.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thermae Titi (Tïtianae)
    Thermae Titi (Tïtianae), or Baths of Titus, were public baths built at Rome in 81 under emperor Titus. Located at the foot of the Esquiline Hill, the baths occupy part of the Domus Aurea of Nero. The Baths of Trajan were constructed immediately adjacent to the Baths of Titus in the early second century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thermae Traiani
    A monumental public bath of ancient Rome that was built between 104 and 109. The architect Apollodorus of Damascus built the baths for Trajan.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Thermes des Lutteurs
    A Gallo-Roman bath complex identified in 1991 at Saint-Romain-en-Galt that originally covered some 8 ha.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thermes gallo-romains, Pithiviers-le-Vieil
    A Gallo-Roman bath complex at Pithiviers-le-Vieil.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thignica amphitheater
    A Roman amphitheater at Thignica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Thimlich Ohinga
    A complex of stone-built structures in Migori county, Western Kenya, in East Africa, Thimlich Ohinga belonged to the Luo culture. The architecture is evocative of the Great Zimbabwe Empire located in Zimbabwe. The site was enrolled on the UNESCO World Heritage list in 2018.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tholos at the Sanctuary of Asklepios, Epidauros
    The Tholos, a circular structure in the Sanctuary of Asklepios at Epidaurus, was constructed beginning between 365-360 BCE. The Tholos was designed by Polykleitos the Younger and features Doric architecture as well as a constructed labyrinth beneath the floor of the structure.
    Creators: Alex Tagashira-McGillicuddy; Catie Herberg
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter; Alex Tagashir-McGillicuddy
  • Thrypti
    Thrypti, a mountain range of eastern Crete.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tibradden Chambered Cairn
    A prehistoric cairn located atop Tibradden Mountain.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Til-Barsip Archive 1
    In House C1 in the Lower City of Til-Barsip, 22 Assyrian clay tablets, as well as 2 Aramaic texts, were discovered in and around the doorway between Room XI and XII in a secondary position. The earliest text dates to 683 BC, during the reign of Sennacherib (704-681 BC), but most of the documents date later, to the reign of Ashurbanipal (668-ca. 631 BC). The archive belonged to a man called Hanni, with some of the texts also concerning a man named Ištar-duri, and consists of purchase and loan documents as well as some others, such as a juridicial agreement.
    Creators: Poppy Tushingham; Thomas Seidler
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Timpone della Motta
    The Timpone della Motta is an archaeological site located near Francavilla Marittima. The site was inhabited from the Middle Bronze Age onward. During the Iron Age, an Oenotrian settlement flourished here, one that developed into an important sanctuary. The site passed into Greek control in the later seventh century B.C. and was eventually abandoned following the Bruttian conquest of the region during the fourth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tırmıl Tepe Höyüğü
    An unexcavated mound on the outskirts of modern Mersin in Turkey. Archaeological surface survey yielded pottery dating from the Calcolithic to the Medieval periods. Atop the mound lie the much-depleted ruins of a possibly medieval fortification. Tırmıl Tepe Höyüğü numbers among the proposed locations of ancient Kundu/Kyinda.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
  • Tiscali
    A cave settlement on Monte Tiscali with the remains of over 60 huts.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tiszapolgár-Basatanya
    A Chalcolithic cemetery located at modern Polgár, Hungary, with at least 156 graves. This site is the typesite for the Tiszapolgár or Tiszapolgár-Româneşti culture, an Eneolithic archaeological culture. This archaeological culture has been identified on the Great Hungarian Plain and elsewhere in eastern, central Europe. It dates ca. 4500-4000 BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Titchikha Hillfort
    Fortified site associated with the Saltov-Mayatskaya culture (8th-10th centuries CE) located northwest of the modern village of Titchikha, Voronezh Oblast'. Remains dated to the Scythian period have also been found in the vicinity of the site.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Titus Tunnel
    A Flavian period channel cut for the purpose of diverting the course of a river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tofet
    The Punic tofet at Sulcis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb 3 (Tombs of the Kings)
    Tomb 3 is a rock-cut tomb with a peristyle courtyard in the "Tombs of the Kings" necropolis of Nea Paphos.
    Creators: Ariel Cooper; Matthew Redford
    Contributors: Tom Elliott; Thomas Landvatter
  • Tomba dei Carri
    A mid-seventh century BCE tumulus at Populonia with a diameter of 28 meters; part of the San Cerbone necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba dei giganti di Laccaneddu
    A Bronze Age "giant's tomb" in Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba della Montagnola
    A tholos-type tomb dating to the seventh century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba della Mula
    A tomb near Sesto Fiorentino, that dates to the seventh century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba dell'Arciere
    An Etruscan tumulus dating to the seventh century B.C. at the locality known as La Collina in the comune of San Casciano in Val di Pesa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba del Timpano
    A tomb of the Hellenistic period located close to a Graeco-Siceliote center.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba di Boschetti
    An archaic Etruscan tumulus located near Comeana, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba di Fadilla
    A Roman tomb on the Via Flaminia at Grottarossa that is associated with Annia Aurelia Fadilla, the daughter of the emperor Marcus Aurelius.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomba Lattanzi, Norchia
    A Hellenistic, rock-cut tomb at Norchia. The site is located within the modern municipal boundaries of Viterbo in Lazio, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tomba Torlonia
    An Etruscan tumulus-type tomb in the Monte Abatone necropolis of Caere that dates ca. 320-200 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tombe de l'Empereur
    A Gallo-Roman burial mound located at Moxhe Hannut in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb Garden of Aur(elius) Inachus
    An inscription found beside the Via Appia near the tomb of Cecelia Metella in 1851 identifies a cepotaphium, i.e. a tomb in a garden, belonging to an Aur(elius) Inachus.
    Creators: Yuyao Liu
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tomb Garden of Chaldaeus at Thyateira
    A single Greek inscription from Thyateira attests to the construction of a tomb monument with garden by one Chaldaeus. Its precise location is not known.
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Tomb Garden of C. Octabios Eutyches and Munatios Dionysios at Hypaipa
    Tomb garden built by C. Octabios (Octavius) Eutyches, Munatius Dionysius, and several others in Hypaipa
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Tomb Garden of Theodoros at Smyrna
    A funerary garden attested in text carved on a marble block from the settlement of Smyrna
    Creators: Annette Lei Guan
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Tomb of Annedia and Lucius Caesius
    The Tomb of Annedia and Lucius Caesius is an aedicula tomb in the Porta Nocera necropolis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Artaxerxes III
    The tomb traditionally associated with the Persian king Artaxerxes III Ochus (358-338 BC). Location based on OpenStreetMap
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Aulus Hirtius
    A tomb located in Rome's Campus Martius. Its remains are now submerged in the channelized waters of the Euripus canal beneath the Palazzo della Cancelleria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Aulus Umbricius Scaurus
    A tomb at Pompeii's Herculaneum gate that may be that of Aulus Umbricius Scaurus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Derecia Methe
    The Tomb of Derecia Methe is a house-type tomb located at the Porta Nocera.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Horemheb (KV57)
    Horemheb, final ruler of the 18th dynasty, was buried in KV57.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Lucius Ceius Serapio
    The tholos-type Tomb of Lucius Ceius Serapio and his wife, Helvia, stands near the Porta Nocera at Pompeii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Lucius Publicius Syneros, Aebia Fausta, Lucius Aebius Aristo and Aebia Hilara
    A partially enclosed house tomb.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Lucius Sepunius Sandilianus
    The Tomb of Lucius Sepunius Sandilianus is a Roman-period tomb, possibly of tholos typology, located in the Porta Nocera necropolis of Pompeii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Marcus Servilius Quartus
    A Roman tomb on the Via Appia dating ca. A.D. 100.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tomb of Marcus Venerius Secundio at the Porta Sarno (Pompeii)
    A tomb dating to the first century CE, excavated in 2021 in the necropolis of Porta Sarno at Pompeii.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tomb of Mentuemhat (TT 34)
    The largest private tomb in the Theban Necropolis, located in el-Assasif and containing the burial of a local ruler of Thebes during the 25th-26th Dynasties.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Publius Aelius Callistion
    The tomb of Publius Aelius Callistion, a freedman (libertus) of the emperor Hadrian, is colloquially known as the "Sedia del Diavolo". It is located in a piazza that derives its name from the tomb's occupant (piazza Elio Callistio) in Rome's Trieste neighborhood.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Seti I
    Tomb KV17 in the Valley of Kings was the burial place of the 19th dynasty Pharaoh Seti I.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Tomb of Seuthes III
    An elaborate tomb located near Kazanlak, Bulgaria. The Tomb of Seuthes III, who was King of the Odrysian Kingdom from ca. 331 to ca. 300 BC, is found in the Valley of the Thracian Rulers.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of the Kings near Enkomi
    Royal tombs of the Middle Bronze Age located near Enkomi.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Gabriel Moss
  • Tomb of the Nasonii
    The tomb of the Nasonii family is an ancient Roman hypogeum-type tomb along the Via Flaminia in Grottarossa in the northern outskirts of Rome. The tomb was exposed during road works in 1674.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of the Ottavii
    The mid-third century CE tomb of the Ottavii was discovered beneath the Villino Cardani (now at Via della Stazione di Ottavia, 73) on 17 August 1921. Based on epigraphic evidence, the tomb was occupied by the remains of one Octavia Paolina, her father Octavius Felix, and two other relatives. The archaeological remains of a number of ancient villas are known in the area, mostly lying on property that later belonged to the Colonna family.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tomb of Theron
    Theron was a fifth century B.C. tyrant of Akragas. A tomb located near the Porta Aurea of the city is traditionally referred to as being that of the tyrant.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of the Stronnii
    The Tomb of the Stronnii at Pompeii is a monumental altar tomb that is flanked by lions carved in tuff.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Thutmose III (KV34)
    KV34 served as the tomb of 18th dynasty Pharaoh Thutmose III.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomb of Virgil
    The so-called tomb of the Latin poet Virgil.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tombs of the Buccii and Melissaei
    The Grave enclosure of the Buccii and the Melissaei located on the west side of Pompeii's Herculaneum Gate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tombs of the Festoons and Frontespizio
    Two collocated tombs on the Via Appia - a Republican tomb belonging to the time of Sulla known as the 'Tombs of the Festoons' and a second tomb called the 'Tomb of the Title Page' by Luigi Canina who studied and restored it.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tombs of the Kings
    The "Tombs of the Kings" archaeological site is a Hellenistic and Roman-period necropolis associated with the city of Nea Paphos and characterized by large, rock-cut, subterranean tomb structures.
    Creators: Thomas Landvatter
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tomen y Mur amphitheatre
    An oval, embanked area of the north-east of the Roman fort has been identified as an amphitheater, one of only three known in Wales. The amphitheater is located near the site of the parade ground.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomen y Mur Roman bath house
    A bath complex associated with the first-century fort at Tomen y Mur.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tomen-y-Mur West Practice Camp II
    A temporary Roman camp of the first century CE located northwest of the Tomen-y-Mur Roman fort.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tongeren Gallo-Roman temple complex
    The Gallo-Roman temple complex of Tongeren is located in the northwestern part of the city of Tongeren. The site pre-dates the Roman city wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Topazios (island)
    An island in the Red Sea. The island is noted by Pliny as a source of topaz.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tophet of Carthage
    The Tophet of Carthage, also known as tophet de Salammbô, is a hybrid sanctuary-necropolis of Punic Carthage.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Tor Boacciana
    A Medieval tower, perhaps of the twelfth century, connected with the Bobazani family.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torcularium villa
    A Roman villa of the early second century BC constructed in opus incertum and named because of the presence of a torcularium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torraccio a Poggio Moiano
    A Roman mausoleum of the second century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Torreblanca del Sol (Fuengirola)
    An imperial Roman bath site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre degli Embrici
    An imperial Roman villa with a bath complex that emerged in the first and second centuries AD, transitioning to a fortified site after the sixth century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre dei Capocci
    The Torre dei Capocci, together with the Torre dei Graziani, was built in the twelfth century by the Arcioni family as a monumentalized entrance to the Esquiline.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre dei Conti
    A fortified Medieval tower located in Rome, dating to AD 1238, and built by Richard Conti, brother of Pope Innocent III.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre dei Graziani
    The Torre dei Graziani is a twelfth-century tower on the Esquiline Hill in Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre del Giudizio
    Torre del Giudizio is a Medieval tower built atop a pre-existing Roman site located near the fluvial harbor of vicus Alexandrini.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre de Urkulu
    A Roman tower monument atop mount Urkulu.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre di Centocelle
    A Medieval tower that was originally built in the twelfth century and is located near the crossroads of the present-day via Casilina and viale Palmiro Togliatti in the city of Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre di Donoratico
    An Etrusco-Roman fortified hilltop settlement that later served as a fortress of the Della Gherardesca family from the twelfth to the fifteenth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre di Pietra Pertusa
    A Medieval tower along the Via Flaminia near Prima Porta.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre d'Ischia, Vejano
    The archaeological site of Torre d'Ischia was identified in 1982, with evidence for Proto-Villanovan occupation.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre Maggiore
    A place located at the 21st km of the via Ardeatina, Torre Maggiore is likely built on the site of a domusculta and is connected to key Roman families, including the Savelli, Altieri, Capodiferro, Serlupi, and Maddaleni families. The tower has a square plan and rises to 34 meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre Scribla
    The remains of two towers of a Norman fortress near Spezzano Albanese.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre Spaccata
    The ruined Medieval tower (ninth and tenth centuries) is built atop the remains of a quadrangular Roman tomb of the Antonine period that was executed in opus latericium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torre Valca
    A Medieval tower (12th or 13th century) now located within the grounds of the Caffarella park.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torri in Sabina
    Torri in Sabina, a comune located in the Province of Rieti, Lazio, lies some 50 km north of Rome. It may succeed the Roman site of Forum Novum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Torrione di Micara
    A Roman tomb that was adapted for use as a medieval fortification. It is located near modern Frascati, southeast of Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tor Tignosa
    Tor Tignosa, mapped and listed in the 17th century Catasto Alessandrino as a landed estate, is a ruined stone structure located some 8 km northeast of Lavinium. Multiple votive inscriptions were found in the vicinity, providing evidence for an ancient sanctuary dating to between the fifth and second centuries BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Torvaianica
    A Roman villa near Pomezia discovered in 2006. The rich remains of the villa were uncovered along with at least 69 tombs.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tour de Biran
    The remains of a fortified Gallo-Roman tower.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tour de la Chèvre d'Or
    A Roman funerary monument.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tourraque d'Ortolas
    A Gallo-Roman tower.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tower 10
    Defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 11
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 12
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen

  • Tower 1 (Dura-Europos)
    A rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. The fortifications were built ca. 150 BCE. They were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.

    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
