  • Tower 21
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 22
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 23
    Rectangular defensive tower externally added to the western defensive circuit wall around the city of Dura-Europos and intended to cover a junction between stone and mudbrick curtain wall near the city's northwest corner. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 24
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the western side of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 25
    Rectangular defensive tower externally added to the western defensive circuit wall around the city of Dura-Europos and intended to add additional protection in a section of mudbrick curtain wall on the city's northwest corner. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 26
    Rectangular defensive tower externally added to the western defensive circuit wall around the city of Dura-Europos and intended to add additional protection in a section of mudbrick curtain wall on the city's northwest corner. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 3
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 4
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 5
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the northern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 5a
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the northeastern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 6
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 7
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 8
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower 9
    Rectangular defensive tower located on the southern end of the defensive circuit walls around the city of Dura-Europos. Built ca. 150 BCE, the city's fortifications were breached in 256 CE and went out of use thereafter.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Tower of David
    Fortification located near the Jaffa Gate in Jerusalem. The current structure dates to the Mamluk and Ottoman periods, and is on the site of earlier Hasmonean, Herodian, Byzantine, and Early Muslim fortifications.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tractus Umbriae
    According to Pliny the Elder, the Tractus Umbriae was the coastal territory near the mouth of the Umbro that was originally settled by the Umbri. It was located between Saena and Telamo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tralles ancient theater
    The theater of ancient Tralles.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Trayamar necropolis
    Punic necropolis on the southern coast of the Iberian Peninsula dated to the 7th century BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Treasury of Thutmose I
    Treasury of Thutmose I at Karnak from the beginning of the New Kingdom.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Trebbio
    An Iron Age settlement covering some 20 ha was identified at Trebbio, located to the south of Sansepolcro.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Trebiates
    An ancient tribe of Umbria that Pliny places in the sixth Augustan region.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tremona
    A multi-phase settlement - Neolithic to Medieval periods - that is now preserved as an archaeological site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Trenčin castle
    A castle located above the town of Trenčín in western Slovakia that preserves epigraphic evidence of Roman military activity during the Marcomannic Wars.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tre Ponti necropolis
    A necropolis along the Via Amerina, likely in use from the third century BC until the third century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tre'r Ceiri hillfort
    Tre'r Ceiri is an Iron Age hillfort located in Wales atop the easternmost summit of Yr Eifl, a mountain located on the north coast of the Llŷn peninsula in Gwynedd, northwestern Wales.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Troculu
    A megalithic "giant's tomb" in proximity to a nuragic settlement.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Trophonius oracle (Boeotia)
    An oracular cave sanctuary at Lebadeia (modern Greece). Pausanias reports seeing a cult image here that was made by Praxiteles.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Tom Elliott
  • Trou de Billemont Tumulus
    The Trou de Billemont Tumulus is a second century AD Gallo-Roman tumulus in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Trypillia
    Trypillia (Obukhiv Raion, Kyiv Oblast, Ukraine) was the site of an extensive proto-urban settlement of the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture ca. 4300-4000 BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • T͡Sart͡siaty Kalak
    Settlement site near the Georgian village Edisa in South Ossetia. Archaeological remains, including burials, were found in this site dating from the 11th-12th centuries CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tsitelbegebi
    Settlement site between the villages of Takhtidziri and Dvani in the Kareli Municipality of Georgia. The site has late-Achaemenid-Early Hellenistic and Late Hellenistic-Early Roman period cemeteries. This settlement has largely been washed away by flooding of the River Prone.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tuba
    According to the Babylonian topographical text Tintir = Babylon, Tuba was one of the four city districts of the western half of the inner city of Babylon and it contained three temples.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tuficani
    An ancient people of Umbria whose territory is now unlocated.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tulūl al-Fāj
    Two mounds from Parthian and Sassanian periods where Old Babylonian bricks have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tulūl Bismāyah
    Group of kassite mounds, some of which have been completely obliterated or covered by residential buildings.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors:
  • Tumuli of Koninksem
    A pair of Gallo-Roman tumuli dating to the first through third centuries AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulo del Principe etrusco
    A seventh century B.C. Etruscan tumulus located near Pisa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus aux Six Frères
    The Tumulus aux Six Frères (tumulus of the six brothers) is a Gallo-Roman burial mound at Dhuy in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus de Péré
    The Péré tumulus, or Pairé tumulus, is a Neolithic tumulus that dates from the fifth millennium B.C. The site is located in Prissé-la-Charrière, in Deux-Sèvres, in New Aquitaine, France. It is composed of three main megalithic structures, built at different times.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Tumulus of Avennes
    The Tumulus of Avennes is a Gallo-Roman burial mound dated to the Flavian period located in Liège Braives, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Avernas
    A Gallo-Roman burial mound located near Avernas-le-Bauduin, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Glimes
    A Gallo-Roman tumulus located near Incourt, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Havelange
    The Tumulus of Havelange is a Gallo-Roman burial mound located at Havelange, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Marcinelle
    A Gallo-Roman tumulus located nesr Marcinelle Charleroi in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Noirmont
    A second century Gallo-Roman tumulus at Chastre, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Noville
    A Gallo-Roman tumulus near Noville, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Vissoul
    A Gallo-Roman burial mound located near Vissoul in Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tumulus of Xhendremael
    The Tumulus of Xhendremael (known also as Li Tombe di Hên'mâl) is a Gallo-Roman burial mound near Xhendremael in Belgium. In 1933 the remains of a Roman villa were discovered in its vicinity.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tunnel of Eupalinos
    A sixth century B.C. aqueduct on Samos, the Tunnel of Eupalinos is an amphistomon, meaning it was excavated simultaneously from each terminus. The tunnel measures 1,036 m in length.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Tunni
    Tunni is a mountain in Tabal. Inscriptions of the ninth-century-BC Assyrian king Shalmaneser III (r. 858-824 BC) refer to it as "the mountain of silver."
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Turlu Höyük
    Tell Turlu (Turlu Höyük) is ca. 7 km northwest of Nizip (Gaziantep Province, Turkey), near the modern village Turlu. In 2003, a basalt stele of the Assyrian official Bēl-iddin (reign of Sargon II; r. 721–705 BC) was discovered there. The ancient name of this large site, which was occupied in the Neolithic Period, is not known.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors:
  • Turris Mamilia
    The Turris Mamilia was a tower in Rome's Subura that was part of the sacred rites of the Equus October.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tushqah
    Nubian Cemetery site along the Nile in use in the Middle Kingdom and the Second Intermediate Period. The site was inundated by the creation of the Aswan Dam.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Tusson tumuli
    An assemblage of four Middle Neolithic tumuli located in the territory of the commune of Tusson in the French department of Charente. The four tumuli are known colloquially as "tumulus de la Justice", "le Petit Dognon", "le Gros Dognon", and "le Vieux Breuil".
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tuzla-15
    An archaeological site in the western Taman peninsula containing the remains of several structures associated with the Maikop-Novosvobodnaya culture and dated to the late fourth-early third millennia BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Twann
    The village of Twann, Switzerland located on Lake Biel. The site has been occupied since the Neolithic period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Twee Tommen
    A twin Gallo-Roman burial mound located to the east of Monte Aachen, Belgium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tymphaioi
    An ancient tribe of northwestern Greece that belonged to the Molossian tribal state.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Tytkesken-VI
    Multi-period burial site in the northern Altai region. The bulk of the burials on the site are dated to the Pazyryk period (6th-4th centuries BCE), with additional burials from the Byikenskaya (8th-6th centuries BCE), Bulan-Kobinskaya (2nd-3rd centuries CE), and Turkic (6th-8th centuries CE) cultures.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Ulubrae
    An ancient settlement of Latium located near the Pontine Marshes.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Uluzibbira Roman amphitheater
    A Roman amphitheater located in the modern Essed-Nord village, west of Sidi Bou Ali in Tunisia's Sousse governorate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker; Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Umm al-Biyara
    Sandstone massif just west of Petra occupied in the late Iron Age, possibly with some reoccupation in the Hellenistic period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Umm el-Marra
    Bronze age city in northern Syria, located approximately 50 kilometers east of Aleppo.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Umm el-Qa'ab
    A necropolis at Abydos, Egypt, with royal tombs from the Pre-dynastic period as well as from the Early Dynastic (First and Second dynasties) period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg
  • Umm Marahi
    Fortified site in Upper Nubia in use during the late Meroitic through early Christian periods, built on a site with traces of inhabitation during the Mesolithic and Neolithic periods.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Unexplored Mansion at Knossos
    While Arthur Evans gave this archaeological site the moniker "Unexplored mansion", it was in fact an annexe of the "Little Palace" and post-dates it. The "Unexplored Mansion" was built in MM IIIB or LM IA.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Unfinished obelisk
    Although never completed, the 'unfinished obelisk' at Aswan in Egypt is the largest known ancient obelisk.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed bridge
    A Roman bridge across the Basento river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed bridge
    A Roman bridge located in the Parco dei Medici near Rome, Italy.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed bridge
    A Roman bridge located near Tullonio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed bridge
    This bridge in Liguria is also colloquially referred to as "the Roman bridge". The current 10-arched structure could have Roman origins and could be the place where the Via Iulia Augusta crossed the Merula.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Unnamed bridge near Concordia Sagittaria
    A Roman bridge near Concordia Sagittaria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Unnamed fortification
    An ancient fortification located northwest of Avlan Gölü. This place is discussed by Bean in regard to identifying the site of ancient Podalia in Lycia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Unnamed island (southern Akrotiri peninsula, Cyprus)
    An island comprising the southern portion of the Akrotiri peninsula, separated by ocean from the southern coast of Cyprus beginning ca. 6000 BP until early modern times. Remains of the sea channel are now represented by the land-locked Limassol Salt Lake. The extent of the island corresponded roughly to the modern town of Akrotiri and the air base.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed road
    An ancient road linking Nomentum and Eretum. Portions of the road are extant, particularly within an archaeological area at Monterotondo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman bridge
    An unnamed Roman bridge over the Fosso della Mola.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman bridge
    Located in the Comune Pabillonis in Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge crossing the Rio Mannu stream in Sardinia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman fort, Cheeke Street, Exeter
    A previously unknown Roman fort was discovered in Exeter between Bampfylde Street and Cheeke Street during the construction of a bus station in 2019.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman tomb
    An unnamed Roman tomb that is located near Casale Ghella.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman Villa
    The site of a probable Roman villa located near Farndon, Cheshire.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Unnamed Roman villa
    The cryptoporticus of an Augustan-period villa that later came to be incorporated in the substructure of the abbey of Santa Maria Maddalena in Armillis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Upper Agora at Akragas/Agrigentum
    The Upper Agora at Akragas at Poggetto di San Nicola is the site of the ekklesiasterion, the so-called "Oratory of Phalaris", and the bouleuterion.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Upper Chambers at Kalhu
    This ornately-decorated, elevated building might have been the residence of Sammu-ramat (the legendary Semiramis) in the palace of her son Adad-nārārī III (r. 810-783 BC) at Kalhu (biblical Calah, modern Nimrud). Because these rooms were built noticeably higher than the surrounding area, its first excavator Austen Henry Layard believed that he had uncovered part of an upper floor of an Assyrian palace and, therefore, referred to this area as the “Upper Chambers.”
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Uragh Stone Circle
    A stone circle measuring 33 by 26 feet with 11 standing stones located near Gleninchaquin Park, Tuosist, County Kerry, Ireland.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Urso theater
    The Roman theater of Urso.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Usovo Ozero
    Settlement from the Late Bronze Age Srubnaya Culture located in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 1.8km southwest of Yampil.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Vakilabad
    Hill in Southern Iran with pottery remains from the end of the Bakun period, through the Uruk period, and into the Proto-Elamite period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Valcamonica
    Located in the Lombardy plain, the Valcamonica assemblage constitutes one of the world's greatest collections of prehistoric petroglyphs – created over a period of 8,000 years. The site was enlisted by UNESCO in 1971.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Valdonega Roman villa
    The Roman villa of Valdonega near Verona dates to the first century A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Valle Bona-Monte Rosello necropolis
    A Hellenistic necropolis of Suana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Varaha Cave
    The modern name of a seventh-century Pallava cave temple in Mahābalipuram.
    Creators: Emmanuel Francis
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Variscourt
    A Gallic oppidum located at the confluence of the Aisne and the Suippe.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vasanello
    The modern Vasanello lies on the line of the Via Amerina. Some scholars have long speculated that it is a candidate for being the ancient "Castellum Amerinum". Settlement at the site begins with the Etruscans.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vasconum saltus
    A forest, now unlocated, in the territory of the Varduli.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vatican Obelisk
    An obelisk from Heliopolis in Egypt that the emperor Caius erected in the Circus Gaii et Neronis. It now stands in St. Peter's square in Vatican City, having been re-erected there by Domenico Fontana in 1586.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vaticanus Ager
    A district on the right bank of the river Tiber, between the lower course of the river and the territory of Veii.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vega del Mar
    A paleochristian basilica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Ventimiglia Roman Theater
    A Roman theater at modern Ventimiglia in Italy, dating to the early second century CE.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Very Island
    Island in Lake Turgoyak, Chelyabink Oblast, containing a number of megalithic monuments dated to the Neolithic Period.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Via della Monachina necropolis
    A necropolis at the thirteenth kilometer of the Via Aurelia excavated between 2007 and 2011. A total of 332 tombs were identified at the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Via Livenza hypogeum
    A painted hypogeum tomb of the fourth century A.D. discovered in 1923 between the via Livenza and the via Po.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Via Ostiensis necropolis
    A necropolis at Ostia that began during the second century B.C. on the south side of the Via Ostiensis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Via Ostiensis viaduct
    A viaduct of the ancient Via Ostiensis that purportedly dates to the republican period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Via Pollenza Roman villa
    A Roman villa complex that was occupied beginning in the first century BCE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Via Pompeia?
    An ancient road of Sicily linking Syracuse and Messina.
    Creators: R.J.A. Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Sean Gillies; Tom Elliott; R. Talbert
  • Via Rovigno d'Istria catacombs
    A small catacomb on two levels was discovered excavated in the tuff bedrock in 1953-1954 near the tract of the modern Via Prenestina in the Via Rovigno d'Istria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • via Taranto columbaria
    Two Roman columbaria are located under the present via Pescara, 2. This accounts for the tomb being referred to interchangeably with two modern, street-derived toponyms, namely "via Taranto" and "via Pescara". These tombs are situated near the ancient crossroads of the via Latina and the via Labicana.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Via Veientana
    The ancient Via Veientana led from Etruscan Veii to the Tiber river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vicus Sobrius
    A street in Rome mentioned by Festus.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • vicus vitrarius
    A street in Regio I known only from the Regionary Catalogues.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Viglafia tower
    The remains of a square tower in Lakonia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling
  • Vigna Bevilacqua
    In 1834, Edward Dodwell documented a substantial tract of polygonal masonry walling at Bevilacqua near Frascati that was thought to be associated with a Roman villa platform.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vila Nova de S. Pedro
    A Chalcolithic archaeological site occupied ca. 2600 to 1300 BC.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Vilarenc
    The villa dates from the first century B.C. to the third century A.D. when it was transformed into a bath complex. It was partially reclaimed as a villa in late Roman and Medieval times.
    Creators: Qianli Jiang
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Villa Augustea
    The so-called “Villa of Augustus” at Somma Vesuviana was first discovered in the late nineteenth century. The villa has been shown to have survived the 79 CE eruption of Mt. Vesuvius but was eventually destroyed by a volcanic event in 472.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Cardillio
    Remains of a Roman villa located in the modern Torres Novas Municipality, Santarém District, Portugal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa Commedia
    A villa on Lake Como described by Pliny the Younger. Scholars have long thought it must be located in the vicinity of modern Lierna, and 19th and 20th century finds of floor mosaics and other elements have led to conjectures that the villa must have been located either in the peninsular "Castello" neighborhood or in the core of the old town, which has long been known as "Villa" because of this conjecture. A mosaic from the latter area is now conserved in the Archaeological Museum of Lecco.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa dei Quattro Venti
    A monumental villa complex that is known as the “Villa dei Quattro Venti” is situated on a south-eastern offshoot of the Circeo promontory, approximately 100 meters southeast of the historic center of S. Felice Circeo.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa dei Venulei - Terme Romane
    A first-century A.D. Roman villa and bath complex located in Etruria.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa del Cortijo de los Vila at Alameda
    Roman villa at Alameda, located near the modern town cemetery. It is also known as the “Finca del Moral”.
    Creators: Lai Ching Tsui
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Villa della Longarina
    The ruins of a Roman villa rustica located near modern Giardino di Roma, just north of Via Cristoforo Colombo southwest of Rome.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa della Pisanella
    A Roman villa rustica at Boscoreale that was first discovered in 1868 by Modestino Pulzella. The villa is best known as the findspot of the so-called "Boscoreale Treasure". Following excavation, the remains of the villa were reinterred.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa delle Terme degli Stucchi Dipinti
    An imperial villa, perhaps abandoned in the late first century A.D., located near Tor Vergata.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa dell'Incastro
    An ancient villa in Guidonia Montecelio, Lazio.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa de Los Villares
    A Roman villa about 200 meters south of the center of the modern village of Santervas del Burgo and about 100 meters south of the left bank of the river Cejos.
    Creators: Yiyun Liu
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Jeffrey Becker
  • Villa del Río Roman bridge
    A Roman bridge along the Via Augusta.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa del Torrino (sito 8)
    A villa rustica located on a small hill along the Via Ostiense that likely dates to the first century B.C. It occupies the archaic Torrino site that dates to the sixth and fifth centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa di Casale Ghella
    A villa complex at the eighth mile of the Via Cassia, to which it was linked by means of a paved diverticulum. The first phase dates to the first century BCE and the villa remains in use until the Late Antique period.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa di Fralana
    The remains of the so-called villa of Fralana belong to the villa rustica type. Mosaic floors have been discovered at the site, in addition to a productive area that may have included a Torcularium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa Dionysos (Knossos)
    A Roman-period urban 'villa' at Knossos was excavated by R. W. Hutchinson (1935) and M. R. E. Gough (post-World War II). Based on pottery evidence, the villa dates to the second century CE and comes to be destroyed ca. 170-180.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa di Pipiano
    A Roman nymphaeum dating ca. A.D. 50-55.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa di Podere Anna
    The ruins of a Roman villa rustica were discovered in the 1990s along via Diego Fabbri. The site dates to the first century B.C. and remained in use at least until the fifth century A.D. The remains of a bath complex are substantial.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa di Rufione
    The Villa di Rufione is a villa rustica located along the via Flaminia Vetus, between the hamlets of Montecchio and Bastardo in località Toccioli. The site begins its life in the late republican period and continues in use until the fourth century CE.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa El Soldán (The Sultan)
    A Roman villa 300 meters east northeast of the eastern tip of Laguna Cernea, north of the modern village Santa Colomba de Somoza. Constructed under Tiberius, it was likely the residence of the official in charge of gold extraction.
    Creators: Yiyun Liu
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee; Tom Elliott
  • Villamargo
    A Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa of Asellius
    A Roman villa excavated at Boscoreale in 1903 and 1904 under the supervision of Vincenzo De Prisco and located on the property of one Giuseppe De Martino. Wall paintings and artifacts were recovered from the site and it was subsequently reinterred. Records as to its precise location are less than optimal.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa of Caius Olius Ampliatus
    A 'Villa rustica' associated with one Caius Olius Ampliatus located in the Ponticelli of Naples, Italy. The site was excavated in 1986-1987, with additional work in 2007. The site covers some 2,000 sq. meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa of Lucius Nonius Calpurnius Torquatus Asprenas
    The remains of a Roman villa on the Via Ostiense have been linked to Lucius Nonius Calpurnius Torquatus Asprenas.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa of Masseria Ciccotti
    A Roman villa along the via Herculea near Oppido Lucano.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Villa of Numisia Procula
    A second-century CE villa along the Via Ardeatina. Located at Tor Marancia, the site of the villa is the findspot of numerous significant objects of art, including sculptures of Commodus and Faustina. An inscription identified Numisia Procula as the villa's likely owner. The villa was excavated in the nineteenth century but is no longer extant.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa of the Frescoes
    Referred to both as the House and the Villa of the frescoes, this seaside Roman domestic complex with a peristyle garden covered more than 1,000 square feet and dates to the second century A.D.
    Creators: Brandon Wilson
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Villa on the Property of D'Acunzo
    A villa rustica excavated and reinterred in 1903 located near the Boscoreale train station.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Prato, Sperlonga
    A villa rustica excavated by the École française de Rome between 1979 and 1984.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Regina, Boscoreale
    A villa rustica at Boscoreale discovered in 1977. This is the only villa site currently visible and has been subjected to more modern excavation and analysis.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Romana ai Cavallacci
    A Roman villa first occupied in the Late Republican period and abandoned ca. the fifth century AD.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Romana Baláca
    The site of a Roman villa that was discovered in 1904 in the Balácapuszta field of Vámos village in western Hungary.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Villa romana di Acque Fresche a Civitavecchia
    Ruins of a Roman coastal villa located at Acque Fresche in the comune of Civitavecchia.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Romana di Casalotti
    A villa site that includes a bathing complex, dating from the second to fourth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Romana di S. Andrea
    The partially preserved structural remains of an Imperial villa dating to the third and fourth centuries.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Rufinella
    The Villa Rufinella stands on the site of a terraced Roman villa. The site occupies one of the most commanding positions on the slope above what is now Frascati, placing it in the ancient environs of Tusculum.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa San Giovanni in Tuscia
    A Roman villa of the third and fourth centuries A.D.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Villa Sora
    A coastal villa in the 'contrada Sora' area of Torre del Greco, a district with a great many archaeological remains.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vitozza
    Vitozza is an ancient settlement located near the village of San Quirico. Its rock-cut habitations were in use by the Etruscans and Romans and again during the medieval period, continuing up to the eighteenth century. Over 200 caves (columbaria) have been cut in the local tufo bedrock.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Vivios
    Remains of a Roman villa.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Ryan Horne
  • Vižula Maritime Villa
    An extensive maritime villa of the Roman period occupied the western and southern coasts of the Vižula peninsula, located near modern Medulin in Croatia.
    Creators: Francis Tassaux
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Voconius Pollio villa
    A Roman villa commonly associated with Q. Voconius Pollio that was excavated in the nineteenth century.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Voley Castle
    Voley Castle is an Iron Age hill fort located in Devon, England, on a promontory on Heale Down.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Volna 1
    Site on the Kerch Strait inhabited from the 6th century BCE-4th century CE, and resettled in the 8th-9th, 12-13th, and 17th-18th centuries CE. Rescue excavations were conducted on the site from 1996-2012.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors:
  • Vosgepag
    Vosgepag was the Armenian name for a small village near Van in eastern Turkey (now officially called Beşçatak in Turkish). In its church, a reused building inscription of the Urartian king Minua (9th / 8th century BCE) was found.
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Jeffrey Becker; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
  • Voudeni Cemetery
    The Voudeni Cemetery is a Mycenaean cemetery in Achaea, Greece, that was used from ca. 1500-1050 BCE. The archaeological exploration of the site began in 1923 under Nikolaos Kyparissis.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Brady Kiesling; Jeffrey Becker
  • Vounous-Bellapais
    A series of Bronze Age tombs were excavated at Vounous-Bellapais in the early 1930s.
    Creators: Clifflena Tiah
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Vounous Cemetery (Cyprus)
    Cemetery site in northern Cyprus near Kyrenia with Bronze Age remains.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Vrysi tou Barba
    One of the few known coastal Early and Middle Bronze Age sites in Cyprus. This site is a cemetery located in modern Lapithos, Cyprus.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Vussem aqueduct
    Part of the Eifel aqueduct supplying Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wadi Qitna
    Late Roman-Early Byzantine cemetery at the point where the Wadi Qitna met the Nile. The graves were tumuli and covered 1200 meters. The site was deluged upon the creation of the High Aswan Dam.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Wadi Zoumayli Site
    Settlement site between Gilat and Beer Sheva in the Negev in Israel. This site was inhabited during the Chalcolithic period.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Wall0001, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0002, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0003, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0004, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0005, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0006, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0007, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the west wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0008, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the south wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0009, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the east wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0010, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the east wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall0011, Synagogue (Dura-Europos)
    Portion of the north wall of the Assembly Hall from Synagogue Phase 2 in Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Wall Street
    Western-most N-S street in the orthogonally gridded plan of Dura-Europos.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker; Kyle Conrau-Lewis; Tom Elliott
  • Walma
    Minor Bronze Age kingdom of Western Anatolia whose exact location(s) and extent are matters of scholarly debate. It bordered the kingdoms of Arzawa, Pitašša, and Tarhuntašša, and may have been centered around the settlement known in the Classical period as Hormoi in Phrygia.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Noah Kaye; Tom Elliott
  • Water Eaton Roman camps
    A series of Roman camps on the River Penk along the line of Watling Street.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Welzheim: Ostkastell
    One of two Roman forts located at modern Welzheim in Germany, the excavated remains of the "Ostkastell" are largely preserved. The west gate and a portion of the associated defensive wall was reconstructed in the 1970s.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors: Nina Willburger
  • Welzheim: Westkastell
    One of two Roman forts located at modern Welzheim in Germany, the site of the "Westkastell" is largely overbuilt with modern structures today.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Wesseling Roman Villa
    A villa rustica at modern Wesseling.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Western necropolis at Egnatia/Gnathia
    The western necropolis at Egnatia/Gnathia includes some tombs of the Messapian culture dating from the middle of the fourth to the second centuries B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Whitemoss Roman auxiliary fort
    A Roman auxiliary fort built ca. A.D. 140 that protected the western flank of the Antonine Wall.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Whitton Lodge Roman Villa
    Whitton Lodge is the site of a later Prehistoric settlement enclosure that developed into a Roman villa. The site was identified in the twentieth century by means of cropmarks. Nothing is visible at the surface today.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wilderness Plantation Roman fortlet
    A fortlet was identified via aerial photographs in October 1965. In this vicinity, the Antonine Wall runs roughly parallel between the River Kelvin to the north and the Forth and Clyde Canal to the south.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wimblington
    The site of a Romano-British settlement located in Wimblington, Cambridgeshire, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wincobank hill fort
    Wincobank hill fort is an Iron Age hill fort near Sheffield, England. The fort covers ca. 10,000 square meters.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Winningen
    A Roman villa rustica.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wittenham Clumps
    Wittenham Clumps describes a group of small hills in the Thames Valley where archaeological remains of Iron Age hill forts have been identified.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Woodhouses Hill Fort
    Woodhouses hill fort is an Iron Age hillfort located in Cheshire, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wrekin Hill Fort
    Wrekin Hill Fort is an Iron Age Hill fort covering ca. 8 ha located in Shropshire, England.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Wymondley Roman Villa
    A ruined Romano-British villa located near Hitchin, Hertfordshire, England, in the valley of the River Purwell.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • X7 Barracks
    Military barracks reworked from private houses in Block X7 at Dura-Europos, located east and north of the X7 temple.
    Creators: Anne Chen
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Xocalı
    Extensive groups of Iron Age tumuli in the Lesser Caucasian mountains. A Neo-Assyrian seal bearing the name of Adad-nirari II (911-891 BCE) was found here during excavations in 1895.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Yacimiento arqueologico de Doña Blanca
    An archaeological site with multiple settlement horizons.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Yasin Tepe, Sualymaniayh
    An anthropic mound or tell located in Iraq's Sulaymaniyah Governorate.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Yassıhöyük
    A mound site in Kırşehir province in Turkey containing a palace or temple structure dated to the first half of the 2nd millennium BCE or the first half of the 1st millennium BCE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Gabriel Mckee
  • Yedikilise
    Destroyed Armenian monastery in the village of Bakraçlı where Urartian inscriptions have been found.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Yesemek
    Quarry and sculpture workshop founded under the Hittite king Suppiluliuma in the 14th century BCE.
    Creators: Gabriel Mckee
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Yortan
    Cemetery in modern Turkey's Manisa province with remains from the Early Bronze Age. This is the typesite for the Yortan archaeological culture.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Yukarı Anzaf
    Site for Urartian palace and citadel.
    Creators: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg
    Contributors: Tom Elliott
  • Yurtbaşı/Melik Şerif
    A modern village in the Refahiye region of Turkey's Erzincan province where remains of ancient roads and routes converge and where a Roman milestone has been found. In Roman times, it was likely a walled town or fort, garrisoned at some point by the cohors I Lepidiana. Scholarly opinions differ as to its possible names in antiquity.
    Creators: Tom Elliott
    Contributors:
  • Zababa Gate
    The Zababa Gate is one of Babylon's eight city gates and it is situated on the eastern side of the inner city, directly east of the TE.E quarter. King Nebuchadnezzar II built the gate ca. 575 B.C.
    Creators: Jamie Novotny
    Contributors: Jeffrey Becker
  • Zakisovaia Balka
    An unfortified Hellenized settlement located along the Bug river.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Zama Minor

    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Za Rodina
    A fortified Bosporan site near Temriuk that was founded no later than the fourth century B.C.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Zartepa
    Bactrian walled settlement in Southern Uzbekistan that had a walled citadel and a palace within and probably had a moat outside. The settlement also had a Buddhist sanctuary. The site dates from the 4th-2nd centuries BCE and was occupied until the 5th-7th centuries CE.
    Creators: Zachary Rosalinsky
    Contributors:
  • Zingsheim
    A Gallo-Roman temple of the Matronae Aufaniae.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
  • Zivistan/Elmalık
    Elmalık (formerly Zivistan, Zewestan) is a village in the Van Province in the southeast of Turkey ca. 12 km to the south of Van. Two small Urartian fortresses have been found in the immediate vicinity, which are known as Aşağı Zivistan Kalesi ("Lower Zivistan Castle") and Yukarı Zivistan Kalesi ("Upper Zivistan Castle"). On the basis of several Urartian stone inscriptions of the Urartian king Išpuini (9th century BCE) (CTU I A 2-2 - A 2-4) and one rock inscription of the same king (CTU I A 2-5), both fortresses can be dated to the the reign of the Urartian king Išpuini (9th century BCE).
    Creators: Birgit Christiansen
    Contributors: Carolin Johansson; Rune Rattenborg; Tom Elliott
  • Zorats Karer
    Zorats Karer is a prehistoric archaeological site of the Middle Bronze and Iron Ages located in Armenia. Over 200 rock-cut tombs and monuments have been discovered at the site.
    Creators: Jeffrey Becker
    Contributors:
